identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Dr. Bruner states that western culture is faced with a crisis of values and he argues that foreign policies reflect our values. He explains the crisis in the nature of myths, ideals of society, the nature of the universe, and man; also, explaining the relation of myths to human condition and the intellectual community, in search for identity. Economic well being and adjusted happiness must be equal among strong and weak nations, which in turn increases communication for the myth of self. Bruner states that we must be ready to look at revolutionary challenge in creating conceptions of man and nature through all aspects of economic and political power.

description#1: @00:22 Host introduces speaker @5:10 Fiedler begins @50:32 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Frederick P. Theime. He speaks of the counterculture as it split into political and cultural revolutions. The American "cultural revolution" since the mid-1950s was associated with black emancipation, but has also produced broader change throughout American popular culture. The nation has changed in human rights, media, politics, relationships, and even in how we portray our thoughts. We all experience many aspects of the culture, and we all differ from our past generations. With different kinds of people comes a revolution.

title#1: A Foreign Policy Fit for Peace
description#1: Moderated by Thurston E. Manning; 00:11 Unidentified student introduces Thurston Manning; 02:18 Manning introduces the panelist, Norman Thomas; 03:44 Thomas begins his discussion; 05:37 Thomas states he is going to focus on general foreign policy as well as war and peace; 06:58 Thomas states that the current generation needs to learn the expression â€œabove all nations is humanityâ€; 07:45 Thomas talks about the current state of the world and his concerns. He talks about the prospect of the United States spending billions on the anti-missile program to match Russiaâ€™s program; 12:42 Thomas talks about our evolutionary inheritance and how we cannot avoid war; 14:12 Thomas talks about the notion of loyalty and the human race. He mentions that human aggression should be used towards greater things other than war; 14:50 Thomas talks about all the war he learned throughout history in school; 17:00 Thomas talks about what should be done with foreign policy. He also talks about universal disarmament; 21:55 Thomas talks about communism; 23:55 He changes the topic to the war in Vietnam and communism. He talks about the history of Vietnam and how the United States got into a war with Vietnam; 27:30 Thomas mentions that the United States is intervening in a civil war in Vietnam and have used violence and force terribly; 30:00 Thomas talks about a letter he read in a Catholic paper regarding the request to stop the Vietnam War and asks Timothy to read the letter out loud; 34:44 Thomas talks about the United States president and how he stated he would stop the war and he hasnâ€™t stopped it. He mentions that the United States is not winning the war and questions whether we could actually impose the peace we want; 37:00 Thomas talks about international relations with China and the cost the Vietnam War has caused; 40:10 He talks about constitutional convention and encouraging pacification to villagers in Vietnam. He states there will never be negotiations between governments regarding the Vietnam War; 41:44 Thomas states he wished he was young enough to be president of the United States because he believes he could bring peace; 43:53 He hopes students will not forget Vietnam in their studies and hopes we can move towards disarmament; 45:20 Manning thanks Thomas and announces the next plenary session.

title#1: A Pax on Both Your Houses
description#1: Moderated by Keith E. Davis. Elizabeth Farmer discusses the morality of the US position in Vietnam. In a Q+A with the audience, she explains the place of morality in generalized foreign affairs and imperialism. Sanford Gottlieb also discusses foreign affairs in terms of morality, and Victor F. Isakov talks on the necessity of concessions in war. Farmer speaks on genocide and the use of force to protect minorities. Each speaker generally addresses the topics of morality, use of force, and protection of civilian rights through organizations like the United Nations.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by William Wei. The panel discusses affirmative action. Philip Hart relates a personal story to illustrate how affirmative action should function. Nancy Ramsey urges a data-driven approach to the affirmative action debate. Linda Gorman argues against government-mandated affirmative action because free markets tend to eliminate discrimination. Molly Ivins counters that perfect meritocracies do not exist, and that affirmative action is necessary to prevent discrimination. Audience questions cover specific court cases, different types of discrimination, and practical considerations.

description#1: @00:08 George Truesdale introduces the CWA Session as a part of the program "Challenge To Thought" @00:58 Quigg Newton introduces Tom Mboya @03:35 Tom Mboya talks @54:28 Mboya ends @56:00 George Truesdale concludes the radio broadcast @58:55 tape ends
description#2: Tom Mboya speaks about Africa's problems and its future. He describes the forces striving to free Africa from colonial rule and establish a new order. He talks about the territorial boundaries that were established without respect to geographical divisions or ethnic groupings. He concluded by stating that all Africa asks of the United States is understanding that Africans have the same desires as the U.S. is willing to fight for. Panel chair Quigg Newton presiding.

Talks about how Africa is struggling with starvation; 06:10 Discusses how Africa has been poorer than it has been and how African cannot afford anything; 09:58 Discusses that investment has dropped in Africa and reads a statistic; 13:12 Talks about elite minority and the presence majority; 15:09 Ayittey says there is more oppression than freedom in Africa compared to the colonial period; 17:38 discusses that Africans are being slaughtered by educated people; 22:02 Says that leaders stated only socialism will help them, but the socialism they got was wrong; 32:56 Says that America needs to listen because Africa needs freedom of expression and that Africa needs aid; 38:54 Says that America can condemn oppression in Africa; 39:09 Ayittey stops speaking; 40:20 Unidentified audience member asks if Africa can govern even though there are so many different factions. description#1: Moderated by Richard Schwarz; 00:12 Unidentified man talks about the size of the audience last year versus this year for the same panel; 01:45 [Richard Schwarz] starts the panel discussion by stating the panel will be conducted sort of like an Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) meeting. He also introduces the members of the panel; 07:00 Bill Weeden begins his discussion. He talks about how he is a member of Alcoholics Anonymous and how he has not had a drink for the last nine years. He also talks about how he used to drink every time he had a problem or to enhance his emotions; 08:30 Weeden talks about alcohol as a societal tool and how some people can mess up their life addicted to alcohol; 09:48 Weeden talks about living in reality after being sober for nine years. He used to drink to shut out reality. He also talks about functioning alcoholics; 11:23 Sue Korenbaum begins her discussion. She starts her talk about drinking and driving; 13:00 Korenbaum talks about a study done that showed most drunk drivers were men. She also mentions it did not matter what the legal drinking age was and concludes that the norms or social factors in our society are presented to younger people in a bad way, meaning â€œin order to have a good time, we have to drinkâ€; 16:05 Roger Ebert begins his discussion; 16:45 Ebert admits he has experienced the pain of those who drank and drove. He also admits he did it himself; 18:00 Ebert talks about the normal amount of drinks an average person should have; 18:55 Ebert talks about previous panels like this one and jokes about the topic being â€œdryâ€ this year. He continues to talk about how his approach to the panel is supposed to resemble an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting. He talks about how he is going to attend a real AA meeting that night and tells the audience they are welcome to join if they have a desire to stop drinking; 21:34 Ebert talks about the large amount of material written about alcoholism recently. He talks about the theories about alcohol such as the genetic transmission or genetic predisposition to alcoholism; 22:30 Ebert mentions the book â€œThe Natural History of Alcoholismâ€ by George Vaillant. The book contains a survey of people before they started drinking and how certain â€œpersonality defectsâ€ influence some people to drink alcohol; 27:59 Ebert talks about preventive measures to educate young people about alcoholism. He mentions the compulsion to abuse drugs and alcohol is so strong there is probably nothing we can really do until the abuser chooses to change their lifestyle. He also talks about alcoholism considered as a disease and help from hospitals; 29:40 Ebert mentions that according to AA one must â€œhit rock-bottomâ€ before realizing they need help; 33:16 Shepherd Brooks begins his discussion. He tells a story about driving on the interstate and eating at a truck-stop with other people around. He mentions how he noticed every table had bottles of wine and alcohol; 34:43 Brooks talks about beer and schnapps used as a tranquilizer and â€œbaby-sitterâ€ for children in Austria for years, but now it is a felony; 35:35 Brooks mentions that Australia has the worst amount of alcoholics out of English speaking countries. He continues to talk about the number of children that also drink in Australia; 36:53 Brooks states that there is conflicting information about the country that drinks the most alcohol. One study mentioned the Soviet Union was the country that consumed the most alcohol, but Brooks states that a different study mentioned that France was the country with the highest alcohol consumption. He also says Israel is the country with the lowest amount of alcohol consumption. He continues to say that societal influence in Israel is seen through the low numbers of alcohol consumption; 38:27 Brooks talks about the laws being enacted in several states so that the legal drinking age is changed to 21 years; 39:40 Brooks quotes from an article by Jane Brody in the New York Times. He also mentions the book â€œThe Better Way to Drinkâ€ by Roger E. Vogler. The book talks about the experience of having a .055 percent alcohol content in a personâ€™s blood; 41:27 [Bill Weeden] talks about the percentages that Brooks and Ebert mentioned and states those numbers do not matter to an alcoholic; 43:55 [Audience member] talks about the approach of preventing alcoholism and the image of the glamour of drinking in our society; 44:45 Brooks responds by stating that more students have been drinking less hard liquor within the last two years. He also talks about prevention. Another panelist talks about how there are many people that can drink socially well; 51:11 Korenbaum comments on Brooksâ€™ comment about students drinking more wine and beer and the perception of alcoholic content; 51:43 [Schwarz] reiterates the books mentioned during the talk such as â€œThe Better Way to Drinkâ€ and â€œThe Natural History of Alcohol.â€ He also talks about the book â€œIâ€™ll Quit Tomorrowâ€ by Vernon E. Johnson; 52:47 Audience member asks if alcoholics eat three nutritional meals a day; 53:37 Ebert and Weeden talk about the alcoholic blackout phenomenon; 55:55 [Audience member] talks about the alcoholic content ; 56:39 Brooks expands on his story of the truck drivers and people at the truck stop that he encountered drinking alcohol. He also talks about alcoholic content; 59:23 Unidentified panelist talks about the classification of alcoholics, that being the alpha, delta and gamma types; 01:01:48 Audience member asks the panel about the impact of alcohol on the brain; 01:03:42 Audience member talks about the nutrition gained of an alcoholic and mentions that the cells in the body will take the energy from the alcohol first and the body will not get any nutrition from the food; 01:04:53 Unidentified person talks about the education and norms with drinking. While he approves of the education in the country the message often goes to people already drinking or smoking and it is not really used as a preventive measure; 01:06:13 Unidentified person talks about the social consequences of drinking. She also talks about teenagers and drinking; 01:08:57 Audience member asks Weeden and Ebert for advice on helping a friend give up alcohol before they hit rock bottom; 01:15:13 Audience member states that it would be helpful for alcoholics to make the twelve-step program and other programs readily available. A panelist responds by saying he thinks the depiction of alcoholism on television is useful; 01:18:10 Unidentified panelist talks about the climate in Hollywood. He talks about the AA meetings in Beverly Hills and how the money, leisure time and egos or insecurity of people has led to cocaine abuse; 01:20:24 Audience member asks about the organizations that advertise on television. Panel mentions that it is probably dangerous to introduce someone to AA if they are not ready for it; 01:24:08 Audience member states that it seems the alcoholics he knows personally, as well as novelists, tend to be sensitive people and asks the panel if alcohol is a product to understanding the worldâ€™s pain; 01:30:44 Audience member asks the panel if it could be counterproductive for some people if alcoholism is labeled as a disease; 01:34:35 Audience member asks about raising kids and the perception of drinking that parents can instill on their children. Panelist does not believe in rigidity and does not trust people who do not drink at all; 01:43:16 Audience member talks about physical fitness and steering young people away from alcohol. Panelist talks about the public relations battle regarding alcohol; 01:47:07 Audience member asks the panel what to do if you are living or working with someone about to hit rock bottom; 01:53:07 Panelists talk about other panels they are presenting at and the discussion ends.

description#1: Moderated by Simon Hoggart. The panel takes the form of a news quiz game based on Simon Hoggart's British television show. Questions cover the Iraq war, popular culture, and current political events. The panelists use the questions as an opportunity for satire and political humor, telling jokes and creating fake movie titles based on the Bush administration and the Iraq war.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speakers discuss what it means to be an intellectual in nations such as the United States and Britain. It is reasoned that it involves one's political allegiance, leading from university to often work in government. The role of an intellectual is described through society's expectations, and one's work, performance, and interests. One speaker claims that the word 'intellectual' is more of an adjective than a noun in the US because it is almost a profession here, a way to self-recognize. All agree that the work and focus of an intellectual is in the life of the mind.

title#1: American Graffiti 50 Years of Social Pathology

Religious rights are appearing everywhere, just not the south; 16:06 Adams finishes; 16:21 Eric Sterling starts speaking; 17:10 Relationship between religion and spiritual; 20:09 Pathology breaks out in excesses and what drives them; 20:19 Fear drives everything and leads to problems. Fear has distorted how people think; 25:37 Sterling finishes; 25:45 Roger Ebert begins speaking; 26:34 Rise of television in America is leading to people being more isolated rather than social; 27:26 Talks about a pathology called tribalism. Also talks about civilization; 31:02 Talks about women from Afghanistan and how tribalism affects them. subject#1: Educational tests and measurements--United States--History--20th century
description#1: Moderated by Milagros Caraballo. Speaker Nicholas Lemann discusses the rise of standardized testing in bringing about the rise of meritocracy in the United States. He gives an overview of how meritocracy became associated with success in America, opposed to older forms of getting ahead, such as class and birthright. Lemann addresses the problems of the current system of meritocracy, and what the outcomes of the system have been, opposed to what they were supposed to be. He finalizes the talk by giving his thoughts on whether the meritocratic has been the right path to success in American society.

description#2: Moderated by William E. Briggs. The speaker explains the American and Soviet quest for dÃƒÂ©tente, which seeks respect and improved relations between both sides to protect their core interests. DÃƒÂ©tente aims to achieve a stable international situation and to prevent thermonuclear war. The speaker lists four American views of dÃƒÂ©tente: those who oppose any agreement, those who want dÃƒÂ©tente with the Soviets, those who support all agreements, and those who seek a mutual agreement. DÃƒÂ©tente might increase trade, enhance military power, improve relations with China, and relieve misconceptions that nations have of each other.

description#1: Moderated by Andree Kail. Pepper Schwartz begins by talking about body image and briefly defines what body image is. Shepherd Brooks explains why popular images are not what people should be like or aspire to be, and suggests people to be themselves and to be comfortable with it. Robert Ebert talks about bodies and movies. Ebert states that a story in a movie doesn't mean anything, and that it comes down to body language. Robert Irwin talks about how there is more than one definition in art. Irwin states why art is not an act of either communication or an attempt to inform.

subject#4: Conference for the Reduction and Limitation of Armaments
description#1: Moderated by Carl W. Ubbelohde; 00:16 Ubbelohde introduces the subject of the panel and the speakers; 01:30 James Avery Joyce begins his talk; 02:36 Joyce reflects on the time he was a student in Geneva, Switzerland where he attended the first World Disarmament Conference, also known as the Geneva Disarmament Conference, hosted by the League of Nations; 05:48 Joyce offers three propositions regarding the arms race and disarmament; 13:57 Joyce offers one last comment as the most important statement on international disarmament regarding the economic and social consequences of disarmament; 16:18 Recording cuts to introduction of Salman A. Ali; Ali talks about his experience living in a developing country and how the country spends a lot of money on defense and arms, even though the money is really needed for national development to improve the living standards of its people; 18:54 Ali offers a solution to disarmament, that being, the United Nations must be strengthened to replace national power and turn it into a world power to stop any one nation from imposing its will through military strength; 25:47 Recording cuts to introduction of Peter Mennell; Mennell also explains his experiences at the Geneva Disarmament Conference; 27:47 Mennell asks why the United Nations hasnâ€™t achieved more and explains that the organization is made of people with national interests; 28:20 Mennell talks about armament in small nations; 31:15 Mennell talks about nuclear testing and delivery vehicles in Russia as a first proposal discussed from the Geneva Disarmament Conference; 35:20 Mennell states he thinks scientists need to be away from politics and we need more input from the scientific community apart from government influence; 41:00 Mennell talks about nuclear deterrence and national polices. He also agrees with the United Nations gaining world parliamentary democracy and power; 45:44 Recording cuts to [Jux Henri Ratsimbazafy]; [Ratsimbazafy] offers several comments regarding disarmament and the Geneva Disarmament Conference. He says the conference is just the gateway to disarmament; 49:45 [Ratsimbazafy] talks about a visit to Cuba where he was told deterrence does not work. He continues to talk about smaller nations; 54:10 Recording cuts to Mennell. He responds to remarks made by the other panelists; 54:50 Mennell talks about economic development in nations and the investment towards peace. He also compares the military spending in the United States; 56:47 Panelists joke and recording cuts; 57:03 Ubbelohde asks the audience for questions. The first audience member comments that his impression is that most of the United Statesâ€™ foreign aid goes into military motives anyway. Unidentified panelist [possibly Joyce?] responds with examples of foreign aid from other countries; 58:48 Ali also comments on the military spending in the United States; 01:03:00 Audience member asks a question about economic aid from the United States to undeveloped countries. Joyce responds with examples about aid from England; 01:05:40 [Mennell?] also follows up with Joyceâ€™s comments about aid and international affairs; 01:07:41 Audience members asks Mr. Mennell a question about a proposal regarding China. [Ratsimbazafy] also responds to the audience memberâ€™s question; 01:15:03 Audience member asks Joyce a question about his remarks regarding changing the worldâ€™s concept of disarmament to a concept of peace and how we can develop trust. Joyce talks about a lack of trust with the Russians and needed cooperation; 01:19:00 [Mennell] also responds to the question about trust amongst nations; 01:21:00 Audience member asks Joyce a question about political and international sovereignty; 01:24:24 Panelists talk about the Rocky Mountain news; 01:25:00 Audience member asks a question about the press [catalogerâ€™s note: question is difficult to decipher]; 01:25:39 Recording cuts to an answer from a panelist; 01:27:44 Panelists finish with closing comments.

description#1: @00:00:01 Introduction of panelists @00:02:35 Richard Holbrooke talks @00:12:04 Holbrooke ends @00:13:02 Yukio Satoh talks @00:22:42 Satoh ends @00:23:00 Hebert Scoville talks @00:30:06 Scoville ends @00:30:25 Vladamir Tuminov begins @00:44:33 Tuminov end
description#2: Richard Holbrooke examines the different approaches to negotiations with specific reference to Vietnam, and his direct association with negotiations in Paris for the first year and a half. He talks of his personal experience, and then shares general observations. Discusses the philosophies of U.S. military officials in negotiations. Yukio Satoh explores Japanese foreign policy, as a member of Japanese Foreign Servic -- discussing its weak points, peace maintenance, and Japan's dependency on U.S. military power for security of Japan and its defenses. Herbert Scoville discusses a different approach to negotiations with specific regards to arms control. Vladamir Tuminov responds to other panelists, discusses chain of foreign policy, speech writing and foreign policy, gap between rich and poor countries. Chairman Thad Tecza presiding.

description#1: Moderated by Spencer (Spence) W. Havlick; 00:06 Havlick introduces the panel topic and panelists; 02:30 Beulah F. Rohrlich begins her discussion; 03:41 Rohrlich talks about her involvement with the Society for Intercultural Education, Training and Research (SIETAR) and experience with intercultural communication. She continues to talk about how each culture views the world and humor differently; 05:05 Rohrlich mentions that laughter is one of the extremes of emotion and talks about the philosopher Lin Yutang; 06:08 Rohrlich believes that laughter is a sign of someoneâ€™s mental health. She continues to talk about culture shock from international students; 08:15 Rohrlich talks about the third stage of culture shock which is the ability to laugh at yourself and the stupid things you do in another culture; 12:49 Rohrlich asks if laughter is universal. Is it something that exists in all cultures?; 13:25 Margot Adler begins her discussion. She talks about smiling as a physiological reactor to the brain; 14:50 Adler talks about laughter and religion; 16:55 Adler investigated theories of play and laughter. She quotes someone stating that play is the most important activity of human life and is rooted out as an adult; 18:00 Adler talks about her discovery of satirical religions, such as the â€œReligion of the Great Spider,â€ â€œReformed Druids of North America,â€ and the â€œWorship of Erisâ€ which was founded in a bowling alley in Los Angeles in 1958; 25:30 Adler reads Erisian philosophy by Robert Anton Wilson; 31:00 Rohrlich makes two comments on Adlerâ€™s discussion. She talks about her experience at Princeton University and attending church; 33:05 Rohrlich tells a joke about the pope that phones his mother; 33:50 While waiting for Annette Goodheart to arrive they take questions from the audience. First audience member states that you can read wanted ads in the publication â€œSoldier of Fortuneâ€ and talks about â€œPrincipia Discordiaâ€; 35:20 Rohrlich talks about tee-shirts used for communication. Havlick mentions that most of the tee-shirts seen while travelling are university tee-shirts; 38:45 Havlick talks about the literature regarding laughter. He also asks the audience for questions while Goodheart catches her breath. Audience member mentions that tears produced from crying contain different chemical compounds depending on the reason for crying; 41:18 Goodheart begins her discussion; 42:50 Goodheart talks about the â€œexcretionâ€ of laughter, and jokes about how serious the Conference of World Affairs is. She mentions that she brought toys to the conference and some people played with them and others didnâ€™t. She emphasizes that adults really need toys and play more than children; 46:45 Goodheart notes observations about cultural laughter and where it is okay to laugh; 51:20 Goodheart talks about how vital it is to our functioning to use the energy generated from emotions like fear and humor; 55:10 Goodheart states her business is to help people understand and use their emotions; 58:00 Goodheart mentions that you have to experience pain in a playful manner so that it is released; 59:20 Panelist asks Goodheart a question about drugs and laughter; 01:02:35 Panelist also asks Goodheart about her being invited to work at penal institutions. Goodheart talks about working with a senior citizen group; 01:04:47 Audience member asks for ideas to get yourself out of a rut of not laughing; 01:08:55 Audience member asks what Goodheartâ€™s definition of pain and its emotions is; 01:11:50 Audience member asks about laughter and sarcastic jokes; 01:17:50 Audience member asks about jokes; 01:22:40 Audience member relates to Adlerâ€™s statements about people acting smarter and asks Adler how to deal with those social situations; 01:30:40 Audience member asks about knowing the difference between genuine, real laughter and laughter; 01:32:15 Audience member asks about Goodheartâ€™s experience with doing work in hospitals with either the patients or the staff; 01:43:18 Audience member asks about book references regarding laughter and nonverbal communication. Goodheart mentions the book â€œTalk to Me Laterâ€ and other titles; 01:45:00 Audience member asks about the Type A personality; 01:45:25 Audience member asks about pain; 01:46:42 Havlick thanks the panel.

description#1: Moderated by Sam Kuczun. The panel discusses the media's coverage of and relationship with Ronald Reagan. Robert Brictson addresses the concept of â€œdoublespeakâ€ in politics, arguing that Reagan used it as a technique to foment fear of communism. Margot Adler examines what responsibilities the press has, especially relating to the office of the presidency. Molly Ivins challenges two assumptions: that the press is a uniform entity, and that objectivity is a desirable journalistic goal. Audience questions cover foreign policy, the economy, and the state of American news media.

description#1: Moderated by Mark Papworth; 00:21 Gerald M. Feigen begins the discussion by asking what the dialect is between the artist and the scientist, what is different, what is mutual, and what is the future between them; 04:40 Feigen offers a solution to reconcile the two professions; 06:05 Audio skips and Papworth asks the panel if there are any comments on Feigenâ€™s remarks; 06:14 Unidentified panelist states he thinks they should be talking about individual processes of art history and problem solving in science. The panelist continues to say that the arts and sciences have both benefited from each other; 08:30 Second unidentified panelist begins talking about the â€œancient quarrelâ€ and that art and science are different languages. The second panelist continues to mention that while the scientists promote technology, poets or artists â€œgive light to the worldâ€ and are the ones that help others understand science and technology; 16:40 Buckminster Fuller begins talking; 17:00 Fuller talks about Werner Heisenbergâ€™s experiments and the public perception of him; 19:50 Fuller talks about mathematician, George Boole and the preposterous things he would do; 21:38 Fuller talks about Picasso and his statement that â€œart is a lie.â€ Fuller compares Picassoâ€™s actions with Boolean mathematics; 31:05 Roger Revelle is introduced. He expresses that, in his opinion, the artist and the scientist are the most closely related because they require the same qualities such as a â€œseeing-eyeâ€ and a creative imagination to find relationships between phenomena; 36:40 Revelle continues to state that there is a greater estrangement between art and science; 38:34 [George Boas] mentions that the scientists are killing the artists; 41:03 [Boas] asks â€œwhat kind of mind is attracted to science?â€ and states his objections to science while the artist still maintains his amateur status; 44:12 Papworth asks Dr. Feigen to make a concluding statement since he started the discussion. He tells the audience to experiment with both art and science and no one has to be either role; 48:05 Audience applauds panel.

description#1: Moderated by Mary Ormsbee; 00:07 Ormsbee introduces the panel. The conversation starts in the middle of Thomas Powersâ€™ biography; 01:00 Jed Duvall begins his discussion. He states Haiti really needs more education and clean water and less weapons like tear gas, sent from the United States; 02:20 Duvall talks about the book series â€œWorld Military and Social Expendituresâ€ written by Ruth Sivard. He continues to talk about the American people that have benefitted from the money made selling goods to other countries; 06:03 Thomas Powers begins his discussion. He talks about the heart of the arms race between the Soviet Union and the United States; 09:06 Powers talks about the European order before 1914; 12:15 Powers talks about the conflicts in Central America; 14:05 Angela Delli Sante begins her discussion. She goes over figures and expenditures spent on arms; 15:30 Delli Sante talks about material deprivation in underdeveloped countries; 24:53 Delli Sante talks about the political and civil liberties related to the arms race; 28:10 Delli Sante looks at a way the world can use all the money geared towards the arm race and spend it on better things that would create more peace and less poverty for developing countries; 35:05 Eric Casino begins his discussion. He first talks about the situation in the Philippines; 39:52 Casino mentions, you cannot compare the arms race with trade; 40:21 Audience member asks Delli Sante for a reference of all the statistics she presented; 41:57 Audience member asks Delli Sante if there is a place where no amount of money can change it. In other words, even if money is sent to developing countries for education, some countries will go to extra efforts to kill or reeducate its educated people and the money will have gone to waste; 45:10 Audience member asks Duvall a question about how the media covers the arms race; 47:19 Delli Sante addresses a previous question about the money sent to developing countries; 54:28 Audience member asks Casino a question about Cory Aquino becoming a hostage of the United States; 56:00 Audience member asks Duvall about a widely felt impression that the media has not done a good job covering the arms control treaty and the fear people have about the topic; 01:03:03 Audience member asks the panel for an example of creating a situation in order to spur the arms race; 01:03:36 Audience member asks Duvall if it was a media problem or political problem as to why people have not heard about the invasion in Honduras; 01:05:28 Audience member asks about a black out in the news media regarding Honduras; 01:11:33 Audience member asks the panel how much money is actually paid for by developing countries on arms; 01:15:04 Audience member asks Duvall and Delli Sante what kind of incentive we could give to ensure peacekeeping without spending millions of dollars; 01:22:47 Audience member talks about the investment to create jobs over the investment spent in the military; 01:34:08 Audience member offers ideas for stopping the arms race; 01:35:00 Audience member asks whether we need to start controlling transnational corporations to produce better products like food and asks whether agribusiness is related to what is happening to the supply of food in developing countries; 01:38:10 Audience member asks about profitability and internalizing costs; 01:42:03 Panel ends.

description#1: Moderated by Randolph H. Hudson. Jiri Nehnevajsa believes that the U.S. will develop anti-ballistic missiles, which he views as unnecessary, because of political pressures put on the Presidential candidates in the coming election. Isador I. Rabi outlines the social, economic, and technological factors regarding the ineffectiveness of an anti-ballistic missiles system. Velma Linford states that the money that would have gone into building an anti-ballistic missile system would be better invested in a variety of social improvement programs.

title#1: Anti-Ballistic Missiles - Through Thick and Thin
description#1: Moderated by Adrea Rosenberg. Samuel T. Cohen describes the logical fallacies used by those for and against building an anti-ballistic missile system. H. Prescott Sleeper believes that the money that would have gone to building an anti-ballistic missile system should go towards finding peaceful applications of nuclear energy and that the use of nuclear weapons, especially in the atmosphere, could possibly have grave consequences.

description#1: From 1956-1959 there was a founding of a new more progressive middle east Â– changing with experiences to benefits the middle class and raise the standard of living; thus, contributing to better health, longer lives, and more education. The speaker argues that Arab socialism is much different than the Marxists socialism, noted differences being: a face of nationalism connected with industrialization, health programs, land reforms, and expanding education. In addition, he speaks of industry, foreign aid, manufacturing, and private enterprise for economic development.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Are We Breeding for Our Oblivion
description#1: The speakers illustrate the importance of birth control and population control. As well as the importance of educating children, usage of medicine, and the awareness of the social aspects that can affect and result from population growth. One of the speakers argues that the scientific curve should be applied to the field of fertility control to avoid population booms in the future. Actions must be taken for population control, especially for those who are less equipped (financially or otherwise) for parenting. As we increase scientific and technical capacity to invent the future, there must be an increased focus on predictions for the social arena and monitoring population growth.

description#1: Moderated by Phyllis Kenevan. John Newhouse begins by talking about what fourth world really means. Newhouse discusses the attitude of both the supplier and recipient countries of arms weapon. Christopher J. Makins talks about the key arguments regarding questions of leverage and the "if I don't, someone else will" argument that Newhouse has mentioned earlier. William L. Eagleton briefly explains why countries want arms in the first place. Ovidia Soffer discusses some concrete examples regarding the problems the other three panelists previously mentioned.

description#1: Moderated by Marie Fagan. Miroslav Nincic begins by talking about various ways in which engineering can create a stable and long term solution to arms race. James T. Bush states that the problem lies in the United States and Soviet Union losing any rational for building nuclear weapons. Bush also states that there is no logical end to the arms race. Charles Hauss states that the solution in the long run to the arms race is to build a shift to a new way of thinking. Peter Pringles ends the panel by talking about how the arms race was created.

description#1: Moderated by Wesley Posvar. Wesley Posovar introduces the problems surrounding arms control and the effects it has had on the world. George Rathjens discusses arms control specific to the Vietnam War and the Soviet Union. He highlights the differences between arms control and disarmament as well as the history of and changes to both. He explains nonproliferation in terms of international agreements and peace relations between the US and the Soviet Union. Sydney Giffons discusses the proper and improper methods to build an arms-control relationship and Dr. Martinn clarifies the points made by the previous two speakers. Colonel Marshner directly explains the military's point of view on the situation as well as societal misconceptions surrounding the role of the military. Marvin Kochstein explains public opinion and media coverage on nonproliferation. He also discusses the safeguards implemented in weapons testing.

subject#3: Treaty between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on the Limitation of Antiballistic Missile Systems (1972 May 26)
subject#4: Interim Agreement Between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on Certain Measures With Respect to the Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms (1972 May 26)
description#1: Moderated by Thomas Blau. Herbert Scoville begins by talking about two agreements on strategic arms limitation such as the ABM Treaty. Then, Scoville briefly talks about mutual balance force reduction and advices not to worry about the balance but rather about the mutual force reduction. Farangis De Munoz blames the military for creating the Vietnam situation and states that the military services have been running the country for a long time. Munoz questions why the military mind is dominated in many parts of the world. Stanley Reed ends the panel by stating that arms control agreement can be accomplished.

description#1: Moderated by Milton E. Lipetz. Adam Yarmolinsky begins by talking about a few arms control negotiation that the United States is involved in. He explains the purpose of SALT negotiations and provides three explanations on how progress has been made. Yarmolinsky briefly states that no one can win a nuclear war, and that non-nuclear nations of the world are concerned that nuclear powers are not moving rapidly enough towards disarmament. Yarmolinksy ends by stating that we are moving ahead slowly to a more peaceful world and provides four reasons explaining his reasons why.

description#1: Moderated by James G. Allen. Harold M. Agnew states that, depending on world events, the U.S. will fluctuate between building up arms and decreasing arms. Walter Goldstein argues that the "semblance of stability" between the U.S. and the Soviet Union will be upset when other countries with less stable governments obtain nuclear weapons and that a non-proliferation treaty is necessary. James L. Tuck states that he is more concerned about developing nuclear energy than creating nuclear weapons. Agnew and Tuck have a discussion about the feasibility of complete disarmament and the future of nuclear technology. Agnew and Goldstein have a discussion about other governments obtaining nuclear weapons.

description#1: Moderated by Kenneth R. Hammond. Marvin Kalkstein discusses abandoning the arms race and reducing our level of weaponry. Global and US methods for reduction are explained. Harold Agnew challenges Kalkstein and proposes viewing armaments in terms of new defensive and offensive systems. Joseph Angel describes the hypertrophic and hypotrophic perspectives on arms control. He suggests an arms control solution would be the creation of a supreme organization that could determine the necessity of arms to different countries. Saul Padavar explores the psychology of violence that propels countries to fight each other.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Ulrich Goldsmith. Toby Eady believes that people who criticize art should be able to analyze the entire process of making art, not just final result. Jim Burnes describes the process of creating his work of art: a man driving through a wall of televisions in a convertible. Roger Ebert discusses Chris Burden and his works and asks the other panelists to report this as if they were journalists. He continues and describes what the media did when reporting on one of Burden's works called Doomed. The panelists discuss the process of making sensational news stories.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Cecil Effinger. This is the first of five panels in the World Affairs Conference of Disarmament. Harvey Averch argues that "Western values" have created a "philosophy of force," creating "symmetry" through nuclear stalemate. He proposes alternative strategies hinging on arms control and diplomacy while still maintaining some nuclear weapons as "deterrents." Feigen asserts that the U.S. and the Soviet Union should not have the power to use weapons that will spread radiation across the globe and that a greater number of nuclear weapons increase the chances of "accidental war." He also argues for diplomacy and a world government like the UN. Averch returns to talk about systems analysis, emphasizing the importance of inspection in maintaining arms control.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Avoiding War in the Third Century- Is There an American Role
description#1: Moderated by Harry Carlson. Robert Pickus begins talking about how he doesn't expect the government to lead towards a world without war. Pickus is more concerned on what people/society has to say. He states that society plays a crucial role in America's progress to a world without war. In order to have a world without war, Pickus suggests that one must know the minimal conditions Â– disarmament, law, sense of community, and response Â– essential to that role. He ends by stating the most important task in the third century, which is to help establish a world community that can resolve its problems without mass arms.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speaker urges the importance of understanding what our system requires, rather than using substances to remedy a feeling or pain without knowledge of the substance. The panel gives examples of various types of psychoactive drugs and their psychological effects. Moreover, they discuss how one is able to function in society with or without taking such substances. The causes and effects, as well as the cure, if any, for those who take these addictive substances are discussed and considered by the panel.

description#1: @0:22 Paul V. Thompson introduces speakers @2:48 Fuller talks @10:25 Fuller ends @10:41 Seldes talks @15:24 Seldes ends @15:34 Butcher talks @20:50 Butcher ends @20:57 Rudich talks @33:03 Rudich ends @33:20 Panel interaction @38:13 Audience Questions @1:0
description#2: Buckminster Fuller states that "good" and "bad" are not useful words for mankind. He talks about dividing the world into two parts and what man tends to think about as bad taste using the technique of reduction to absurdity. Gilbert Seldes makes the point that all methods by which taste is changed are themselves changed and this rate of change is accelerating. Charles Butcher posits a strong intuitive feeling that there is something to the meaning of taste, even though there is danger in defining any specific thing as being in good taste. The ability to distinguish "good" from "bad" taste comes from effort -- what works for you. Norman Rudich states that taste is on of the most individual, untranslatable, and mercurial concepts to talk about. Humanizing one's surrounding leads to good taste. Clutter equals bad taste. The question session is poignant and funny. Chairman Paul V. Thompson presiding.

title#1: Bernhard Goetz: Trial by the Press
description#1: Moderated by Salvador Rodriguez del Pino. The panel discusses Bernhard Goetz, who shot four young black men attempting to mug him on the subway in New York in 1984. Peter Tauber argues that illegally carrying weapons in public is a threat to public safety. Margot Adler places the issue in the broader context of safety in New York City at the time, and argues that the city is not as dangerous as most people think. Molly Ivins extends Adler's point to argue that irrational fear is the source of the problem. During the question and answer session, the panelists discuss the media's role in perpetuating New York's dangerous image.

description#1: Moderated by Norwood Robb. Andy Ihnatko discusses Microsoft's failures in programming, gives a personal anecdote about the incompatibility of Microsoft software with other operating systems, and displays a machine that he can control with his Mac. Roger Ebert describes why Microsoft is a successful company, recalls his initial frustrations with Windows, and examines why Windows dominates the business world. Richard Stallman argues that all computer industries are involved in unscrupulous business practices and mentions the development of free software. Tod Nielsen lists the "Top 10 Lessons" he learned from Bill Gates.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by James G. Allen. Ralph Lapp, the main speaker, describes the effects of nuclear fallout and radiation on an individual's health. Lapp refers to the health effects from the aftermath of Hiroshima and to hypothetical nuclear situations of various levels. Due to time constraint, Harrison Brown very briefly agrees with Lapp. Aaron Novick discusses the negative genetic effects of nuclear radiation. Lapp then speaks again, emphasizing a realistic view on the potential of nuclear disaster. Questions from the audience follow.

description#1: Paulo Lazzareschi talks about the political and economic history of Brazil over the last 18 years. Lazzareschi discusses the political coups and uprisings since 1964, discussing the reforms and character of the varying regimes. He ties this to Brazilian economic development over this time period, and discusses the possible political and economic troubles Brazil could face in the future.

title#1: C60 Buckmisterfullerenes: the celestial sphere that fell to earth
description#1: Moderated by Joseph H. Romig. Harold Kroto discusses the history of molecules and chemistry. He explains the structure of molecules and revolutions in how people view them. Kroto shares the specific techniques involved in discovering the Buckeyball molecule and the exploration of its structure. Kroto details his struggles with studying the molecule and how it came to be named the Buckeyball.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Can Big Business Save the Environment?
description#1: Moderated by Phil Deloria. The panel discusses the way businesses impact the environment, and how the public can influence big business. Mary Barley argues that consumers must encourage businesses to make environmentally conscious choices. Robert Repetto argues that citizens are more politically responsive than big business. Molly Ivins disagrees, arguing that businesses have much more money and power than private citizens. The panelists discuss subsidies, legal action, and money in politics. Audience questions cover environmental regulations, consumer choice, socioeconomic class, and the property rights movement.

He starts by talking about rulers throughout history; 06:30 Lasky talks about the term â€œsocial-anthropophagyâ€ or the eating of man-by-man. He continues to relate the term to capitalism. He also talks about his experience as a lawyer and the way our courts are made to work against the people; 08:19 Lasky states that it was once a traditional concept of law that litigation was to be discouraged; 09:17 Lasky refers to a leading federal judge, Charles Edward Wyzanski Jr.; 12:19 Lasky talks about how the court system has turned into a judicial juggernaut working with any claim no matter how small or large and how anything can now be a class action lawsuit; 13:24 Lasky talks about the conduct of the legislative body and Congress; 14:30 Lasky talks about the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. He continues to talk about the jury system in the United States; 21:59 Lasky talks about suits for damage and antitrust laws. He relates the laws back to the workings of a jury; 25:47 Lasky talks about judicial opinions and unanimous consent, or according to Lasky, â€œunanimous dissentâ€; 26:30 Lasky talks about a case involving General Foods; 28:17 Lasky talks about the Antitrust Improvement Act of 1976; 29:00 Lasky talks about the history of the antitrust laws and brings up â€œsocial-anthropophagyâ€ again. He uses examples of cases regarding discrimination in the workplace; 45:45 Lasky talks about the emotional force of consumerism in the court system; 49:59 Lasky finishes his discussion and takes questions from the audience; 50:20 First audience member asks Lasky how he would remedy the problem using either the press, courts, or congress; 53:05 Next audience member asks a question [catalogerâ€™s note: question too quiet to understand]. Lasky talks about white collar crime; 56:45 Audience member asks a question [catalogerâ€™s note: question too quiet to understand]. Lasky responds by asking the audience to consider the â€œparabolic mirrorâ€ of the mean and nice leader talked about at the beginning of the discussion. description#1: Samuel Shapiro compares Fidel Castro and the Cuban revolution with the abolitionist John Brown in the United States. J.P. Morray speaks to charges against Castro: cruelty, power hunger, long-windedness, treacherousness, deceit. I.F. Stone states that Cuba is the only country to emerge out of anti-colonialism after World War II which went Communist. He says that we made Cuba completely dependent on Moscow, and that Castro is fundamentally an independent person in contrast to the moribund Soviet bureaucracy. John Culver critically remarks on passages in J.P. Morray's book, and also on an article by Samuel Shapiro on which his talk was based. Panel chair Rita Weiss presiding.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: A panel of speakers discuss the varieties and methods of providing foreign aid, and talk about the methods of getting the best results. They discuss the changes in providing aid that have occurred in the last few decades, and debate whether the results have been beneficial. Panelists discuss various problems, such as aid being stilted in local bureaucracies, misunderstanding of the skill-sets and knowledge of indigenous people, and the conflicting interests of aid providing countries.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: China After Mao-Death of a Resolution
description#1: Speaker, professor Ralph Buultjens(New School) talks about the influence of Mao Zedong and his political philosophy in shaping China during the 20th century. He argues that Mao was a historically unique figure in history for his depth of influence in decisions that shaped the current Chinese state. Buultgens argues that with the death of Mao, the Chinese state is undergoing further enormous changes, such as rapid modernization that will have a global impact.

description#1: Moderated by Ulrich K. Goldsmith; 00:00 Goldsmith explains that John Walker and Edwin Diamond were unable to attend the discussion; 00:42 Audio cuts out; 00:51 Doris Havice begins her discussion about being at a predominantly Black college; 02:45 Havice answers a question about the Black college which is â€œwhy havenâ€™t we had a riot here?â€ Havice states she has a number of answers. She talks about studentsâ€™ experiences with Martin Luther King Jr. and former riots they had been in; 07:10 Havice explains why riots occur and mentions that riots are not the only form of violence by a group of people. Havice continues to say that it is better to act than to brood and is worried about the brooding happening in Birmingham, Alabama; 08:25 Havice shares a story about a memorial for Martin Luther King Jr. in Birmingham; 09:53 Havice talks about generalizations of riots in cities versus college riots; 12:30 Havice ends her speech and Goldsmith introduces [Dr. Kahn?]; 13:04 Kahn begins his discussion about a series of personal statements and incidents that had occurred after the death of Martin Luther King Jr. Kahn expresses that his kids are Black and Jewish and his family lives in a predominantly white neighborhood where parents do not allow their kids to play with Kahnâ€™s kids; 16:32 Kahn and his wife wonder if an interracial marriage can survive at that time. He also talks about police response to riots; 24:57 Kahn talks about the media and white presentation of riots so that white people can maintain control. Kahn also suggests the meaning of a riot be renamed and described differently; 33:00 Kahn wonders how we begin to rebuild society and urge integration; 35:00 Kahn talks about self-organization and government programs; 37:50 Goldsmith asks the audience for questions; 38:27 Audience member asks for Haviceâ€™s opinion about Mayor Daleyâ€™s decision to â€œshoot â€˜em deadâ€; 39:48 Audience member asks Kahn who in government makes the calls to break relationships with Black groups and poverty programs; 44:35 Audience member follows up with Kahnâ€™s response and asks if the president has anything to do with the break in relationships with Black groups and programs; 45:38 Goldsmith pauses the discussion to allow for those who need to leave; 46:21 Audio cuts to audience memberâ€™s question. Audience member asks why there are less riots in Birmingham, Alabama. Havice responds by saying the younger population is tired and afraid of the violence; 48:52 Audience members asks Havice what she thinks about the difference in Black culture from different places; 49:27 Same audience member follows up and says she thinks there are a lot of differences from different states, such as Austin, Texas. Havice admits that she does not have an answer because the audience memberâ€™s response comes from a white perspective; 54:00 Audience member asks a question about people throwing people out of the Black community and how will it impact the Black movement. Kahn responds by reflecting on failed employment programs; 01:00:31 Audience member asks about Chicagoâ€™s rumor control; 01:05:55 Audience member asks if there is welfare colonialism in Washington D.C.; 01:06:51 Audience member asks where the money goes in relation to the Watts riots in 1965; 01:11:54 Audience member asks about orders implemented from the Mayor of Chicago; 01:17:13 Audience member states that her feeling from the speakers is that it is alright to riot, but the audience member asks if it really is alright to riot. Kahn also responds; 01:21:54 Same audience member disagrees with Kahnâ€™s response and Kahn attempts to clarify; 01:26:50 Audience member asks a question about education and providing opportunities for Black people. identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Cold War and the Drift to the Garrison State
description#1: Moderated by Eugene Wilson, Vice President of the University. The speaker, New York journalist Norman Thomas, argues the pros of the Socialist party in a culture and society torn by opposing political perspectives. Speaker highlights issues surrounding the bipartisan system, later comparing and contrasting the Socialist party against the Democratic and Republican parties. Noting the downfalls of a two party system, Speaker discusses the need for a 3rd party to create a balance between polarizing perspectives. Speaker concludes by discussing the benefits of a socialized culture and government as opposed to one which has been imbued by political and fiscal ideologies.

description#1: Calvin Dietrich explains why a nation-state is infeasible and lists some indirect benefits of the Cold War. James Avery Joyce states that the mass media must become more objective and that the Cold War cannot be solved with military action. J. Richard Goldstein argues that communications between nations must be improved and that the Cold War stemmed from competition between the U.S. and Russia. J. P. Morray believes that the Cold War began as a problem within the two nations. Fred Warner Neal discusses the Soviet position on the Cold War and the misunderstandings between the two nations.

description#1: Moderated by Dennis Van Gerven. This panel discusses corruption in college athletics, particularly the practice of paying athletic recruits and passing illiterate athletes. Molly Ivins recounts scandals within Texas college athletics, the role of authorities in aiding the corruption of the system, and argues against paying college athletes. Robert Casper Brictson explores discrepancies in colleges regarding how they approach the athletic budget and lower academic standards for college athletes. Shepherd Brooks introduces the â€˜Plantation Systemâ€™ in Georgia; illiterate athletes are allowed to graduate college but are left with no life skills and unable to survive in the workforce. George Armelagos discusses the emergence of big business athletics and maintains that the new focus on money and corruption has ruined the spirit of the game. Clay Spontaine shares his own experience as a high school and college football player, and emphasizes the danger of the infantile pageantry that is present in many aspects of American society. Audience questions cover drugs, race, capitalism, and physical education.

description#1: Moderated by Mark Constancio. The panel discusses the adversarial relationship between the legislative and executive branches in the United States. Bruce Sumner contextualizes the Social Security debate in Congress by explaining congressional budgets. Harriet Barlow argues that neither the executive branch nor the legislative branch is serving the American people effectively. Douglas Bennet attributes this failure to a lack of direction. Molly Ivins compares Ronald Reagan and George Bush to illustrate how American presidents work with the legislative branch and hurt the American people. Audience questions focus on campaign finance reform and general elections.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speakers here discuss what it means to be a conscientiousness objector in regards to war. The first speaker defines it as one who refuses to be in allegiance with military service. However this person can and often will find an alternative civilian manner in which to make up for this refusal of participation in the service. The reasons for refusal could be due to religious training or beliefs, which are strong enough to place a sense of responsibility upon the person to not enter the armed forces. The choice deals with what the majority believes on war versus moral imperatives.

description#1: Moderated by Omer C. Stewart. J.P. Morray outlines the history of containment. Calvin Dietrich argues for containment and refutes the basic principles of communism. Joseph W. Angell Jr. gives an alternative account of the history of containment and explores the consequences of containment. Noel Parrish states that the U.S. government has supported leaders they believed would not "brutalize" their nation's people, but these leaders have often turned against the U.S. Thus, U.S. intervention and containment are necessary.

title#1: Continuity and Discontinuity in Russian and Marxist Thought
description#1: Moderated by Norman Michaels. The speakers discuss the traditions of 20th century Russian history, the Marxist party and the Bolsheviks. The Marxists (led by Lenin) proposed a rational but utopian ideal. In pre-Soviet Russian religion, there was no individual salvation; instead, people could be saved only in a community. Similarly, the Russian revolution can be best viewed through the attitude of the peasants. Eventually, the revolution favored the proletarian struggle and limited the liberty of the peasants. One speaker contends that all governmental measures in Soviet Russia strengthened centralized state power over wide areas, with a focus on national survival.

description#1: Moderated by David Barsamian.The panel discusses press coverage of the Iran-Contra affair. Molly Ivins analyzes the political actors and attempts to explain the media's reaction. Peter Dale Scott argues that the establishment press failed to cover the Latin American drug connection to the Contras. During panel discussion, Adam Hochschild and Molly Ivins agree that journalists learn to avoid controversial topics. Audience questions include media manipulation, libel suits, and conspiracy theories.

description#2: Moderated by John P. Lymberopoulos. The speaker raises environmental awareness to promote a healthier and cleaner environment for all species. She describes societal expectations of corporations since the 1900s and our dependence on industry. She explains environmental regulations, passed to regulate problems and improve environmental quality. Corporations, she claims, are valued for the goods and services they supply; however, in terms of economics, political power, and environmental effects it is our responsibility to monitor corporations. Lastly, she emphasizes that environmental acts are standards for the country and that corporations must meet and preserve these standards.

description#1: Michael Straight speaks about the ideology of communism from the standpoints of history, politics and personal experience. He talks about the birth and death of a faith and its stubborn refusal to die as a result of fear of alienation and isolation. He speaks to the difference between ideology and faith and the literary works that describe this era in history, i.e. the death of a butterfly. Chairman Kaye Howe presiding.

titleSeries#1: Series V: The Mythology of the American Experience
description#1: Moderated by Ronald C. Billingsley. Ray L. Hart begins by talking about why death has been an un-American activity and why it is now becoming an American activity. Edwin Casebeer states how the horror of death is the horror of existing in hell. Casebeer then talks about love and death. Phillip K. Bock tries to relate the subject of the panel with anthropology. Brock explains how the feeling about death in the American society is deeply repressed. Jack Forem states how talking about death is pointless because it is inevitable. Forem ends the panel by telling people to live life as fully as possible.

title#1: Deep Eye, Ear, Nose and Sore Throat
description#1: Moderated by Donald J. Unruh. Roger Ebert talks about how he thinks pornography can be therapy. Inge Schneier Hoffmann states how she has come into terms with certain issues concerning pornography. Hoffman explains that she believes art and pornography are incompatible. Pepper Schwartz talks about the basis of pornography. Schwartz then briefly talks about pornography in women and questions what is considered erotic. Michael Gold talks about how he thinks pornography in New York has gone out of hand.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Did Reagan Win the Cold War?
description#1: Moderated by Bob Greenlee. The panelists discuss the end of the Cold War and its consequences. Kirsten Amundsen credits several other leaders for the end of the Cold War, including Harry Truman. Felix Rodriguez argues that Reagan's policies increased military spending, and led to the fall of the Soviet Union. Molly Ivins points out that the Cold War lasted forty years, and no single world leader deserves full credit. Richard Aregood disputes that increased military spending was beneficial to the United States. During discussion, the panelists define multiple factors that eased the conflict. Audience questions cover Mikhail Gorbachev, other American presidents, and the role of the media.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Jack Crouch. Jacquard H. Rothschild argues that complete disarmament is the only true solution to prevent a "nuclear holocaust" since this is the only way to guarantee that the weapons will never be used. Berndt von Staden believes that disarmament can only happen in small gradual steps and that any steps toward disarmament must maintain the current balance of power. Joseph W. Angell Jr. states that a far more devastating "World War III" could have already occurred had atomic weapons not been developed and used as deterrents.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series I: The United Nations: 25 Years Later
description#1: Moderated by Houston Wearing. Zenon Rossides begins by defining what disarmament is. Rossides states that disarmament is a subject that concerns all countries for the survival of humanity. Then, Reginald Duwarnt starts by saying that the French believe in disarmament. Duwarnt gives an explanation on why the French didn't sign the Non-Proliferation Treaty. George Sherry talks about the development in the disarmament field. Sherry states that all effective progress in the field of disarmament is not disarmament, but the control over weapons/arms to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. Burner Meinhoff concludes by saying that feasible wars are conventional wars, and nuclear weapons should never be used.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#3: Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (1968 June 12)
description#1: Moderated by Edward A. Amstutz. Alan V. Washburn begins speaking about the efforts of disarmament that has been going and are going on, ranging from broadest to narrowest. Washburn briefly talks about the Test Ban Treaty, Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, Multiple Independently Targetable Reentry Vehicle (MIRV), chemical and biological warfare, and arms transfer. He states that there is an inverse correlation between the effectiveness and realism of effort, and the success in the real world. Then, Washburn's colleagues briefly give their opinion about how efforts towards disarmament are negligible.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Albert W. Smith. The United Nations held a special session devoted to disarmament, and Katherine L. Camp discusses the details of that plan. William Epstein talks about how the small powers are the only ones interested in disarmament, and the large powers are not. However, Thomas Karas states that all nations are interested in disarmament and explains his reasoning. Nancy K. Ramsey talks about the distinct difference between arms control and disarmament. Ramsey hopes arms control will lead to disarmament but questions if it will ever happen. David Singer ends the panel by talking about the topics that was discussed earlier by the other panelist in more detail.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Disarmanent Control and the Arms Agency
description#1: Moderated by Floyd Baskette. Roger Fisher begins by stating that arms control is important as long as people recognize what it can and cannot do. Fisher mentions how disarmament is controlled by agreement and adequate inspection. Then, Scott Payne begins talking about the reasons behind inspection and agreement, and the complexity behind disarmament. Payne also states the benefits of disarmament by mentioning some treaties. Norman I. Gelman begins by talking about the politics behind disarmament and the history of failure of disarmament as a policy. Gelman ends by agreeing with Payne saying that the only way to approach disarmament is through a peace approach.

titleSeries#1: Series X: The Job of Sex
description#1: Moderated by Payson D. Sheets; 00:00 Sheets introduces the panelists and the topic of the session; 02:10 Betty Dodson begins her discussion. She starts with a background on her masturbation history. She talks about her first experience at the age of five. She also talks about how bad she felt about masturbation as she got older. Eventually she started sneaking it during her marriage and later got a divorce. She then mentions that she revamped her sex life later in life; 09:04 Dodson tells a story about her mother and how they share their masturbation patterns; 11:08 Dodson talks about how she got into teaching masturbation to women who do not masturbate; 12:12 Sonya Hamlin asks Dodson about her final goal of the book she wrote. Dodson says everyone needs to discover their own bodies; 13:54 Dodson talks about pair bonding and solo relationships; 15:00 Dodson talks about discovering your own sexual response patterns and the attitude of masturbation between men and women; 16:30 Dodson talks about the married women she works with at her workshops and the lack of information women have about their bodies. She continues to say that there should be no restrictions as to how people socialize their sexuality; 18:09 Hamlin asks Dodson about how hard it must have been to look directly at genitalia and how she decided to teach others about that. Dodson states she always thought her genitalia was deformed; 20:50 Hamlin asks how easy it is for women to learn quickly about themselves at the workshop and the impact the information has on women; 22:09 Hamlin states that her movement has caused a lot of men to put themselves down and Dodson tells a story about men coming to her workshop as well. The men also find out they are not as sexually aware; 23:00 Hamlin and Dodson talk about using vibrators. Dodson also talks about a â€œmeditation on self-loveâ€ and designing your own sex trip; 25:20 Hamlin thinks Dodson is narrowing what could be considered a pleasure. Dodson talks about food, painting, people, and other things that could be considered pleasurable; 27:18 Audience member asks Dodson if most women are following male sexual response patterns. Dodson talks about sex roles and rhythm; 28:40 Audience member asks about the training Dodson has done and the quick orgasm. She talks about delaying your orgasm; 31:44 Audience member asks Hamlin and Dodson about how quickly women can orgasm alone but achieving an orgasm with a man takes longer because women are too afraid to speak up. Hamlin canâ€™t believe Dodson is not teaching more men since it sounds like they also need the education; 33:04 Audience member states that one must deal with themselves first before partnering with someone else. Hamlin disagrees and talks about the fall-out of a relationship once they become liberated and masturbation is too soloist. A man in the audience disagrees with Hamlin and mentions men actually do not feel that threatened about women learning more about their bodies; 35:53 Audience member asks what is wrong when one partner becomes liberated while in a pair bond when they were not liberated before; 36:36 Audience member comments about the hostility regarding liberation and master-slave relationships during sex; 38:35 Dodson refers to herself and states she is â€œwalking around with the best lover I knowâ€ and how secure she feels about herself; 39:17 Audience member asks about monogamy; 38:29 Audience member asks about complex sexual responses between men and women. Dodson talks about finding a compatible energy; 41:11 Audience member talks about stereotypes between men and women regarding sex; 42:09 Audience member asks how Dodson critiques Freudâ€™s analysis of masturbation being infantile; 44:18 Audience member asks Dodson whether or not â€œpeople that get stuck on the masturbating level are going to be homosexual and lesbian.â€ Dodson states they can if they want to, people should choose and that masturbation leads to sexual preference; 45:39 Audience member asks about Dodsonâ€™s remark of how becoming more sexually open made more people open to her; 47:13 Hamlin asks Dodson how she foresees the future of family structure and monogamy and children; 49:13 [Sheets] talks about rapid change and then the panel goes outside; 49:42 Recording cuts out and repeats the point Hamlin asked about regarding the family structure.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Marie Fagan. [Molly Ivins was scheduled to participate on this panel, but is not heard on this recording.] Robert Cornet vehemently argues that the media do not promote addiction, and advocates the necessity of learning the power of rhetoric in order to defend oneself against the persuasive powers of media. Thomas Adams agrees with Cornet in that there is no actual causation between media and addiction, and explores why people first start using drugs and subsequent media targeting of race and gender groups. Bruce Sumner ponders the significance of the first amendment and the societal origins of addiction, agreeing with his panelists that the media is merely a reflection of society, and does not instigate addiction.

description#1: Moderated by Robert E. Day. Norman Rudich discusses the merits of entertainment and people's attitudes towards entertainment, patriotism, politics, and indifference. He focuses on the film "Doctor Strangelove" and its critical reception versus that of "My Fair Lady." He gives an in-depth analysis of the characters. Joseph Angel explains "black humor" and gives his criticism of the film. Harold Agnew discusses the military's relevance and parallels to "Strangelove." Donald Wiseman uses poetic language to explicate the film's impact on pop culture and his own life. All speakers analyze the character of Jack D. Ripper in terms of nuclear war.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Don't Despair, America is Still Out There
description#1: Moderated by Richard Byyny. Using wit and satire, Molly Ivins addresses the American political landscape in the early 2000s. She explains her concern over the direction of the country, particularly with money in politics. However, Ivins cites anecdotal evidence from her journalistic career to argue that American people are extraordinarily resilient. She concludes her remarks by encouraging the audience to maintain a sense of humor while fighting for freedom. During the audience question period, Ivins covers topics like campaign finance reform, 21st century media, and the military conflict in Iraq.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Earl W. Phillips. Charles Butcher argues that a government agency should be created to convert weapons facilities into factories for consumer goods and retrain workers for new positions. Paul Jacobs argues that trade unions have no position on disarmament because the government has not outlined a plan for the economic displacement of workers involved in armament. R. Buckminster Fuller discusses the Great Depression. Butcher returns to state that economic displacement really "isn't a problem." Jacobs returns and uses San Francisco as an example of why economic displacement is a serious problem. R. Buckminster Fuller returns and says he believes the GI Bill from the Great Depression will return in the form of fellowships.

description#1: Moderated by Reuben Zubrow. Harvey Averch describes the economics of deterrence and post-attack economics. Rudolph Winnacker discusses how the military can continue its current expenditures without "militarizing our society" and how "peace through strength" can deter future war. Clarence Ayres explains why limited civilian consumption Â– not military spending Â– is the cause of slow economic growth. Richard Miles talks about the effects of nuclear war on Great Britain and whether Great Britain should continue its nuclear weapons program.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Daniel Bradford. The panel discusses the editorial process in print journalism, mostly from the perspective of the writer. Molly Ivins shares an anecdote about unsubstantiated claims of cocaine use by Ann Richards becoming news headlines. Simon Hoggart explains how seemingly trivial rewrites can compromise integrity. John Tierney emphasizes the broad range of editorial oversight he had as a writer. Stuart Schoffman tells stories from his stints as a writer at Time magazine and as a Hollywood screenwriter. Audience questions address objectivity in journalism, the influence of government, tabloids, gender bias, and television news.

subject#1: Eisenhower, Dwight D. (Dwight David), 1890-1969--Political and social views
description#1: Moderated by Earl Young. Andrew Knight summarizes Eisenhower's message, which cautions people about the rise of the military-industrial complex and its ability to obtain more power than it already has. Philip Geyelin goes over military expenditures and lists some of the indirect benefits of developing weapons. Michael S. March states that the government should not try to destroy the military-industrial complex, but control it. (Some portions of this recording are partially indecipherable. These portions are indicated by asterisks on the Technical Details section.)
