title#1: Energy: The U.S. and the Arab World
description#1: Moderated by Russell E. Shain; 00:00 Shain introduces the panelist, John Walter and mentions the other two panelists are sick and not attending the session; 01:14 John Walter begins his discussion. He talks about his experience at the Conference of World Affairs; 03:49 Walter states his topic is about energy and the United States and the Arab world. He continues to talk about the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC). He goes over statistics related to OPEC production; 08:20 Walter talks about the rapid economic development problem and OPEC countries; 10:45 Walter talks about the problem of diversification and asks if a country can build an industrial society on the exportation of one product; 12:30 Walter talks about the problem of inflation from U.S. dollars; 13:47 Walter talks about OPECâ€™s influence in developing countries. He lists examples of developing countries that turned into exporters of oil and inflation; 16:26 Walter talks about OPECâ€™s pricing strategy; 17:59 Walter asks two major questions of OPEC. Can exports of crude oil build an industrial economy? And will OPEC get left holding the oil bag or will there be technological advances?; 18:35 Walter talks about the United Statesâ€™ imports and exports; 20:51 Walter talks about the United Statesâ€™ response to OPEC. He talks about Project Independence; 24:00 Walter talks about the windfall profits tax and deregulation of crude oil and natural gas in the U.S. Walter continues to talk about the response to the deregulation of gas and oil; 29:10 Walter talks about a few other concerns and moves on to where the United States might be going with crude oil; 32:58 Walter talks about the coal industry; 34:15 Walter talks about nuclear energy; 36:08 Walter talks about the technology and future of energy such as solar energy; 38:10 Walter talks about the energy crisis and the use of animal dung from the past. He mentions that the only thing useless about energy is our knowledge of it and continues to talk about our future energy source; 42:00 Walter closes his discussion by stating we might not need OPECâ€™s oil in the future; 42:33 Audience member asks Walter to address the pros and cons to moving towards a more decentralized system and away from a centralized system, like an electrical grid; 45:40 Audience member asks, given the fact that knowledge is often useless why did Walter write off nuclear energy as a possibly solution for the future; 47:02 Audience member asks if the oil companies are ethically or morally responsible for the death of the earth; 49:15 Session concludes.

description#1: Moderated by H. Leedom Lefferts, Jr.. William McPherson begins by talking about a movie, The Exorcist. McPherson explains that the popularity of the movie and novel means something; indicates a reaction against idealism. Christopher Cory talks about how the popularity of the exorcist is an expression of compassion fatigue. Edwin Casebeer then explains the variation of a quote and discusses whether people are pondering the devil as a reality. Casebeer states that people are turning towards a myth to be horrified because of the activity of rationalists.

description#1: Moderated by Thorrel B. Fest. Joseph Fink discusses the possible causes of "accidental thermonuclear war" between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. Irving L. Horowitz contends that the chances of accidental war are very slim. Joseph W. Angell discusses films and novels related to the Cold War and points out that they all assume that the military is "psychotic." John Midgely argues that "discontinuity in the government" in either the U.S. or the Soviet Union can result in accidental war. G. Deane Davis states that accidental war is highly unlikely and that films and novels about the Cold War are "science fiction."

title#1: Fiction is Dead and Awaiting Burial
titleSeries#1: Series XVI: Art, Literature and Drama
description#1: Moderated by Nancy Bush. Roger Ebert states that we need to appreciate novels by all authors, not just ones by "respectable authors," and that fiction is still alive in various art forms, including novels and films. Roger W. Wescott plays devil's advocate and states that fiction is dead because of society's emphasis on science, but believes that fiction (through play) has been a part of mammalian behavior for millennia. Joseph W. Angell Jr. argues that fiction plays three purposes: fiction is a substitute for reality, fiction interprets reality, and exceptional fiction can be a reality. Angell also believes that many new novels lack originality.

description#1: Moderated by Jimmie H. Queen; 00:09 Queen introduces the panel; 03:00 [Daniel Ellsberg] begins his discussion. He starts by talking about the power structure on the micro level versus the national level; 04:10 Ellsberg talks about power and non-system in relation to human services. The services include education, health, welfare, and corrections; 13:00 Ellsberg advocates for two approaches to handling power in a non-system. He first talks about using money and cost effectiveness as a tactic to phase out things like prisons and increase services for other people; 16:13 P Ellsberg goes over the second strategy. He talks about using advocates to help the individual consumer negotiate their way through the system; 21:15 [Michael Ansara] begins his discussion. He talks about historical parallels between the 1950s and 1970s; 22:37 Ansara tells a story from 1965 regarding his experience in Indochina; 26:27 Ansara talks about a primary lesson learned after the Vietnam War. He talks about the long distribution of power placed in the hands of people; 34:00 Ansara states that as long as societies believe they are powerless and must do what they are told it will be impossible for society to build the organizations and change needed to take more control. He talks about an organization called Fair Share; 36:25 Ansara talks about the rise of a new left and new right out of organizations and organizers in society; 44:45 Ansara talks about the type of organizer such as blue collar working class families and poor families. He continues to talk about a legislative hearing the organization Fair Share attended; 49:18 Ansara also tells a story about auto insurance rates rising; 01:00:30 Unidentified person talks about the title of the panel. He continues to talk about the Vietnam War. [catalogerâ€™s note: speaker difficult to understand]; 01:34:38 Recording cuts out; 01:24:49 Recording comes back [catalogerâ€™s note: speaker difficult to understand]; 01:37:01 Audience applauds speaker and session ends. Moderator apologizes because they were unable to hear two of the panelists speak.

description#1: Moderated by Rustem Igor Gamow. James B. Blue starts by stating that there is a lack of diversity in the arts and discusses his involvement with the Rice Media Center and public television to help combat this. He shows video clips from various films: one by a black high school student talking with her blind aunt, another by the Coalition for Barrier Free Living showing people's struggle with mobility, and a final film produced by Blue called Who Killed the Fourth Ward?

description#1: Moderated by Earl Sampson. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how movie actors are perceived as fantasies in the 1930s and 1940s. Ebert states why movie actors give us role models and why movies are the greatest voyeuristic, escapist art form of all time. Leslie Kopit talks about how illusions in movies help people come to a deeper truth and help make certain roles become possible. Richard W. B. Lewis talks about superficial influences from actors. Lewis states that great movies are a clarification of life, then questions why there aren't there more great movies. Inge Schneier Hoffmann talks about heroes and anti-heroes in movies in the last few decades.

description#1: Moderated by Walter G. Simon; 00:00 Simon introduces Dr. Feigen; 00:18 Gerald Mason Feigen begins his discussion. He talks about where the term â€œfinkâ€ came from. He states anyone who broke a strike during a trade union was called a fink; 02:03 Feigen states that in prison a fink is someone who â€œsqueals to the prison guardsâ€ with the hope or implication of getting a reward; 02:48 Feigen tells his story about meeting a pleasant fink or champion fink in Haiti; 04:00 Feigen states a way from not becoming a fink is to rediscover your innocence; 04:27 Peter Michael Mayer begins his discussion. He states that while the term fink is contemporary the type of people who are finks do not change; 05:30 A fink is the type of person that cannot be relied upon and is distrusted. Mayer talks about narcotics in the Jazz scene and how the term fink came about through labor unions and in the Jazz scene and then culture as a whole; 07:40 Mayer talks about how young people use and popularize the term. He also mentions that we are in a fink producing society; 09:30 Michael Michaelis begins his discussion. He jokes that he comes from Washington where it could be considered the capital of fink; 10:40 Michaelis thinks that finks operate from a base of fear, rather than knowledge; 12:00 Ralph Nader begins his discussion by talking about the simplistic definition of the term fink. He says a fink â€œdoes what he can rather than what he shouldâ€; 13:12 Nader thinks the word is not important, but the phenomenon should be described. He talks about the institutional restraints that activate the behavior of a fink. Nader tells a story about General Motors; 18:20 Nader states that an institution can get away with something several times without being impacted or held accountable, but an individual only gets one time to make a mistake; 21:10 Simon calls for comments and questions from the panel before the audience; 21:18 Feigen comments on the panel discussion; 21:55 He mentions that finks are susceptible to temptation and bribery; 25:50 Mayer responds to the panel discussion; He talks about Naderâ€™s concerns that rules are not being followed at the institutional level and worries about the problems of the individual working for the institution; 28:30 Michaelis talks about the interrelatedness of institutions; 29:50 Nader responds by saying he would be interested to see how we can create more viable careers not attached to institutions; 34:15 Feigen talks about Naderâ€™s remarks of the individual; 37:17 Simon asks for questions from the audience; 37:24 Audience member makes a correlation between all the panelistsâ€™ stories and notices that the fink in each story was someone quite successful and wonders why; 38:35 Audience member asks a question about individualism; 42:50 Panelists talk about the university student and the university as a fink institution; 50:05 Michaelis talks about the generalist and other panelists respond about the group and the individual; 52:49 Audience member asks about institutional restraints for faculty at the university and wonders if it is viable to create institutions which allow criticism of itself; 01:03:57 Mayer thinks the panel has given too much faith to the individual and talks about providing more faith at the societal level and the enforcement of the antitrust law; 01:06:10 Simon ends the panel and thanks the panelists.

description#1: Moderated by M. John Loeffler. Christopher T. Cory begins by briefly introducing himself. Then, Bonnie S. Hyra explains her definition of flexi-time and states 7 ways jobs can be divided. Christopher T. Cory talks about restructuring the balance between the demands of work and production. Cory then briefly talks about the satisfactions received from a job. Sonya Hamlin speaks from personal experience and discusses why flexi-time is necessary. Hamlin also explains how flexi-time opens up possibilities. Jane Howard talks about her lifestyle as a free-lance writer.

description#1: Moderated by Walter Orr Roberts; 00:20 Roberts begins the panel by introducing himself and the speaker; 02:45 Carl N. Hodges begins his discussion. He talks about how much he learns when he attends the Conference of World Affairs. He also talks about the language of technology; 08:58 Hodges talks about a previous plenary session about the space program and the aesthetic experience of looking at the earth from the moon. He also talks about the environment of the moon. While looking at the image of earth, Hodges mentions that most of the planet is covered by water which makes up a small percentage of the food market and most of the food is harvest by land; 10:27 Hodges points out that much of the land is not habitable for food and those problems have led to predictions of famine. Hodges believes that is not going to be the case because the main source of food comes from the sun; 11:55 Hodges talks about the problem of having fresh water available on the earth. He also talks about creating a desalting plant for water; 13:20 Hodges talks about a new form of agriculture which involved encapsulating the plant and then using humidity from the sea water to create a tropical environment; 15:30 Hodges mentions a project he worked on using waste water; 16:36 Hodges talks about the shrimp project and how the technology can make a contribution to the natural environment; 25:40 Hodges talks about another project regarding the use of carbon dioxide for increase in plant growth; 26:00 Hodges talks about a project called the Experimental Prototype Community of Tomorrow (Epcot) built by Walt Disney in Florida for people to experiment with technology. He continues to talk about a ride and pavilion about the story of agriculture at Epcot; 29:55 Hodges talks about space colonization and the future of food production; 32:40 Audience member asks how we introduce water into new environments; 33:40 Roberts asks how we will introduce water in space; 34:08 Audience member asks why we need to go to the moon to grow food while there are equally hostile places on earth; 34:59 Audience member asks if these technologies will be able to be used by developing countries and people who are already struggling with food and resources; 37:09 Audience member states they have heard about technology fixing the worldâ€™s problems before so what reassurance can Hodges give to ensure this isnâ€™t a pipe dream. Audience member also asks about the Green Revolution; 40:30 Audience member states that the Green Revolution failed because it required fertilizer; 42:22 Audience member asks a question [catalogerâ€™s note: audience member quiet and question difficult to decipher]. Hodges talks about the jojoba plant and industry; 43:58 Audience member asks how one deals with the salt intake in the soil; 45:47 Roberts thanks Hodges and ends the panel.

description#1: Moderated by Olivia Lopez Carter . The panel discusses race relations in America during the Reagan administration. Molly Ivins argues that conservative domestic policy cuts social services, negatively affecting ethnic minorities. Sam Papich demonstrates how the NCAA discriminates against young Black men in college athletics, relating stories from his time in the FBI prosecuting illegal gambling operations. Barbara Smith traces systematic oppression in America to the history of colonialism in Africa, and examines the anti-apartheid movement in South Africa.The audience question and answer period covers FBI surveillance of Martin Luther King Jr., affirmative action, and the future of South Africa.

title#1: Freedom and the Creative Imagination: The Negro Literary Ferment
description#1: The speaker claims that African American authors have been unable to escape racial stereotyping. However, he highlights a writer who has moved beyond anger and has developed concerns for his or her craft in relation to the larger world of art and ideology. Literature has been a medium through which African Americans can explain racial situations, arriving at a new self perception and self definition in relation to the world. The speaker urges writers to experiment with means of expressions to bring richness and diversity to the field, regardless of race.

description#1: Moderated by Michael Tracey. The panel discusses the problems and societal effects of the contemporary press. Speakers discuss the ways the press is too restrictive in some areas and overreaching in others. Themed around "freedom from the press", specific topics of discussion include the moral obligation of the press, privacy, the burden of consensus in publishing, and the consolidation of media sources and loss of quality local news sources.

title#1: From Nuclear Deterrence to Nuclear Disarmament
description#1: Moderated by Bobbie McCallum; 09:22 McCallum introduces the panel; 11:18 Charles Hauss begins his discussion. He asks the audience if they think we need to disarm. He admits it is a very difficult task; 12:20 Hauss talks about the parallels between deterrence and disarmament; 13:34 Hauss talks about the course he teaches on disarmament and goes on to list three models to get us out of disarmament; 24:00 Samuel Cohen begins his discussion. He believes we are moving towards nuclear disaster; 24:40 Cohen states we have been in this situation for 40 years and looks back in history. He continues to talk about how the problems have increased today; 26:14 Cohen talks about the signing of a nuclear arms control treaty and concludes that the Soviet Union has never believed in deterrence; 28:40 Cohen talks about the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty (ABM); 34:14 Cohen talks about the Soviet Union and the treaties that have been signed. He believes the future remains bleak with the Russians since he has not seen any signs of potential change; 35:30 Cohen tells us what we should do when dealing with disarmament. He thinks we should just get out of the situation and apply the money towards other things; 37:57 Sara Sheldon begins her discussion. She states she agrees and disagrees with some of the things Cohen has said; 39:50 Sheldon talks about the fallacies that nuclear weapons have given rise to; 44:00 Sheldon talks about the Peacekeeper (MX) defense system and perception theory; 52:44 Thomas Powers begins his discussion; 53:10 Powers states we donâ€™t know if deterrence works and then looks at the facts of deterrence; 58:40 Powers talks about the peace movement and its phases; 01:05:05 Powers asks what kind of agreement we can make with the Soviet Union on disarmament issues; 01:06:40 Audience member asks Powers for his opinion on change; 01:10:46 Audience member asks about the Mikhail Gorbachev proposal; 01:15:25 Audience member asks Cohen why he thought the Gorbachev proposal is wrong; 01:24:05 Audience member asks what direction we can take to move forward; 01:26:05 Audience member asks for Cohenâ€™s response to the increasing number of countries developing weapons; 01:31:37 Audience member comments he is astonished to hear the panel say that nuclear disarmament is impossible to achieve; 01:39:00 Panel continues to talk about who is in favor of disarmament and what can we do about it; 01:42:20 Audience member comments that the change has to come about through fear; 01:45:31 Audience member asks the panel to expand on the economy and money spent towards disarmament; 01:48:11 Audience member comments about the panels differing perceptions on deterrence and whether we can keep going this way; 01:51:00 Audience member comments about the economics of disarmament. He also talks about the Korean War; 01:55:52 Audience member asks if there is a political utility to think about deterrence differently; 02:00:16 Recording cuts out.

title#1: Function of Literature in Emergent Nations
description#1: @00:04 host introduces panel and speakers @3:12 Simon begins @10:52 Simon ends / Eady begins @18:10 Eady ends / Bock begins @22:58 Bock ends / Moos begins @33:45 discussion with panel and audience begins @1:09:30 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Robert E. Day. For countries newly emerged from colonialism, the speakers propose that literature can shape the lives of the nation and produce revolutionary change. The speakers speculate that literature may result in the growth of society, when literature relates to the rest of the world. Literary means can educate people about society and the integration of ideas. The speakers contend that we must understand the basic needs of society, rather than fight over politics. One speaker claims that writers in many Southeast Asian nations express the lives of their countries by writing about their people.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The panel of speakers discuss the ideas of Pierre Teilhard de Chardin. Discussion includes whether Teilhard de Chardins ideas have become viable, or if time still needed to gain perspective on them. Discussed are Chardin's thoughts on the goal of human evolution and the cosmos, and whether there will be a greater unification of consciousness. The implications of contemporary issues in technology, and the intersection of science and religion are brought up as issues affecting the way Teilhard's ideas can be thought about.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: This is a panel discussion about the types of generals entrusted to retain order and peace, either mercenaries or aristocrats (in the 18th and 19th century) as at the time, that was the best way to get into the officer corps. It was said, and a commonly held belief, that generals possessed divine guidance and intuition following from hereditary lineage. Professionalism and confidence was necessary while competing with other nations, and compromise was necessary while moving between old and new systems. The speakers end the panel by featuring different military organizations and emphasizing the importance of their work and interaction with students on college campuses.

titleSeries#1: Series XVII: Toys Men Play With
description#1: Moderated by Bruce F. Curtis. Edgard von Schmidt-Pauli discusses generals, the topic of nonproliferation and atomic energy, and the common tone created by military establishments. Jiri Nehnevajsa asks to what extent high military officers influence government policy and determine a country's fate. He also questions the power that generals have in ordering weapons and by extension war. Russell Baker focuses on the toys of war, including both the weapons and the gadgets used in combat. He discusses the necessity of eventual disarmament and the need to control the power of generals.

titleSeries#1: Series VII: The District of Columbia
description#1: Moderated by Gayle A. Waldrop; 00:00 Waldrop tells the audience that if they want to learn more about government by publicity then read the book "The Fourth Branch of Government" written by Douglass Cater. Waldrop continues by introducing the panel. 03:33 Douglass Cater begins his discussion about a reporterâ€™s role in Washington and the book he wrote, "The Fourth Branch of Government." 08:11 Cater continues to talk about how the image of politicians are impacted by reporters and how publicity has a reactive influence on policy and people; 09:50 Cater talks about his experience traveling the world, most notably London, [Beijing?], Delhi and Moscow to compare the relationship between government and the press; 14:32 Cater talks about the publicity competition in the executive branch to compete for a place in the public eye to get funding; 17:30 Cater talks about the recent development of the presidential press conference to sustain a unified image before the people and for his programs, as well as the investigative committee of Congress; 23:50 [Waldrop] thanks Cater for his discussion and introduces George Lodge; 24:30 Lodge talks about concerning news leaks to the press, especially regarding information about the military; 27:17 [George Ghesquiere] starts by thanking Cater for his work. He continues to talk about the role of the press in Washington and why it is important to consider the power and influence of news media in the United States; 38:30 Waldrop introduces Yarmonlinsky to start his speech; 39:25 Yarmonlinsky talks about â€œthe problem with noise or staticâ€ regarding the news; 44:35 [Martin Landau] covers three topics: the notion of public opinion, the role of the government, and the role of the press with respect to government; 53:35 Waldrop thanks the members of the panel and asks Cater if he would like to respond to the panel; Cater talks about George Lodgeâ€™s comment and mentions a time about troop reductions in Europe; 59:49 Cater says he does not agree with Landauâ€™s discussion that Congress is being transformed into a consenting agency and Landau responds with a follow up discussion; 01:04:45 Recording is cut-off at the end.

description#1: Moderated by Mark Constancio; 00:13 Constancio starts the session and explains how the program will function. He continues to introduce the panel; 02:00 Dr. Love starts the discussion. Love states she thought of the topic for the conversation because she grew up Catholic. Dr. Love talks about the Catholic Church in the 1950â€™s and what it was like growing up Catholic. She states the strict rules and diet were scary for a child. 10:00 Dr. Love talks about the politics of the Catholic Church and how bad it deals with women, birth control, and homosexuality. She continues to say it is very Medieval and itâ€™s getting worse; 15:08 Roger Ebert begins his discussion. He also reflects on his childhood and how similar it was to Dr. Loveâ€™s. Ebert continues to say the American Catholic Church was a very strange church around the 1950â€™s. He says it was very patriotic; 20:29 Ebert talks about rigid rules of the Catholic Church versus comedy and how the rules change; 32:00 Ebert talks about issues such as abortion and the heritage of his Catholic upbringing impacting his moral decisions; 33:30 BlasÃ© Bonpane begins his discussion. He appreciates the previous remarks from the panelists. subject#3: Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund
description#1: Moderated by Ricardo Moya. The speakers discuss the richness of the Chicano culture -- its language, traditions, and people. Speeches highlight Chicano attempts to participate in government, to improve education and equal opportunities for young adults, and to attain appointments to judicial positions. The main speaker, Calleros, claims that the term 'harvest of shame' evokes the hard work and inequality Chicanos have endured: changes in language, the Mexican territories lost to the U.S. in 1848, and other injustices inflicted upon Chicanos.

description#2: Moderated by Robert B. Jacobs. Mulford Q. Sibley discusses the strengths and inadequacies of the United Nations. Grover Rich speaks on the nature of politics to understand how the UN can be more useful. He defines politics and political power as the ability to coerce. Sibley challenges Rich on the topic of coercion. Chawla explains that the U.N has become necessary as a means to diffuse international conflict. Brian Urquhart also believes the U.N is necessary because of its numerous benefits and equalizing role for all countries. Tad Krauze discusses the issue of the UN in terms of the individual and its psychological necessity. Noel Parrish questions the use of force in the United Nations.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Leo Cabell. Amy Edmondson argues that the hatred of learning is a learned process, claiming it is human nature to want to learn. David Finkle discusses the duality of the meaning of the phrase â€˜hatred of learningâ€™, and explores how some people hate both learning and those who have learning. He ponders why there are some who resist learning, and questions the historical background of learning. Molly Ivins argues there are three sources of the hatred of learning: sense of failure, the perception that people use knowledge as an oppressive weapon, and the idea that learning results in abandonment of former identity. Michael Stoff claims learning is an ongoing process and concurs with Edmondsonâ€™s belief that it is human nature to learn. He explores American societyâ€™s treatment of teachers and the possible reasons for failing teachers.

title#1: Health Care Delivery Systems: Market or Government Control
description#1: Moderated by Carla King. The panel discusses health care in America. Terry McNally examines the concept of holistic health maintenance, and how it relates to potential health care alternatives. Michael Franc compares different free market options and makes the case for consumer choice. Ruth Oratz argues that American health care is fractured and provides different levels of service to different people in an arbitrary way. Molly Ivins focuses on the costs incurred by consumers and hospitals, arguing that a single-payer system would be most effective at reducing these costs. The audience question and answer period covers administrative costs in health care, alternative medicine, and political will.

description#1: Moderated by Robert J. Hefling. Christopher J. Makins begins by stating some policy problems governments and people face in situations where disarmament is not preceded very satisfactorily. Makins briefly talks about how regional arms control regiments would create stable balance between countries that are in political conflict. Patrick M. Morgan discusses the general notion of deterrence, and the flaws/weaknesses in that concept. Morgan also mentions the key central elements of deterrence. Alexander S. Yerekovsky ends the panel by stating that the Soviet government has a policy in the area of disarmament and limitation of arms in order to prevent a nuclear war.

title#1: Higman: A Collection and the Birth of the Conference
description#1: The panel starts with a video of audio clips from various panels. Tom Adams recalls his experiences with Higman and the process of writing Higman: A Collection. Roger Ebert describes his reaction when he learned he would be writing the introduction to the book, discusses his memories of Higman, and introduces "witnesses" (university professors from different departments) who have been present for the majority of the 50 years of the CWA: David Hawkins, James Deugan, Adam Larbolinski, and Ken Hammond. Ebert, Leslie Green, and Betty Brandenburg discuss a variety of topics. Higman family members give their thoughts on the CWA.

title#1: Hollywood in the Living Room: The VCR Revolution
description#1: Moderated by Paul Shankman. Roger Ebert begins by showing a clip of Beyond the Valley of the Dolls and then lists the differences between seeing a movie in a theater and watching it on VCR. Michael Stoff discusses some of the pros and cons of using a VCR to play movies for his children, making home videos, and how the VCR has revolutionized viewing pornography. Stoff concludes by analyzing VCR from a historical viewpoint. Lynn Minton discusses the movie-viewing experience, how the VCR has come to replace aspects of it, and teenagers in relation to the movies.

description#1: Moderated by Donald Weatherley; 1:00 Weatherly talks about homosexuality; 04:30 Richard Green begins the discussion; 05:10 Green mentions that the main issue that will be addressed during the panel is revolved around the medical model and behavioral model; Green talks about how homosexuality was defined as a psychopathic disorder then changed to a sociopathic disorder. He continues to say that the medical model still continues to define homosexuality as a disorder and therefore considered unhealthy under the model; 08:50 Green quotes from the book â€œThe Gay World: Male Homosexuality and the Social Creation of Evilâ€ by Martin Hoffman. He continues to talk about the biological aspect of homosexuality; 13:20 Green talks about the psychological considerations of homosexuality; 15:00 Green quotes Alfred Ernest Jones and his psychoanalytic model; 19:51 Green ends his discussion on a philosophic note regarding the survival of the human race; 20:20 Jack Baker begins his response to Greenâ€™s theories. Baker states that many of the models and theories presented come from white, middle class clinicians who are taking a bias sample and act like they represent the homosexual population; 23:38 Baker takes on a philosophical standpoint regarding homosexuality; 24:15 William Simon begins his discussion. He talks about Sigmund Freud and the behavioral aspects of people. Simon continues his discussion by stating the disease model needs to change; 28:30 Simon finishes his discussion about the sociological position and the fact that no parent raises their child to be homosexual and how do we ease the transition during the â€œcrisis of coming outâ€; 31:58 Unidentified panelist disagrees with one point from Simon and Simon responds about the alienation of the human and sexual experience; 33:57 Weatherley announces a new discussion happening; 34:23 Diane Settlage begins her discussion about female homosexuality and the fact that only white, male homosexuals are written about. Settlage states women are often omitted or neglected from the conversation of homosexuality; 36:29 Settlage mentions that, in some ways, there are advantages for gay women to be accepted in society after being neglected. She continues to say most women generally tolerate homosexuality and the cultural sexual variations put in place by men makes the image of two women together more acceptable; 38:35 Settlage mentions that there are less women that identify as exclusively homosexual because of the social conditions of marriage; 42:42 Weatherley asks the audience if anyone needs to leave for class and they take a break; 44:10 Audio cuts to unidentified panelist talking about Freud; 45:02 Same unidentified panelist talks about the question of bisexuality; 47:10 Audience member asks about the hormone biological studies that come up in the press; 53:36 Audience member asks what methods have been used to treat homosexuals, such as shock therapy; 59:55 Audience member asks if assigning homosexuality as a disease is a way for a society to mitigate punishment or legal control of people; 01:01:50 Audience member asks if the panelists know what the cure rate is of people who identify as gay. First unidentified panelist states that the term â€œcure rateâ€ is wrong and continues with his discussion; 01:05:20 Audience member makes a joke [catalogerâ€™s note: statement too difficult to decipher]. Panelists follow up with a discussion related to the joke; 01:06:06 Audience member asks about sorting out income taxes related to marriage; 01:08:25 Audience member asks a panelist if they are going to challenge so that he can take the bar exam; 01:09:22 Audience member asks about courtship between male homosexuals; 01:13:30 Audience member asks a question [catalogerâ€™s note: statement too difficult to decipher]. The panelists are not quite sure what the title is; 01:24:59 Audience member brings up a point about the womenâ€™s gay liberation movement and Settlage responds; 01:26:40 Audience member asks a question [catalogerâ€™s note: statement too difficult to decipher]. 01:30:15 Audience member asks is the violent type of homosexuality should be in prison; 01:32:45 Last audience member asks their question [catalogerâ€™s note: statement too difficult to decipher]. description#1: Moderated by Barrie M. Hartman. The panel discusses the sometimes uneasy relationships between the American public, political structure, and media. Douglass Cater addresses and challenges the stereotype of the newspaper reporter in Washington. Samuel Chavkin examines the ways that government actions have affected journalism and led to self-censorship. Sidney Hyman argues that people interpret television and print journalism differently, leading to misunderstanding and tension. Molly Ivins wonders how to limit hostility toward the press while respecting the first amendment, also touching on concepts like objectivity and corrections. Audience questions address television journalism, sensationalism, and Rupert Murdoch.

description#1: Moderated by Gordon Gee. Admiral Gene R. LaRocque gives his view on the state of America with relation to national defense. LaRocque argues for a responsible, defensive military, and against a permanent military industry. He also advocates for withdrawing American troops from Europe and Asia. LaRocque ends with a note of optimism, foreseeing the end of the Cold War to be imminent. Questions from the audience follow.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: How to be Cheerful about the American Political System...Anyway
description#1: Moderated by Richard Byyny. Molly Ivins begins her speech about the American political system by discussing President George W. Bush. Her speech continues by touching on money in politics, corruption, and a general sense that the American public's interest in democracy is waning. However, Ivins strikes an optimistic note, citing campaign finance reform legislation. She argues that the American populace is affected by the political system in ways that they do not always recognize, and encourages more people to become politically active. Audience questions cover Texas politics, Ann Richards, and the electoral college.

title#1: How to Make Your Own A-Bomb
description#1: Moderated by Eugene Wilson; 00:02 Wilson introduces the panel; 02:40 Sonya Hamlin and John A. Phillips begin. Hamlin asks Phillips about his biography. He talks about his education in science; 06:33 Hamlin asks Phillips to talk about the project he created while at Princeton University. Phillips talks about the atmosphere as a student at Princeton; 11:30 Phillips states that his report was supposed to be independent work and he wanted to challenge the notion that it would be impossible to build an atomic bomb without a Los Alamos type of team; 12:26 Hamlin asks if Phillips had any problems with his report. Phillips states that his professor would not allow him to do it at first and then finally agreed. 13:35 Hamlin asks where Phillips started with his research. He said he started with books about nuclear reactor theory. He also went to Washington to get declassified documents on the Los Alamos project; 15:26 Hamlin asks if Phillips was ever concerned about how close he really was to designing a nuclear bomb. He states he tried to pick up his paper but it was then classified information; 16:30 Phillips talks about his uncertainty with one configuration in the bomb which was the high explosive aspect; 17:17 Hamlin asks Phillips what he made in relation to the Hiroshima bomb. He mentions it could fit in the trunk of a car and does not look like a typical bomb; 18:33 Hamlin asks what his responsibility is now that he has made it. He realizes that his discovery has made the world aware that any terrorist group could make a bomb; however, he does not share his information about how he made it; 19:39 Hamlin asks if Phillips was disappointed with the governmentâ€™s response to his design; 22:48 Hamlin asks Phillips about the personal cost of creating the bomb. He talks about his roommates. He also talks about how careful he has to be around the press; 25:00 Hamlin asks about the contracts Phillips has been offered such as to act in movies and write books; 29:05 Hamlin asks what he wanted to be before he made the bomb and Phillips mentions that he wanted to be part of the astronaut training program and had applied to be part of the research lab; 31:25 Hamlin asks who Phillipâ€™s strongest influence was in his life. He mentions his parents; 32:55 Audience member asks Hamlin why she thinks Phillips doing the movie would be so bad; 33:35 Audience member asks if Phillips has any concern for his safety. Phillips talks about the call he got from the Pakistani government; 34:19 Audience member asks Phillips what he thinks is an alternative to nuclear fission as an energy source for the future; 35:20 Audience member asks what can we do to prevent armament racing and wars; 35:47 Audience member asks how Phillips will ever know if his bomb actually works. Phillips was told that his bomb was designed very closely to what the military uses but still cannot be sure until it is tested; 37:20 Audience member asks Phillips to talk about his design in more detail. Hamlin asks the audience if they want his formula and Phillips states it would be wrong if he shared his information; 39:04 Audience member asks if Phillipsâ€™ bomb is a dirty bomb; 39:40 Audience member asks Phillips about his intention when designing the bomb; 40:27 Audience member asks how balanced the trigger is for the bomb; 41:10 Audience member asks if it were actually possible to get the physical material to build the bomb and handle it if he were a terrorist; 42:37 Audience member asks what the government can do to stop terrorists from making bombs the way Phillips did; 44:14 Audience member asks how long it took to design the bomb. Phillips states it took him five and a half months; 44:29 Audience member asks if he is in touch with the FBI; 44:45 Audience member asks if any elementary designs are available in books; 45:32 Audience member asks if Phillipsâ€™ bomb could be built in a basement; 46:15 Audience member asks if Phillips was aware about a bomb that exploded in China and the fact that the radioactive material came from Savannah, Georgia; 47:57 Audience member asks Phillips why we are worrying only about plutonium instead of uranium; 49:12 Last audience member asks what quantity of plutonium was used in Phillipsâ€™ bomb; 49:45 Hamlin finishes the panel by focusing on the first reason why Phillips created the bomb. He states that if an average undergraduate student can design a workable atomic device then it is safe to assume that a terrorist group can too. He also mentions that it is important that these organizations do not get their hands on the uranium or plutonium; 50:50 Discussion ends.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Roderic Park. Molly Ivins presents a lecture on the state of the United States. She discusses the 1996 presidential election, summarizing the Republican candidates and their unique strengths and weaknesses. Ivins analyzes corruption in the American political system, and explores the growing dissatisfaction with the two-party system. She challenges cynicism about government, and encourages citizens to consider their own political responsibility. The lecture ranges to the implications of the Information Age on modern society and the role of satire in political commentary. Audience questions cover corporate politics, American media, and the war on drugs.

description#1: Speaker Veronica de Negri discusses the state of democracy and human rights in Chile. She recounts her personal experience as a Chilean exile, and the death of her son at the hands of the Chilean government. She focuses on the struggle of political opponents in Chile, particularly that of women and children. De Negri's brings up the role of torture, murder and intimidation used by the Pinochet government. Her dialogue implores the audience to consider the role of the US government in supporting the Pinochet dictatorship, and in understanding how it underscores human rights violations in Chile

description#1: Moderated by Wesley J. Yordon; 00:02 Yordon introduces the panel; 01:28 Arthur Pearl begins his discussion. He talks about what happens to a county when it loses its sense of humor; 03:08 Pearl talks about the 1930s in America. Although it was a hard time people still found a way to have fun; 04:25 Pearl blames technology and a loss of community for the current loss of humor. He continues to mention that humor really started on college campuses and should be brought back to campus; 06:05 Pearl goes over the difference between comedy and humor. He points out specific people in politics; 07:33 Pearl talks about socialists and the country, Sweden. He mentions that Sweden has a higher suicide rate than the United States; 10:30 Pearl tells a story of an American in Rome and his favorite Italian restaurant; 12:05 Pearl talks about law and order when trying to understand the current administration; 15:00 Pearl talks about the concern of credentials and standards in schools which is another reason why humor is lacking in America; 18:33 Peter Tauber begins his discussion; 20:00 Tauber talks about his connection with panelist, Steve Allen. He also talks about Christopher Reeve; 23:40 Tauber mentions that humor is all about dating, death, and politics and makes a connection to the Conference of World Affairs; 25:16 Tauber talks about the Reagan administration; 27:44 Tauber talks about the fire at the Hilton Hotel in Las Vegas in 1981; 29:35 Tauber talks about his experience writing for Saturday Night Live; 31:45 Tauber makes a joke about the brain and the heart of comedy; 34:13 Steve Allen begins his discussion. He talks about his similar appearance to Christopher Reeve and Superman; 36:50 Allen talks about right-wing comedy and politics. He also mentions that during tough times there is more comedy; 38:40 Allen comments on law and order as well; 39:19 Allen reads the philosophy of humor that he wrote. He also talks about rock music; 44:35 Allen mentions art and Andy Warhol. He continues to read from his philosophy; 50:35 Allen finishes his discussion and audience applauds; 51:07 Recording cuts out.

description#1: Moderated by Marsha Caplan. The panel discusses marriage and gender roles. June Golden presents the absent Molly Ivins' prepared remarks, which focus on public interest in unmarried women. June Golden's own remarks analyze changing roles within marriage. Sayre Seldon argues that greater independence for women has led to fewer marriages, noting that this independence is limited to privileged women. Susan Love shares her personal experience as a lesbian to illustrate the limiting effects of gender expectations. Michael Shaw faults gender stereotypes perpetuated by the media. Audience questions cover maternal and paternal roles, stereotypes, and divorce.

description#1: Moderator not identified. Phil Campbell argues that the U.S. policy of containment translates into the idea that revolutionary, nationalist movements in the third world are synonymous with the Soviet Union, and reactionary policies to these movements has fostered anti-American feelings throughout the world. John Tirman asserts the necessity to leave Nicaragua on its own without outside interference, and maintains that Nicaragua should not be at the forefront of U.S. policy. Reed Brody provides a brief history of the Nicaraguan conflict and Reaganâ€™s role as a contra. Molly Ivins focuses on internal politics, illuminating the debate between those who argue we should never have supported right-wing dictators while others argue we did not support these dictators enough.

title#1: I Claimed Italy and Gave it Back to the Italians
description#1: Moderated by Vine DeLoria; 00:30 Unidentified person introduces the Assistant Director for the Colorado Conference of World Affairs. The assistant director mentions to the audience that there will be a brief special event before the scheduled program. He then introduces Roger Ebert to start the special event; 01:15 Ebert talks about the efforts of the volunteers for the Conference of World Affairs. Ebert nominates Betty Brandenburg as the best volunteer after 35 years of service; 04:46 Ebert hands Betty a plaque for her efforts; 05:18 Betty makes a short speech and thanks those she has worked with; 06:00 Moderator, Vine DeLoria introduces the panelist; 07:25 Audio cuts out; 07:40 Audio slowly comes back; 11:40 Adam Fortunate Eagle begins his discussion. He introduces himself and talks about his background growing up on Indian reservations; 15:00 Adam Fortunate Eagle makes peace with the space he is presenting in; 17:28 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about how the staff of the Conference of World Affairs came to the realization that the United States was coming up to the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbusâ€™ arrival in America and there were no Native American speakers lined up for the 1992 conference; 18:01 Audio cuts out; 18:14 Audio slowly returns. Adam Fortunate Eagle is still talking about his participation in the Conference of World Affairs; 21:46 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about his experience meeting the scholars in the Native American Studies Department at CU Boulder. He continues to talk about the importance of humor and jokes that Native Americans have experienced four â€œB.C.sâ€; 23:15 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about his experience living in the San Francisco Bay Area in the 1960s. He continues to say that he would go to San Franciscoâ€™s Aquatic Park on Columbus Day and watch the â€œreenactment of Columbusâ€™ discovery of America.â€ He explains that white Boy Scouts played the role of Native Americans and he felt embarrassed about it; 25:15 Adam Fortunate Eagle asks the audience if they know what â€œB.I.A.â€ stands for and jokes that it means â€œboss Indians aroundâ€; 25:30 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about his experience as chairman of the United Council and wanted to tell the Italian Federation about the reenactment; 26:09 Audio cuts outs; 26:20 Audio slowly returns. Adam Fortunate Eagle continues to talk about the reenactment; 27:47 Adam Fortunate Eagle continues to talk about the parades in San Francisco on Columbus Day and realizes the Native American community was never invited to participate in the events; 28:35 Audio cuts out; 28:54 Audio slowly returns; 29:15 Adam Fortunate Eagle mentions that the Italians have a really bad sense of history, further mentioning the Italians didnâ€™t think back to the pilgrims arriving in America and the reality of what Columbusâ€™ arrival was actually like. He continues to tell a story about how he spoiled the Italian Americansâ€™ celebration of Columbus; 33:53 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about his invitation to be a delegate at the International Conference on World Futures Research in Rome. He jokes about going back home to â€œItalyâ€ in San Francisco. He continues to talk about how he prepared for the conference; 38:00 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about his travel to Rome and naming the airbus â€œChief Joseph.â€ He continues to talk about his arrival to Italy and jokes about taking Italy on behalf of the Native Americans; 43:00 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about how he was treated with respect by the president and guards in Italy. He also mentions his experience meeting the pope and how he was treated as a celebrity in Italy; 48:10 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about how he became sick right before the International Conference on World Futures Research; 50:16 Adam Fortunate Eagle relates his previous story to what the Spaniards did to the Native Americans if they didnâ€™t accept Christianity; 51:50 Adam Fortunate Eagle jokes with Japanese business men about buying portions of land in Italy since he claimed he owned Italy. He continues to talk about the discovery of Italy once he returned to San Francisco; 56:00 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about a dream he had; 59:10 Adam Fortunate Eagle talks about the Native American Studies Department. He continues to shake a rattle and chants. He tells the audience to follow along; 01:01:57 Adam Fortunate Eagle thanks the audience and the singing stops; 01:02:20 The audience starts with questions; 01:03:00 First audience member asks where Adam Fortunate Eagle got his shoes. He jokes that they are â€œGucci moccasinsâ€; 01:03:31 Second audience member asks Adam Fortunate Eagle to explain the symbolism on his outfit. He continues to talk about the traditional dancers in his family; 01:05:16 Third audience member asks what the four sacred colors are. Adam Fortunate Eagle says the colors are red, white, yellow, and black; 01:05:59 Fourth audience member asks what Adam Fortunate Eagle has planned for this Columbus Day in San Francisco; 01:07:00 Audience member makes a statement [catalogerâ€™s note: audience statement quiet and too difficult to decipher]; 01:07:32 Audience member thanks and jokes with Adam Fortunate Eagle about giving back her homeland; 01:07:38 Next audience member asks Adam Fortunate Eagle to talk about the previous session with the Hopi elder but Adam Fortunate Eagle admits he was not there for that talk; 01:08:24 Audio cuts out; 01:08:35 Audio slowly comes back; 01:09:07 Audience member asks if Adam Fortunate Eagle has mentioned anything about the American Indian Day proposition that would be on the Colorado ballot; 01:09:47 Audience member asks if Adam Fortunate Eagle is going to be discovering any other lands; 01:11:35 Audience member asks a question about a previous session he was in and challenges him to rewrite racist and homophobic jokes; 01:14:34 Audience member asks if Native American humor is a survival mechanism; 01:15:47 Audience member states he is Italian and appreciates Adam Fortunate Eagleâ€™s humor; 01:18:30 Audience applauds and session ends; 01:18:55 Talking continues in the background.

description#1: Moderated by Michael Ehlers; 00:14 Recording starts in the middle of a conversation; 02:20 Marilyn Stasio talks about [Robert Barron] and satanic literature; 05:00 Stasio talks about the entertainment pages in the news and what art is represented; 07:40 Stasio talks about the representation of celebrities and how the news never covers the content of the person but what they are wearing; 08:35 Stasio talks about meeting Rupert Murdoch; 11:17 Stasio finishes her talk and the next panelist, Roger Ebert begins his discussion. The Ebert talks about a story related to Rupert Murdoch; 15:00 Ebert talks about the Chicago Sun-Times and â€œthe windowâ€ after a merge and strike of the paper; 17:30 Ebert talks about how boring the Chicago Tribune was; 20:00 Ebert talks about Murdoch taking over the Sun-Times newspaper and what it was like at the beginning; 28:00 Ebert goes over the headlines on the front pages of newspapers; 30:23 Andrew Neil starts his discussion. He talks about his favorite headlines from the New York Post and New York [Daily] News; 33:00 Neil talks about how the New York Post is losing Murdoch money; 34:15 Neil talks about his experience running The Sunday Times, London. He shows the front page and brags that the paper covers international news very seriously; 38:50 Neil compares his journalistic work environment in England to an American work environment and continues to say how competitive it is in England to make sure his national paper is read while in America there is more of a â€œbig city monopoly environmentâ€; 40:30 Adam Hochschild begins his discussion by stating he is the only panelist that works for a publication not owned by Rupert Murdoch; 41:20 Hochschild talks about the attacks on Rupert Murdoch and the themes that reoccur such as the fact that Murdochâ€™s papers publish a lot of information that is not news, they focus on celebrities, and serious news gets ignored but Hochschild mentions that these attacks have been problems in American newspapers for a long time; 45:30 Hochschild talks about how newspapers have to compete with television which is why American newspapers have topics that are not considered newsworthy; 46:50 Hochschild believes people should approach newspapers with critical skepticism; 49:35 Ehlers invites the audience to stay for questions. He also asks the panel to comment about the correlation between politics and Murdochâ€™s politics reflected in his papers; 50:52 Unidentified panelist [possibly Roger Ebert] starts the discussion on Murdochâ€™s politics by stating he believes Murdoch is more conservative than liberal and his papers reflect that; 51:27 Stasio adds to the discussion about Murdochâ€™s politics and mentions her newspaper was used to elect Ed Koch the current mayor in New York; 53:36 Andrew Neil responds to the question about Murdochâ€™s politics and how The Sunday Times, London differs when talking about politics; 54:17 Unidentified panelist [possibly Adam Hochschild] responds to the question of Murdochâ€™s politics. 54:49 Unidentified person [possibly Roger Ebert] speaks about their concerns with the freedom of the press and politics and mentions the saying â€œthe freedom of the press belongs to the man that owns one.â€ He continues to say that The Tribune will conform their paper to any political majority in any state because they only really care about the bottom line of selling newspapers; 58:10 Stasio talks about the issue of the role of print union and the survival of the newspaper; 01:01:12 Andrew Neil talks about British print unions; 01:05:23 Audience member asks a question about Rupert Murdochâ€™s sports network; 01:08:18 Audience member asks Ebert how The Sun-Times improved; 01:13:28 Audience member mentions that Murdochâ€™s influence in the San Antonio Express made it a terrible paper and the town is so corrupt journalistically; 01:16:24 Stasio responds to the audience memberâ€™s comments; 01:18:18 Audience member talks about Richard Nixon and the Republican National Convention. He also talks about the competition that Neil talked about and Murdochâ€™s politics; 01:19:40 Neil responds to the audience memberâ€™s question. The audience member does not agree with Neilâ€™s response; 01:24:21 Stasio interjects to respond to the same audience member about politics in newspapers; 01:25:39 Unidentified panelist also interjects about the audience memberâ€™s question regarding politics in the newspaper; 01:26:50 New audience member asks a question about the problems with Murdoch and his political power. Ebert responds first and Neil follows up by stating he believes Murdochâ€™s political influence will not be as powerful in television because you can convey more politics in a paper than you can on television; 01:32:46 Hochschild responds to Neilâ€™s comments; 01:35:12 Neil responds to Hochschildâ€™s comments and states he believes there are more democratic journalists than republican journalists. The panelists continue to talk back and forth about the topic; 01:35:49 Unidentified panelist talks about the concentration of ownership; 01:38:30 Stasio talks about how Murdoch cannot sell the New York Post; 01:39:05 Audience member asks a question [catalogerâ€™s note: question difficult to decipher]; 01:43:00 Audience member asks the panel how Murdoch operates and if he is just in it for the money; 01:45:00 Panel ends.

title#1: I Know Persons from Outer Space
description#1: Moderated by Pauline H. Coker; 00:11 Coker introduces the panel; 2:04 Sonya Hamlin begins the discussion by asking the audience if they have read Whitley Strieberâ€™s book titled â€œCommunion: A True Storyâ€; 02:49 Strieber talks about his experience and how the book is a true story; 04:00 Strieber talks about the skepticism of his experience and asks the audience to have an open mind; 05:15 Strieber starts with his first experience by stating he went to a therapist after the event happened because he thought he was totally mad. He starts talking about the night of December 26th, 1985 when he was awakened by a loud rustling noise in his cabin in a remote area. He mentions he saw a figure about three and half feet tall standing in the doorway and other smaller figures running through the doorway; 09:15 Strieber talks about how he was being carried away by the figures that came into the bedroom and into the woods and the snow. He mentions him and his doctor used hypnosis to try to remember details he could not normally remember. 11:25 Strieber talks about the next figure he saw in the woods with a tan suit on. He then talks about how he was rising above the forest and into a room. He then sees a figure that looks like the one depicted on the cover of his book â€œCommunion: A True Story.â€; 12:35 Strieber describes the round room he was now in with the visitor. He talks about how he was trying to wake up and felt as if his mind and body were separate from each other. Once he realizes he is already awake he began to panic; 14:51 Strieber talks about the first words he heard from the figure. In a deep voice the figure stated â€œweâ€™re going to do an operation on your brain.â€ He says he began to scream and an electronic, mechanical female voice asked him â€œwhat can we do to help you stop screaming?â€ He responds by saying â€œYou could let me smell you!â€ because he could not see or use his other senses. A figure held up a hand and it had a mild, dry, cheesy smell or cardboard smell. He also states the figures were gray in color; 20:48 Strieber talks about the procedures the visitors started doing to him. He talks about the operation he had on his brain. He also mentions a rectal probe. 22:35 Strieber talks about how he got out of the round room and made it home. He talks about how he remembers sitting in his living room on his couch, naked, and with a terrible taste in his mouth. When he woke up the next morning, he had a terrible feeling the entire day. He also mentions he had not talked to his wife about it at first. 26:00 Strieber talks about his family ski trip and how he started to feel a sharp pain behind his ear. He continues to say that his wife mentioned it looked like he had a small needle mark on his head. 26:55 Hamlin asks Strieber why he went to the psychiatrist. Strieber explains that he had a few long interviews with the psychiatrist and suggested that hypnosis might help to retrieved some of the missing parts of his memory. Strieber mentions that he believes [Dr. Kline] did not want Strieberâ€™s memories to be real. 32:15 Hamlin asks Strieber if there are unique things discovered from previous experiences and the most current experience Strieber has had. She continues to ask if there is a commonality between all of the experiences; 34:20 Strieber explains this â€œexternal witnessâ€ that seems to be present from every incident; 40:48 Hamlin asks Strieber to try to characterize what the visitors are and asks why they seem to only choose certain people over others. Hamlin expands her question by asking what the visitors seem to be seeking from Strieber and why they come to Strieber and the same people; 43:19 Strieber explains the seven places that the visitors might be coming from such as another planet, on earth and we canâ€™t perceive it, visitors from the future or time travelers, side effect of natural phenomena; 47:00 Hamlin asks Strieber to expand on his experiences compared to other peoplesâ€™ experiences; 49:04 Hamlin asks Strieber if the people who have these experiences gain the ability to turn off television sets, wreck hi-fis and have problems with their cars. Stieber mentions he has problems with the circuitry of his computers; 50:20 Hamlin asks Strieber if he is now a missionary trying to explain his message to everyone. Strieber does not quite admit that he is a missionary but mentions he recently had another experience about two weeks before the panel although he could not talk about it yet; 57:20 Stieber opens the discussion to questions from the audience. The first audience member asks about the meaning of the title of the panel discussion and about how many incidents Strieber has had with visitors; 58:00 Hamlin realizes another talk is about to start and ends the panel.

description#1: Moderated by Bob Watford. Leonard Feather begins by talking about how illiteracy can be defined in different ways. Feather then states different degrees of illiteracy. Claudio Spies talks about other forms of illiteracy such as insufficient reading. Spies discusses the irresponsibility of teachers and how the teaching of English has deteriorated. Roger Ebert states how reading for him is the most artistic pleasure since the written word creates a world in one's mind. Ebert then talks about how there are people who know how to write and read but choose not to. The panelists then discuss the importance in knowing a second language.

description#1: 00:00:05 Russell Shain begins 00:01:12 Shain ends 00:01:22 Toby Eady begins 00:05:19 Eady ends 00:05:23 Edward P. Morgan begins 00:10:49 Morgan ends 00:10:53 Roger Ebert begins 00:12:50 Ebert ends 00:13:01 Max Lerner begins 00:22:22 Lerner ends 00:22:29 Questions from the audience begin 01:32:37 Questions from the audience end 01:33:45 End of tape
description#2: Moderated by Russell Shain. Toby Eady expresses his disdain for producing television nature documentaries and briefly touches on media in Europe. Edward P. Morgan argues that reporting and journalism sometimes use illusions to create sensational news stories. Roger Ebert finds that new filmmakers are great at making exciting films, but unfortunately do not make many films regarding "the human experience." Max Lerner believes that today's media cannot create "mythical heroic figures," and as a result, today's people are less able to identify with heroic figures. Lerner also mentions that television networks and the press have too much control over what is produced.

description#1: Moderated by E. Merle Adams; 00:00 Adams introduces the topic of discussion and the panelists; 02:32 Buckminster Fuller begins his discussion. He mentions he did not choose the topic of the panel, â€œin and outâ€; 03:24 Fuller talks about the political expression of â€œin and outâ€ and the significance of the phrase; 05:00 Fuller talks about his experience nominating a speaker at the faculty club; 10:45 Fuller talks about his understanding of the expression â€œin and outâ€; 11:20 Marya Mannes begins her discussion; 12:00 Mannes begins with art and talks about the art movement Abstract Expressionism and how right now it is â€œinâ€ but it will be â€œoutâ€ soon; 12:50 Mannes changes the topic to houses and windows. She explains that the picture window became â€œinâ€ about ten years ago and is now on its way â€œoutâ€ in American civilization; 13:47 Mannes states marriage and femineity is â€œinâ€; 14:12 Mannes states that gibberish has been â€œinâ€ for a long time; 14:56 Mannes talks about the moral and spiritual values by the government is â€œinâ€ but leadership and authority is â€œoutâ€ right now; 16:00 Malcom Bradbury begins his discussion. He mentions he thought being â€œoutâ€ meant being an outsider; 16:55 Bradbury talks about rich girls and what they wear and how people are defined as upper class and non-upper class in England; 19:57 Bradbury talks about a new upper-middle class in England that set the standards about consumption and culture. He talks about the old cars they drive and the cheap clothing they buy; 24:20 Bradbury talks about the thornproof suit and how â€œinâ€ it was ten years ago. He also talks about pants without pockets; 28:00 Bradbury asks if English sports cars are â€œinâ€ in America. He also asks about the off-white Burberry trend among American women; 30:00 Fuller asks what non-freedom is. Bradbury talks about the social class in England while the social class in America is nonexistent; 31:32 Audience member asks who â€œtheyâ€ are when it comes to trends. The panelists talk about the groups that start trends; 35:23 Mannes uses toy manufacturing as an example to relieve companies of over accumulated stock by turning their product into trends; 36:53 Bradbury talks about the people who start fads and then drop fads once they have been communicated. He continues to talk about the standards related to these trends. Audience member tells Bradbury to be an individual and wear what you want; 39:00 Panelists talk about how trends start on the East or West Coast because that is where most of the advertising is. He uses western clothing as a way to make a statement of what is â€œinâ€ and â€œoutâ€; 41:07 Audience member asks Bradbury a question about communication of trends in England and whether it has a financial impact; 44:23 Bradbury talks about the [Yale writers?] and compares the trend to rock nâ€™ roll popularity; 46:20 Unidentified person asks what defines â€œin and outâ€ between America and England; 50:00 The panelists talk about beards that are â€œinâ€ in the Denver area; 52:40 Audience member asks why the panelists are only talking about menâ€™s clothing instead of womenâ€™s clothing. Mannes mentions that the women in England are slower to catch on to trends than American women; 56:01 Audience member asks about English menâ€™s opinions about English women looking too well dressed or attractive; 57:31 Audience member admits he is still having a hard time understanding what the â€œinâ€ group means; 01:03:27 Recording cuts out.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Laurie Van Horn. The panel discusses the current state of American media in the late 1990s. Michael Elliott traces the positive changes in American media, specifically its integrated approach to international journalism. Molly Ivins disagrees with Elliott and identifies various failures of the media, including irresponsible fact-checking and poor subject selection. Patricia Ellis agrees with Ivins that the media is indefensible, especially as media outlets consolidate. Joseph Mehan points out that journalists have begun criticizing their own profession more fully. David Finkel uses a personal anecdote to illustrate the fallibility of the media. Audience questions cover endowed newspapers, political journalism, and media criticism.

description#1: Moderated by Thomas Bird. Tom DeVries recalls the type of person Allard Lowenstein was: a political activist in the National Student Association who always seemed to know what was going on. Roger Ebert states that Lowenstein was "a marker in [his] life" and discusses his personal encounters with Lowenstein. Ebert also believes that DeVries is a marker in his life and recalls how they met. Paul verbalizes his thoughts and memories about Lowenstein. DeVries returns to discuss Lowenstein's contribution to the Dump Johnson movement.

titleSeries#1: Series III: Ethics and Greed in America
description#1: Moderated by William Scanlon; 00:00 Unidentified panelist talks about reporters and rude anchormen; 00:48 A different unidentified panelist chimes in about reporters and presidents. He continues to say that people always focus on the heat of an issue and not the point of the story or the reporters; 02:06 Unidentified panelist takes a question from the audience. The audience members thanks the panel and admits he thought they were going to have a discussion about ethics in print news media but there doesn't seem to be a representative that writes for print news on the panel; 03:13 The same audience member brings up a discussion about "facts that arenâ€™t true," or alternative facts in the media. He continues to talk about the difference between insignificant facts and significant facts and asks the panel about what significant facts the news media reports, namely the Denver Post; 05:50 Panelist, Molly Ivins responds to the audience memberâ€™s question by stating that certain anchors have â€œcloutâ€ or â€œpowerâ€ which makes the facts more significant; 06:18 Unidentified panelist adds that journalists cover what the dayâ€™s obsessions are and the American public are no longer interested in uncovering the â€œdark conspiracies under the faÃ§ade of democracy.â€ The same speaker continues to mention that people are only interested in stories about wealth, power and celebrity; 07:04 Another unidentified panelist changes the topic to focus on what should be on the front page of a newspaper; 08:07 Audience member asks a question if the White House issues information, or disinformation, to the media and if the media fact checks it; 08:20 Unidentified panelist responds about how complicated it could be check each type of report; 09:10 Different unidentified speaker responds to audience memberâ€™s question stating there are so many events that happen at the White House and most events are recorded and copies are made; 10:50 Unidentified speaker or audience member asks a follow up question; 11:23 Molly Ivins states that the media quotes authority and it is a â€œfatal weakness in this countryâ€ and proving if authority is lying is difficult in objective journalism; 13:00 Unidentified panelist responds by quoting Joseph McCarthy; 13:25 Molly Ivins talks about Ronald Reaganâ€™s claim that people use their food stamps on vodka and how untrue it is; 15:55 Unidentified panelist talks about the characteristics of journalists and their audience; 16:58 Different unidentified speaker mentions that we have come a long way for what is depicted in newspapers in America; Audience member asks a question the panel disagrees with. description#1: Moderated by Paul Levitt. Arthur Kopit begins by talking about an aspect of nostalgia and states two types of nostalgia: definition of the word and assumption of the habits of another era. Kopit then provides a list of things that will probably disappear and be nostalgic for. Richard W. B. Lewis talks about the definition of nostalgia, which he defines as homesickness. Inger Schneier Hoffmann talks about how nostalgia is not just nostalgia for the past, losses, or place, but a longing for a more perfect state. Then a discussion about nostalgia between the panelists begins, followed by questions from the audience.

description#1: Moderated by Walter B. Lovelace. Marcia Millman describes her experiences following various medical professionals in a hospital for several months, focusing mostly on medical mortality review meetings and malpractice. Mary Redick analyzes medical systems "cross-culturally." Roger Ebert discusses a movie about a man's battle with cancer, his personal experience with doctors, and the novel Blood and Money.

title#1: India: Under the Sainthood-A Closer Look at Mahatma Ghandi
description#1: A panel of speakers discuss the legacy of Mahatma Ghandi in India and in the realm of non-violence in the light of a recent film on Ghandi. Speakers review if Ghandi is more successful as a saint or a politician. Debated is role of Ghandi's thought in the history of India, particularly in the separation from the British Empire, and whether his thought still has importance in contemporary Indian society . Analysis is given to what effects events in Ghandi's life had on his thought and leadership.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The participants give an overview of the emergence of the "information society". Participants talk about how the current information society differs from previous societal paradigms such as industrial and agriculturally based societies. The speakers discuss the possible necessary and unavoidable outcomes of the transfer to an information society, such as educational understanding, the effects on jobs, the poor, and those without access. All of the discussion is done in the context of understanding on how changes in content and the information container interacts with the human condition.

description#1: Moderated by Mark Meredith; 01:00 Meredith introduces himself, the topic, and the panel; 08:05 Marvin Leibstone begins his discussion. He talks about his experience at his last presentation; 10:14 Leibstone talks about the definition of terrorism. He mentions that terrorism is a specific type of tactic or operational mode by a group. He also talks about the perception of guerilla warfare groups as freedom fighters rather than terrorists; 13:52 Leibstone talks about what terrorism is not and the level of violence that can occur; 18:10 Leibstone talks about politics before violence. He also talks about military violence and guerilla warfare; 21:23 Audience member asks if Leibstone will be talking about acts of terrorism from a government upon its own people. Leibstone expands on the topic of illegitimate terrorism; 22:15 Leibstone talks about the international terrorist events and groups that have occurred since 1968. Each terrorist organization adheres to a specific belief system. He talks about the Jewish Defense League in the United States as a religious terrorist group. An example of a separatist terrorist organization he provides is the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. Leibstone then provides examples of political groups, that being the IRA Provisionals or the Weathermen; 25:59 Leibstone states that the organizations on the left are usually the â€œMarxist-Leninistâ€ groups and lists some of the names of the groups. He also talks about Maoist oriented groups; 31:17 Leibstone talks about operational strategy and the groups that either operate transnationally, internationally, or are a domestic group; 35:00 Leibstone talks about the role of the media and government regarding terrorist groups; 36:11 Leibstone mentions that terrorism does not always result in war and there are very few cases where a terrorist group actually achieved their long-range political objective; 40:59 Leibstone talks about the groups that did achieve their long-range political goals. He also talks about the use of media as a short-range goal; 44:20 Leibstone talks about the type of acts of terror such as kidnappings, bombings, assaults, incendiary acts, assassinations, and sniping; 47:20 Leibstone talks about the mercenary terrorist in it for the money. He continues to talk about acts of terrorism; 53:25 Leibstone provides an example of an act of terrorism influenced by an international group, that being the Lod Massacre in 1972; 56:00 Brian E. Fisher begins his discussion. He talks about the intelligence side of terrorism; 58:50 Fisher talks about the interaction between intervention services such as the police and FBI. He also talks about the news media in the mix of terrorists and the police; 01:01:37 James D. Henderson begins his discussion. He focuses on contemporary left American history and counterterrorism; 01:03:49 Hans von Ploetz begins his discussion. He agrees with Leibstoneâ€™s definition of terrorism; 01:05:25 Ploetz talks about the similarities and differences of terrorism between countries; 01:07:30 Panel opens to the audience for questions. First audience member asks if the German government has not over reacted to acts of terrorism on public institutions; 01:12:55 Audience member asks if organizations like the IRA and Red Brigades actually support the plights of the Palestinians or they get involved because the groups are similar and want to help each other out; 01:16:27 Audience member asks if there is one identifying purpose of all terrorist groups. Leibstone explains that all terrorist groups are minority organizations that are weak and feel oppressed but believe they are freedom fighters; 01:17:55 Audience member asks about German terrorism and West Germany; 01:25:30 Audience member asks about transnational and international terrorism; 01:26:20 Audience member asks if Leibstone could address the individual personality and how it converges or relates to a terrorist group; 01:33:56 Audience member asks about United States support in South Africa; 01:36:01 Meredith asks the panelists to talk about how they gain their information about terrorist organizations and how they respond to the organizations; 01:49:08 Panel ends and Meredith thanks the panelists.
