title#1: Is Criticism in the Arts Useless?
description#1: Moderated by Sherry Wallace. Gene Lees begins by talking about the subjectivity of criticism. Lees discusses why criticism is not necessary. Nick Brignola talks about whether critics are valid and explains why he believes criticism is necessary. Frederick C. Tillis talks about how consumers of art should develop critical judgment. Tillis then explains why lack of knowledge is the most serious problem of criticism. Roger Ebert talks about how critics are subjective and explains why critics can't be objective. Ebert states that he writes for movie-goers and not for movie-makers.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Betram Morris. Flora Natapoff begins by talking about the subject of nostalgia in terms of pictures. Roger Ebert talks about nostalgic movies and also talks about why nostalgia is a constant motif in advertising. Ebert answers yes and no to the question, is nostalgia debilitating. Peter Michael Mayer talks about nostalgia as an issue in American life. Mayer specifies one area in which nostalgia is always debilitating. Shepherd Brooks talks about the definition of nostalgia. Arthur Kopit explains why nostalgia is not a search for pain, but rather a search for an alternate dream life.

description#1: Moderated by Barry Satlow. Jurek Martin begins by stating that television has a large public service element in it, but is somewhat both a public and private service. Martin talks about television in three different countries Â– Britain, Japan, and United States Â– based on his experiences. Mose Durst discusses religion and media. Durst states how television has been used as an instrument of bigotry rather than public service and enlightenment. Roger Ebert talks about how television as a medium is an inefficient way to communicate political, religious, and philosophical ideas because television has abandoned words for images. Both Durst and Ebert believe that television is not a public service.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Is the Cold War Really Over and What Should We Do About it?
description#1: Former admiral and military analyst Gene La Rocque discusses the role of defense and foreign policy after the fall of the Soviet Union. La Rocque proposes that there needs to be a radical restructuring of the defense apparatus with the demise of the Soviet Union. He argues that there are a number of important issues that should generate more focus in the post-cold war world. He argues that this will be difficult as the end of the Cold War makes many people useless, and that a great deal of profit and influence are tied up with the growth of the defense department for things that are obsolescent.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Hilton M Power. In the last session of the conference, Rudolph Winnacker discusses the impracticability of thermonuclear war between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. In addition, Winnacker argues for "peace through strength" by maintaining nuclear weapons in order to deter future war. The majority of time is spent answering questions from the audience regarding the possibility of other countries obtaining nuclear weapons, potential changes in warfare, the likelihood of disarmament, the future of the Soviet Union, U.S. foreign policy with the Soviet Union, and the effects of a nuclear attack.

description#1: Moderated by Frank Smucker. Mary-Ellis Bunim recalls the ventures of her company, Bunim/Murray Productions, with particular emphasis on the creation of The Real World. Ebert discusses the movie Real Life, the amount of hours a typical American spends watching TV, people on The Real World, and the effects of watching TV.

title#1: Israel's Future in the Middle East
description#1: Moderated by John R. Little; 00:00 Little introduces the speaker; 03:37 Major General Yitzhak Rabin begins his discussion; 04:20 Rabin introduces his topic about the problems facing the Middle East and the Arab-Israeli conflict. He admits that he is going to present the Israeli viewpoint; 06:40 Rabin tells a story about a Czechoslovakian and an Israeli and prepares to describe the situation in the Middle East. 08:04 Rabin goes over one question being â€œwould it be possible to achieve real peace in the Middle East?â€; 11:47 Rabin talks about the major obstacle to achieving peace in the Middle East as he states that the Arab countries refuse to recognize that Israel exists. He wonders how the Arab countries could hate so much after existing for such a long time and against a country that â€œdoesnâ€™t existâ€; 13:00 Rabin believes that powerful countries do not have the right to dictate how smaller countries should live; 14:00 Rabin continues to define what the word â€œpeaceâ€ means and how vague it seems to him in English; 16:50 Rabin comments that he does not believe peace can be achieved without the countries talking to each other. He continues to talk about a peace plan that was submitted to the National Press Club by the King of Jordan. Rabin believes the peace plan does not talk about peace at all because Israel is excluded; 28:00 Rabin explains that only Israel is responsible for preventing another genocide in the Middle East. He continues to say that Israel has to be capable of fighting their own wars and cannot rely on anyone; 30:00 Rabin goes over the legal rights of Israel; 35:00 Rabin talks about the Arab countriesâ€™ position now and mentions that the Arab leaders met in Khartoum, Sudan to decide the policies after the Six-Day War. Rabin expresses that the leaders were very negative and cut off all ties with Israel;41:50 Rabin talks about the refugee problem that has occurred after the wars and separation of India; 48:05 Rabin goes into an example of refugees from the Gaza Strip; 01:06:20 Little thanks Rabin and takes a few questions from the audience; 01:07:15 Audience member asks if it was advisable to attack the airport of Beirut; 01:14:00 Audience member asks what the Israel position is in regards to the Christian pilgrimage; 01:17:00 Audience member asks what the economic situation is and military service requirement is of the Arab citizens of Israel who leave certain territories; 01:20:57 Audience member wants to know what the direct economic aid is to Israel from the United States; 01:22:11 Little ends the discussion.

description#1: Chaired by Horace B. Holmes. [Molly Ivins and Myra MacPherson were scheduled to participate, but neither is heard on this recording.] Josiah Thompson displays and analyzes the Abraham Zapruder film of Kennedyâ€™s assassination. He invites the audience to determine the exact events of the day as the footage is reviewed frame by frame. He provides background information as well as results of the Warren Commission and the botched autopsy. In the Q&A session he speculates on possible conspiracies and reflects on the search for truth and justice.

Holmes begins -- 00:01:35 Holmes ends -- 00:01:44 Josiah Thompson discusses the significance and symbolism of the assassination -- 00:04:47 Begins showing films of the Kennedy motorcade and assassination -- 00:09:20 Changes the film reel and discusses impact of the Kennedy assassination on his own life -- 00:10:47 Begins playing second reel of film -- 00:15:10 Second film finishes playing -- 00:15:13 Begins showing pictures of the Kennedys earlier in the day and another film -- 00:21:56 Thompson discusses research on the assassination and the proposed scenarios -- 00:24:14 Thompson asks the audience to join him in figuring out what happened and begins analyzing the evidence -- 00:26:30 Thompson and the audience look for the first shot and discuss logistics -- 00:42:43 Intermission begins -- 00:44:51 Intermission ends -- 00:44:53 Thompson discusses the Kennedy autopsy -- 00:51:00 Thompson continues discussing the events of the day -- 01:12:10 Thompson discusses the search for truth -- 01:14:10 Questions from the audience begin -- 01:33:53 Questions from the audience end -- 01:33:56 End of tape.

description#1: Moderated by Karen R. Kos; 00:15 Kos introduces the panel; 07:05 Gil Elliot begins his discussion; 07:50 Elliot talks about the surprising things to him in America; 08:36 Elliot talks about a workshop he attended. He also asks the audienceâ€™s preference over Buster Keaton and Charlie Chaplin; 11:00 Elliot talks about positive thinking; 13:50 Roger Ebert begins his discussion; 14:50 Ebert tells a story about touring the House of Lords; 15:57 Ebert attempts to talk about the topic of cosmic banana peels; 16:45 Ebert talks about a previous panel with Margot Adler about masturbation; 19:40 Ebert talks about musical songs; 21:46 Annette Goodheart begins her discussion. She is asked if she became a laugh therapist because she has a wonderful laugh; 22:00 Goodheart tells a story about meeting an Indian man with a good laugh; 23:37 Goodheart states that she thinks itâ€™s sad how serious we take each other and people should die laughing. She works to make people laugh about issues such as cancer; 24:58 Goodheart talks about the phrase â€œsense of humorâ€ and talks about six ways people use the term; 28:20 Goodheart talks about the cosmic sense of humor. She mentions that jokes are not allowed to be told in her group; 31:10 Goodheart talks about Charlie Chaplin; 33:00 Goodheart talks about the realm of happiness and how it comes from pain. She states â€œyou only laugh when it hurtsâ€ and â€œweâ€™re only happy because we laughâ€; 38:00 Molly Ivins begins her discussion; 38:43 Ivins tells her story about being assigned to cover the Texas Legislature as a reporter for several years; 43:34 Ivins talks about the stupidity of Texas congressman, Jim Collins and how she wrote about him in the paper; 45:43 Ivins tells a story about former Texas governor, Dolph Briscoe. She talks about how she makes fun of politicians in her column; 50:10 Ivins talks about the unintentional hostility of laughter; 53:35 Margot Adler begins her discussion; 54:00 She talks about the notion â€œcomedy is tragedy plus timeâ€ and asks who went to the nerd panel; 55:36 Adler talks about her first sexual experience and first time using a tampon. Her story transitions to her experience in jail. She concludes that her experience was really tragic and she felt really terrible about herself but community gathering and tragic events really bring out laughter; 01:0140 Adler tells a story about [Daniel Graham?] at the Conference of World Affairs ; 01:02:45 Adler talks about humor and religion; 01:04:52 Bernard Rands begins his discussion; 01:06:15 Rands tells a story about men in a bar in New York. He also tells a story about a Jewish man eating soup at a restaurant; 01:09:20 Rand tells a story about the mistaken identity of a little girl; 01:11:32 Rands talks about the humor of Bill Cosby; 01:12:17 Audience invited to ask questions; 01:13:34 Goodheart talks about playing with our pain and what â€œfunnyâ€ means; 01:14:53 Unidentified person likes the comment from Goodheart that people who are often the life of the party are not laughing. He also talks about comedians being serious, insecure people; 01:20:15 Panelists talk about jokes and the connection of absurdities with life; 01:24:00 Panelist talks about film and actors; 01:25:40 Panelists comment that you can tell where a societyâ€™s problems are based on the comedy of the time; 01:27:20 Audience member asks Goodheart if there is a relationship between laughter and personal contact; 01:30:55 Audience member asks about the term â€œcharacter assassinationâ€ brought up in a previous panel; 01:34:20 Audience member asks what kind of humor can save Ronald Reagan or people; 01:36:17 Panelist asks for five volunteers to go in the hall and prepare a skit. Goodheart talks about an experience doing a workshop for the Los Angeles Police Department. Panelists continue to tell stories; 01:46:12 The skit begins; 01:49:59 Skit ends and [Goodheart?] asks the audience if there is something they are serious about and need to laugh about; 01:50:16 Audience member talks about their fatherâ€™s funeral; 01:50:44 Audience member states she works as an RN. Goodheart talks about an experience working with a girl that experienced sexual abuse; 01:53:25 Panel ends.

description#1: Moderated by Jane Lowenthal. Harvey Wasserman begins by explaining why he chose to get rid of his television set. Wassermann expresses concern about why the most addictive drug of all, television, is not banned at all. Wasserman discusses the addictive and destructive powers of television. Roger Ebert talks about how he spends a lot of time on the computer. Ebert then discusses how the passivity of sitting in front of a television set has been replaced by the ability to surf the web. David Finkle talks about how headlines can change much more often with television.

description#1: The speakers discuss the relationship between Havana and Miami in relation to trading, production, purchasing of sugar, and ways to benefit the Cuban economic status. Cuba desired to change its political system (capitalist state) and increase its international communication with nations by investing their money abroad in US or Europe. However, the Americans urged a breakaway of dependence, allowing Cuba to achieve a higher standard of living and economic dependence. However, in attempt to achieve this goal, Americans did not realize that the communists wanted to use the Cuban revolution for its own purposes with soviet aid, dependence, and anger towards the US. Finally, a speaker states the necessity of a new policy that will not result in war but instead provide a chance to prove sincerity between US and Cuban relations.

description#1: Moderated by Lewis Sawin. Howard Mills begins by reading and discussing a passage from Lady Chatterley's Lover written by D. H. Lawrence. Sayre P. Sheldon talks about how Lady Chatterley's Lover was her sex education. Sheldon explains why feminists dislike Lawrence. Sheldon then discusses how Lawrence saw sex as the male domination of the female. Katherine Neville talks about how all the books she has read that's written by Lawrence have male characters that are very intriguing. Roger Ebert explains why the keyword in the title, Lady Chatterley's Lover, is "lady". Eric Lax reads and discusses passages from a few novels.

description#1: The status of Southeast Asian countries is discussed by the speakers. As well as how indo-china is underrepresented in the UN. There are military and political factors as to why outside nations want to intervene and be involved in this are: the escalation of warfare, and the dangers of bombings and weaponries in South Vietnam. The desired communist state by Ho Chi Min was against Diem whom fought against the French, but since there is no popular support of outside forces in Vietnam there should also not be a military presence. The white paper justifies the escalation policy and explains what region has control over most of the nation.

description#1: The possession and operation of atomic weapons are discussed by the speakers. There are currently three countries with nuclear programs: the United States, Britain, and Russia. Only public opinion will raise the pressure to ban nuclear tests and dissuade other nations from developing nuclear weapons of their own. The task is for these three active countries with the knowledge and background to reduce nuclear capacity and eventually lead to disarmament.

description#1: Moderated by Faye Johnson. The panel discusses the political left wing in the United States, especially as it relates to the 1988 presidential election. Harvey Wasserman argues that the Democratic Party was torn apart at the 1968 Democratic National Convention as a result of the Vietnam War. Molly Ivins examines and makes distinctions between liberals, radicals, and revolutionaries. Tani Adams relates her personal history to define liberals, concluding that labels are ineffective. David Twersky contests Wasserman's interpretation of 1968, and analyzes Jesse Jackson's role in the presidential election. Panel discussion and audience questions focus on the 1988 election.

description#2: Moderated by John R. Carnes. The speaker discusses the prevalence of espionage and surveillance in our Capital. He sees the entanglement of public relations (as a merchandising technique) with politics to be one of the main concerns in the Watergate scandal. The speaker emphasizes that current legal ethics demonstrate the relationship of authority and law. He describes this as the 'Nixonian' view, that the acts of coercive authority are the law. He specifies that lawless authority has especially affected American Indians and American blacks. Coercion arises not only from local police or judicial authorities, but is also a principal tool of the Pentagon in the prosecution of illegal war. Increase in lawless authority coincides with growth in technology and the momentum for social change.

description#1: Moderated by John Carnes; 00:00 First unidentified panelist talks about the House Un-American Activities Committee. He begins by explaining that Congress organizes their work through committees and investigation; 03:28 First unidentified panelist goes into the history of the creation of the committee. He talks about how communism influenced the group; 07:22 First unidentified panelist states that liberals believe the House Un-American Activities Committee and the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee have operated a â€œcongressional witch-huntâ€; 09:22 First unidentified panelist talks about [Marske v. United States?] regarding aid given to refugees of the Spanish Civil War, as well as the Watkins v. United States case; 18:40 First unidentified panelist asks â€œwhether we have enough courage and faith in our democratic society not to outlaw any political partyâ€ and mentions that communists have not been officially outlawed; 19:54 First unidentified panelist mentions that he thinks it is important that the United States move forward after the McCarthy period and support free discussion. He continues to say a free society requires faith; 21:48 Second unidentified speaker begins by saying that he believes communists should not be dealt with by the House Un-American Activities Committee; 23:40 Second panelist explains that Congress does have the power to call persons directly to the house or senate and commit them for contempt, although the power has not been used in recent times; 37:10 Audio cuts out; 38:04 Third unidentified panelist talks about how committees do or do not serve a useful purpose; 39:43 Third unidentified panelist asks three questions of congressional committees and whether the committee violates fundamental values of society; 46:45 Third unidentified panelist talks about the McCarthy investigation and how McCarthy loved to be photographed; 56:28 Third unidentified panelist suggests reforms that should be required for a legislative committee; 59:30 Audience applauds and recording ends.

description#1: @00:04 John Lawler introduces speaker @2:18 Miller begins @58:22 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by John Lawler (substituting for Robert A. Aldrich). The speaker describes a new 'ism': ageism, in which young people are unfairly judged and sentenced to penal institutions. He calls for correctional reforms with quick and massive changes, without waiting. He describes reform attempts in Massachusetts, before their juvenile institutions were closed. The speaker provides numerous examples of the abuses in programs at their "training" schools. Miller feels that alternatives for youngsters should engage and educate them, and he predicts that conventional institutions will only create more violence and insanity.

description#1: Moderated by Robert Kroepsch. Roger Ebert believes that society might be trying to liberate itself from "American, middle-class concepts of marriage" that include property, legally binding documents, children, stereotypical gender roles, and divorce. He proposes that alternative forms of marriage, such as communal marriage and common law marriage, might help address these issues. Ebert begins a discussion with the audience about the possibility of women keeping their last names, reasons for getting married, factors that contribute to the success or failure of a marriage, accepting change in marriage, new trends in marriage, sexual incompatibility, affairs, open marriages, women with jobs, and equality.

description#1: Moderated by Maurice Albertson. Irving L. Horowitz explores the military, economic, social, and political difficulties in finding a solution to the arms race. Noel Parrish refutes Horowitz, pointing out that nuclear weapons would not be used to kill civilians and that the Soviet Union continues to resist inspection. Jiri Nehnevajsa also disagrees with Horowitz, stating that Americans do not view the arms race in "black-and-white perspectives" and that there is no sinister force at work in the U.S. government that perpetuates the production of nuclear weapons.

description#1: The main speaker explains the Apollo program its goal: to send three men to the moon. The machinery will weigh approximately 90,000 pounds and be extremely sensitive to calculations, which are vital for accurate calibration for space travel. The speakers illustrate its components, durability, and how well it will be able to maneuver in orbit and be able bring the men back to the same location on the planet. There will be a central location built for monitoring around the nation as it is on its mission. One speaker describes the Apollo program as resulting from political decisions, such as economy, prestige of the country, and interest to send someone to the moon.

description#1: Moderated by Robert T. Firestone; 00:05 Firestone begins by introducing the panel; 01:26 Arden King begins his discussion by talking about religious behavior and animal behavioral revolution; 02:36 King explores how the homo sapiens is the kind of animal that can meditate and the range of possible experience which has expanded through life forms; 03:15 King defines what he means by environment; 04:33 King talks about evolution of man and increase in means of communication between life forms regarding behavioral evolution; 06:20 King talks about the basis for behavioral meditation. He talks about man assigning exact meaning to messages and symbolic communication; 08:35 King talks about the distinction of self from other; 10:11 Rama Mehta begins her discussion. She talks about the place of meditation in Hinduism; 10:43 Mehta mentions three principles underlying the concept of philosophy in Hinduism such as liberation from the cycle of life and death; 11:30 Mehta talks about the four types of yoga including the karma yoga, bhakti yoga, jnana yoga, and hati yoga; 14:00 Mehta talks about the Brahman or the supreme being; 15:10 Mehta explains that meditation is a discipline and discovery that cannot be picked up quickly at one time. Careful understanding of what you are doing and an instructor is required; 20:15 Henry Fairlie begins his discussion. He talks about the West expanding to other civilizations; Fairlie talks about Hinduism and its philosophy; 24:20 Fairlie talks about the Western idea of meditation; 26:18 Fairlie talks about the phrase â€œonly connectâ€ from E. M. Forster; 29:20 Fairlie talks about unconscious meditation using drugs and alcohol; 36:20 Roger Ebert begins his discussion. He talks about his time in school and how much he struggled with science but excelled at the humanities; 41:00 Ebert mentions he cannot adjust to a technological society or creative, humanist society; 41:20 Ebert talks about his experience writing and the deadlines he must meet as a reporter. He finds an inability to write for long periods of time alone; 48:50 Ebert continues to talk about a quiet, meditative world of work; 51:55 Members of the panel react to the discussion. King starts by talking about a â€œcontinuous individuationâ€ of the organisms that make up society; 55:55 Audience member asks about the extreme views of meditation, that being materiality of the Western man versus Hindu philosophy that everything visible is unreal and asks if there is possibility of moderation between both cultures; 01:02:45 Audience member asks about the personality of a Hindu in a Hindu society versus personality of a Western person in Hindu society; 01:04:55 Audience member asks â€œwhy does man want to meditateâ€ and continues to state that it does not matter where a man comes from but is just looking for a better life; 01:14:00 Audience member feels like the entire discussion missed the point of meditation and has not really covered the topic of meditation; 01:17:45 Audience member states that Kingâ€™s viewpoints are nonsensical and thinks that people should be able to study both Eastern and Western cultures; 01:27:36 Audience member asks about the power of positive thinking; 01:28:35 Audience member asks Fairlie whether he feels caught in a Westernized conciseness; 01:34:38 Recording cuts out.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Howard Wachtel. Robert Wright begins by talking about what memes are and the history of the term. Wright argues/explains why meme is a very important concept. Wright states that memes are units of cultural information. Ken Goldberg talks about how meme is a generalization of an "idea". Goldberg states why the propagation method of meme is very important. Goldberg then explains how technology can change the process of meme transmission. Roger Ebert talks about how memes comprise the total content of one's mind. Ebert then explains why memes are the cultural equivalent of genes.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Men are from Venus, Women are from Mars
description#1: Moderated by Sharon Conlin. The panel discusses communication difficulties between men and women. Bill Weeden summarizes John Gray's Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus and argues that men and women communicate differently. Sally Fay agrees that women are different, but is concerned that these differences are used by society against women. Molly Ivins examines the historical oppression of women, and argues that stereotypes are a tool of oppression. Harvey Wasserman challenges these stereotypes and sees changing gender roles as a vision of the future. Audience questions focus on gender roles and homosexuality.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Daniel Raybon. This panel discusses the changing relationship and roles between men and women. Thomas Powers argues that men are resisting womenâ€™s attempts to redefine their roles in society, and he asserts that men and women are equals in nearly all aspects of life. Clara Wainwright illuminates the necessity of a group setting where men and women can discuss issues, whether gender specific or extending to the whole human species. Bob Wilber shares his experiences with women (or the lack thereof) in his field of work: nuclear weaponry. Molly Ivins introduces varying roles of women throughout history and subtle differences between the two sexes.

description#1: Moderated by Milton E. Lipetz. Perdita Huston talks about the lives and the families of several villages she has visited in Indonesia, Kenya, Sri Lanka, Mexico and other countries. She explains that she questioned the people in the villages about how the economy and negative or positive change has affected them. Huston also talks about the gap between men and women. She states that it is a fact that for women choices are limited. Huston discusses how she provided the women a chance to voice their opinions.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Message to the Media for the Third Century
description#1: @00:02 host introduces speaker @3:10 Morgan begins @31:14 Morgan ends @44:46 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Eugene H. Wilson. The speaker claims there is a gap between the people and the media, which is not doing their job: they fail to inform the public and they promote controversy. He claims that news is being filtered through a person's voice and face by 2 elements in the media: sight and sound (television and radio). Instead, he contends that the media should document issues at the heart of our national security, such as improving education. He feels that news stories should relate to the public's interests. He concludes that knowledge, constructive controversy and genuine enlightenment fuel the government by the people and for the people.

title#1: Mexiamericana: Chicanos, Immigration and the Transnational Nation
description#1: Moderated by Carmen Atilano; 00:03 Carmen Atilano begins speaking. Introducing the panelists in order: Jonathan Freedman, Arturo Arias, Ronald Klein, and Primitivo Rodriguez; 03:05 Freedman begins speaking how Mexamerica is the most economically booming of the U.S.; 06:20 Freedman says that Chicanas are oppressed in this democracy. They are not aliens; 08:54 Explains what happens to people who come to America illegally and legally; 15:35 Freedman talks about immigration law and amnesty for immigrants; 19:52 Freedman stops speaking; 20:02 Arturo Arias begins speaking about the multi ethnic nation and why so many immigrants are coming to the United States; 36:53 Arias stops speaking; 37:06 Ronald Klein begins speaking about an old fugitive case; 45:09 Klein says that the similarity between religion and language unified the community, 47:16 Klein stops speaking; 47:27 Primitivo Rodriguez begins saying that Chicanos are proud of being American and Mexican; 50:04 Rodriguez says that the culture and future will depend on Chicanos; 0:51:10 Rodriguez discusses the Chicano population. He says the Chicano community is isolated; 55:22 Rodriguez says that Latin American citizens emerged and that the Chicano culture has followed them to the US; 01:01:30 Rodriguez says that Chicanos need to keep being bilingual and cultural; 01:03:35 Rodriguez stops speaking; 01:06:30 Unidentified audience member asks why foreign people have to learn English. Two of the panelists answer her question; 01:16:06 Unidentified panelist says that passing laws for people to learn English is not right and talks about assimilation; 01:34:17 Unidentified panelist says that what happens in the US could happen in Europe too; 01:42:20 Unidentified panelist says that the issues of Central America and South America come to America then those issues will become important to the U.S. Discusses that everyone deserves rights; 01:46:41 Unidentified audience member asks about land struggles in Mexico; 01:51:41 Moderator thanks the panelists. Audience applauds and panel discussion ends.

title#1: Mommy, Where Do Values Come From?
description#1: Moderated by Christine Denning. The panelists discuss personal and social values. Jory Agate asks the audience what their values are, before exhorting them to encourage society to reflect these values. Tom Minnery defines values as that which helps an individual decide what to do in difficult situations. Molly Ivins examines the political debate over family values, arguing that not all democratic values are privileged equally. During discussion, the panel debates the role of religious values in American society. Audience questions lead to discussions about homosexuality, religion, and personal responsibility.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Jean Kim. In this session, Jonathan Broder and Molly Ivins discuss the Bill Clinton-Monica Lewinsky scandal and its impact on feminism. Jonathan Broder frames the discussion by arguing that the scandal was not as serious as Watergate or the Iran-Contra scandal. Broder interviews Molly Ivins, asking questions that cover the various intersections between Monica Lewinsky and feminism in the public discourse. Ivins compares and contrasts different political scandals, pointing out hypocritical responses. The discussion also covers various legal actions taken against the Clinton administration. Audience questions cover historical and legal precedents, the media's role, and Hillary Clinton.Moderated by William Scanlon. ++++++++++++++

titleSeries#1: Series X: Is Art Saying Anything to Anyone
description#1: Moderated by Curt Zimansky. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how movies made in mid-1960s have no meaning and no paraphrasable content. Ebert then talks about how people read novels to find out how it ends. Also, Ebert provides two ways in which a director deals with their ideas. Steven A. Linn talks about why people tend to put film in a category separate from other art forms. Larry Horton explains why movies are the only art form where one can sit down with anybody and get an honest response.

description#1: A group of three speakers give small commentaries loosely based around the theme of "moving the world". The first speaker, Peter Davidson, does a poetry and prose reading on the theme. The second and third speakers provide humorous commentary on politics and contemporary events in 1980.

description#1: Moderated by Kenneth R. Hammond. Steven A. Linn begins by talking about a few murders that have occurred. Roger Ebert talks about terrorism by the gross and states that it is both an individual and institutional thing. Ebert then discusses extremist movements in the world. Larry Horton talks about articles released after the Kennedy assassination. Edwin Casebeer explains why he thinks of terrorism as a political act. Casebeer then states how mass murder terrorizes people, but is not necessarily an act of terrorists. Christopher Cory discusses the safety valve theory of surrogate violence. Cory questions if there are societies with less than greater degrees of violence.

description#1: Moderated by Robert R. Fink; 00:50 Fink introduces the panel and the topic of Music and Language; 00:57 Bernard Rands apologizes because the presentation was supposed to be a joint presentation with Mel Powell but Powell could not make it; 01:45 Rands begins his discussion about the relationship between text or language and the musical context that can be created. He also explains that he usually talks about the syntax and grammar of music but will talk about â€œvisual languageâ€ and how, for example, a painting can create analogies in music instead. He talks about an opera that was based on the life and work of the painter, Vincent van Gogh; 04:25 Rands talks about the technique of the paintings â€œBeach at Scheveningen in Stormy Weatherâ€ and â€œBeach at Scheveningen in Calm Weather.â€ He continues to talk about the foreground, middle ground, and background of the paintings and the surface detail which he makes a connection to in the orchestral surface and compositional sound; 07:23 Rands plays a recording of the orchestra to demonstrate the relation of language between the boats and people in the paintings to the sound, or compositional nature, of the orchestra; 11:09 Rands stops the recording and continues to talk about the quality of the recording and Vincent van Gogh; 12:18 Rands talks about the drawing â€œSorrowâ€ by Vincent van Gogh. He talks about the surface drawing as an outline, the second drawing being more elaborate and then the third stage of the drawing being the most complex. He relates the stages of the drawing to variations in music; 14:30 Rands plays the next recording related to â€œSorrowâ€; 20:27 Rands mentions a painting titled â€œThe Tambourinâ€ or [â€œAgostina Segatori Sitting in the CafÃ© du Tambourinâ€] and talks about the cafÃ© in Paris that many artists would visit. He continues to talk about the geometry of the cafÃ© setting in the painting; 23:06 Rands plays a recording that reflects the language of the painting â€œAgostina Segatori Sitting in the CafÃ© du Tambourinâ€; 28:12 Rands stops the recording and talks about light in a painting. Rands continues to talk about the uneasy relationship Vincent van Gogh and Paul Gaugin had with their fathers. He relates the â€œinner lightâ€ of Vincent van Gogh to his artistry; 31:05 Rands talks about two van Gogh paintings and the difference in light: â€œThe Night CafÃ©â€ and â€œCafÃ© Terrace at Nightâ€; 33:00 Rands starts the next recording in relation to the two paintings about the night cafÃ©; 37:20 Rands ends the recording and concludes with a painting titled [â€œThe Dance Hall in Arlesâ€]; 39:00 Rands starts the final recording about the dance in Arles; 42:45 Rands ends the recording and thanks the audience for listening.

description#1: Moderated by John Galm. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how movies have too much music. Marian Edmunds questions if reality should be underscored with music. Edmunds also questions if film and music can collaborate, and still remain art forms of their own integrity. Johnny Mandel briefly talks about scoring the news. Mandel then explains why there is a lot of music in film today. Dave Grusin talks about why music is put in film for various reasons, and states that the underlying reason is to manipulate how one feels. Grusin then answers Edmunds question regarding film and music collaborating.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: In a diverse panel discussion about the relationship of music and language, changes in music syntax and theory are discussed from several academic perspectives(music theory, anthropology, computer science). These experts in various fields discuss the relationship between music and language and if there are distinct similarities between the two. Heavily discussed are the connections to linguistic theory(particularly Chomsky) and whether such ideas can be imported into thinking about music.

description#1: Moderated by John Bramsen. Miroslav Soukop begins by talking about a general concept regarding mutual accommodation and extermination. Soukop introduces two concepts concerning culture system, social system, and personality system. Richard Felger talks about how extermination is like extinction. Felger then states that there is no way to measure the values of another species. Arden King questions how the concept of environment brings people a little bit closer to understanding themselves. King ends the panel by stating that in any animal, the question of survival lies in the accommodation within their environment.

titleSeries#1: Series XIV: Arms and the Man
description#1: Moderated by John Loeffler. Robert B. Bathurst starts by talking about how mutual security is a state of mind and a psychological perception of threat. Bathurst also mentions how power is about how well we perceive a threat. Thomas A. Halsted talks about nuclear weapon posture as another aspect to US military policy towards Europe. Halsted questions how nuclear weapon should be used towards our enemies and how it will enhance our European allies. William Wilberforce briefly states how both countries must have equal respect for the vital interest of both sides.

description#1: @00.03 Joseph R. Smiley introduces Marya Mannes @3:34 Marya Mannes talks @38:48 Mannes ends @40:05 tape ends
description#2: Marya Mannes describes the present day reality behind the illusions portrayed in commercials and mass media. She speaks about the persistence of myth in the face of that reality, and the "smug incomprehension of people as to what is happening to them." She stated the need for "saints and sacrifices" in order to rise above our present condition of malaise. Chairman Joseph R. Smiley presiding.

description#1: Moderated by Eugene H. Wilson; 00:00 Wilson introduces Ralph Nader and reads from an editorial; 04:37 Nader begins his discussion. He talks about meeting the vice president of the Ford Motor Company; 05:40 Nader talks about the assault on the automobile and the fact that car accidents have led to the fourth leading cause of death in the United States. He also talks about the rising cost of money these accidents cause while the retail sales of the automobile continues to rise; 08:23 Nader expands on his discussion of pollution caused by cars; 09:20 Nader talks about the money the government has spent in research for automobile safety; 10:50 Nader talks about how he came to his opinions about automobile transportation. He mentions that the automotive transportation system has no accountability or responsibly for all of the accidents that occur; 14:35 Nader talks about the functionality of bumpers and how lucrative the business of fixing bumpers is; 15:45 Nader talks about the highway accident toll and the positive impact it has on the economy; 18:00 Nader states there is very little governmental role in highway safety and vehicle design and construction. He continues to say that the automobile industry has attempted to keep total control on their companies and the design of their cars; 21:20 Nader talks about obsolescence and vehicles in the automotive industry and quotes from prominent employees of Ford Motor Company; 23:30 Nader talks about the dagger fins on cars and how the automotive industry stated it had an aerodynamic purpose although since there is no formal reporting requirement at the manufacturerâ€™s level, several injuries had occurred with the dagger fins and companies were not held accountable; 26:38 Nader talks about the advertisement titled â€œSon of Gunâ€ and radio advertisements geared towards teenagers; 29:00 Nader talks about Fordâ€™s responses to safety complaints; 32:50 Nader mentions that a large number of traffic safety organizations have been financed by the automobile industry which shaped the regulations on the highway today; 35:30 Nader talks about the amount of defects in cars that are able to continue to drive on the highways and the driver takes the responsibility for the accident, not the manufacturer; 37:50 Nader lists examples of the general obfuscation of large organizations for example, the companies have actively cultivated consumer ignorance; 47:00 Nader talks about the safety issues of the Torenado. He continues to say that the automobile industry only reacts to external pressure which is why people now wear seatbelts; 50:30 Nader states it is necessary now more than ever for the government to start instilling safety standards. He says there needs to be an independent center for research; 58:09 Nader finishes his discussion.

description#1: Moderated by E. James Quigley; 00:00 Recording starts in the middle of a conversation about Sherlock Holmes; 01:22 Panelist, Sam Rosenberg talks about a story where he went to visit a remote place in Switzerland; 08:30 Rosenberg talks about the background of the author of Sherlock Holmes, Arthur Conan Doyle; 14:00 Rosenberg talks about how characteristics of Friedrich Nietzsche appear throughout characters and themes in the Sherlock Holmes stories. He concludes that the characters in Sherlock Holmes are not totally fictional but take on characteristics of real people in history; 15:00 Rosenberg talks about the book he wrote; 20:00 Rosenberg talks about the rumors of homosexuality between Watson and Sherlock Holmes; 21:30 Rosenberg continues to talk about references of Friedrich Nietzsche and themes of India and Dionysus seen throughout the Sherlock Holmes books; 24:24 Rosenberg explains that he discovered the first 24 Sherlock Holmes stories contain specific references to Catholic liturgy and Good Friday; 27:00 Rosenberg talks about the sexual and religious allegory in Sherlock Holmes; 34:50 Rosenberg talks about his literary investigations and his conclusion of the â€œConan Doyle syndrome.â€ Rosenberg also uses Doyleâ€™s poem â€œThe Inner Roomâ€ as a lead towards the â€œConan Doyle syndromeâ€ that he talks about; 37:18 Rosenberg talks about a specific chapter from the Sherlock Holmes novels to highlight all of the allegory Conan Doyle put in his stories; 42:40 Rosenberg ends with the thought that every detective story is an allegory where the reader is the detective; 45:27 Quigley thanks Rosenberg for his discussion and the recording ends.

description#1: The speaker focuses on the importance of Israel's national existence since 1948 and the desire for independence. This has resulted in negative struggles such as the Nazi period and elimination of aid centers for the Jews. Independence has also led to immigration, accompanied by the problems intertwined with population and economic growth. Thus, the national purpose has turned to focus on fusion, which is why work has begun on educational opportunities regardless of class for a new economy. Working towards peace, the speaker claims that the Middle East will always be an area of diversity, emphasizing that a citizen must be equal in democratic cities despite his class and/or religion.

description#1: Moderated by Francis A. Beer. Christopher J. Makins begins by stating that the North Atlantic alliance is both a military and political organization. Makins explains the significant trends that have been occurring within the military organization of NATO, and also provides the political aspect of alliance. William L. Eagleton talks about how the alliance was set up to defend a group of countries against dangers from the Soviet Union, and not for problems amongst its own members. Patrick M. Morgan discusses the problems that cause debate in the military aspect of alliances. Richard C. Samuel ends the panel by making a brief comment about extra European affairs.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by John F. McMahon. Richard Fryklund starts by exploring the possibility of creating a NATO counterforce that would focus on targeting Soviet nuclear weapons in order to avoid a nuclear war targeting cities. Stanley Reed covers the reasons why NATO was founded. Fryklund discusses the why a NATO counterforce would be infeasible. Harvey Averch states that nuclear weapons should only be used "in direct retaliation" or in "the defense of the free world" and that a NATO counterforce is a better alternative to nuclear warfare. Noel Parrish mentions how previous and current attempts to build up a conventional force in Europe have failed, reasons why a large conventional force will never be amassed by Europe, and how nuclear warfare as the only option. A discussion between the speakers follows.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Negro Political Behavior in the South
description#1: There are many dynamics at play in southern states after desegregation and granting the right to vote to African Americans. Economic changes will surely follow. The speakers posit that the social dynamics underlying segregation and discrimination must be improved through an assimilation of African Americans into middle and upper classes, which will in turn help to eliminate conflicts between races as well as classes. However as the speakers state, the lack of potential leaders makes it difficult to comply with registration, and it is vital for leaders to arise to effect change.

description#1: Moderated by Louis Tenebaum; 00:00 Tenebaum starts by introducing the topic of the panel, as well as the panelists; 03:48 Chatterjee begins the discussion by defining the term neutralism. He talks about the nations that have been neutral. 05:20 Chatterjee talks about how India is not neutralist and how different they are from other countries. He continues to talk about the lack of military alliances with India; 07:00 Chatterjee talks about permanent interests between countries versus allies and enemies that are never permanent; 09:20 Rafiqul-Islam Choudhury begins his talk. Abdul Karim Sumitro begins his talk. description#1: Moderated by Berkley M. Sterling. Jeannine Honicker begins by stating that nuclear power is a nightmare of radioactive garbage. Honicker tells her reason on why she opposes nuclear energy. Paulanne Capavitz disagrees with Jeannine. Capavitz states that using nuclear energy is a peaceful application, and the real danger lies in using nuclear energy as a weapon. John Gliedman talks about how nuclear power is not more dangerous than other ways of generating energy. Gliedman suggests that we must distinguish between short term and long term effects of nuclear power before making extreme actions like closing down all plants.

subject#4: Climatic changes--Effect of nuclear explosions on
description#1: Moderated by Richard Harpel; 00:20 Harpel introduces the panel; 01:40 Harpel talks about recent events and the burden of the thought of a nuclear holocaust occurring from the children that have grown up with bombs. He also reads from the book â€˜War and Peaceâ€ from Leo Tolstoy; 06:45 Richard Rhodes begins his discussion. He states nuclear holocaust is entirely possible; 07:48 Rhodes talks about the consequences of nuclear war and nuclear winter. He states he will be reading from several reports such as â€œNuclear Winterâ€ by R. P. Turco, â€œLong term Biological Consequences of Nuclear Warâ€ by Paul Ehrlich, the winter issue of â€œForeign Affairsâ€ by Carl Sagan, and â€œTwentieth Century Book of the Deadâ€ by Gil Elliot; 10:30 Rhodes talks about the possibility of a 10,000 megaton nuclear exchange; 11:48 Rhodes talks about the immediate impacts of a nuclear explosion such as death, serious injuries and social disruption; 14:10 Rhodes talks about the effect of smoke and dust on the atmosphere and fallout of radioactive debris; 16:18 Rhodes then talks about the cooling of the surface of the earth and possible nuclear winter; 18:50 Rhodes talks about the lack of food and water if a nuclear holocaust occurred; 20:21 Rhodes reads the conclusion from a biological effects study. He talks about the possible extinction of homo sapiens; 22:50 Rhodes talks about an event 200 years ago when disease occurred. He reads from â€œTwentieth Century Book of the Deadâ€; 26:35 Rhodes talks about governments around the world and their involvement with the lives of their citizens; 29:21 Rhodes mentions that nuclear war does not have to happen. He states we need to take back our future; 30:20 Audience member asks whether a decentralized deterrent posture would contribute to nuclear stability; 32:21 Audience member asks if Iran and Iraq had a nuclear exchange would it bring on a nuclear winter; 33:07 Another audience member states that there have been protests in Central Europe and asks Rhodes to give feedback on the effects of the actions of the protestors and what new direction could be considered; 36:34 Audience member makes a comment about President Reaganâ€™s position; 37:07 [Harpel?] relays a circumstance about the military; 41:50 Rhodes makes a statement about feeling inadequate and says that your voice counts; 42:55 Audience member asks for clarification about the after effects of the nuclear war; 44:16 Audience member talks about mutual hostility between places like the United States and Soviet Union; 47:26 [Harpel?] talks about the effects of nuclear winter and how we should be talking about it with other people; 48:36 Rhodes ends the panel; Remainder of recording cuts to the middle of another panel discussion titled â€œThe Fight for Freedom in South Africaâ€ by panelist, Tsietsi Mashinini.

description#1: Moderated by William Kellogg. George Harris begins by talking about how countries like Pakistan and India do not have the level of trust/willingness to come to accommodation that would be required for the development of a nuclear weapon. Samuel Chavkin talks about the promotion against the idea of nuclear war or nuclear arms proliferation. Jiri Nehnevajsa explains how the threat China faces from the Soviet Union is what operates them to its development in nuclear programs. Nehnevajsa then talks about how agreement in reduction of arsenal is a possibility, but complete disarmament is not possible.

description#1: Moderated by Stanley Dollins. Van Atta explains what a nuclear test ban treaty could achieve and its potential shortcomings. Gottlieb outlines the political difficulties involved in creating a nuclear test treaty between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. Parrish discusses the history of developing a nuclear test treaty between the U.S. and the Soviet Union and the negative military implications of such a treaty. Michael refutes several of Parrish's points and explains how the U.S. resuming testing could have negative consequences for the world. Kalkstein explores the future of nuclear weapons and what the U.S. would hope to gain from a nuclear test ban.

title#1: Nuclear War: How Did We Get to Where We Are?
description#1: Moderated by Walter Orr Roberts; 00:00 Roberts introduces the panelist, James T. Bush; 01:40 Bush begins his discussion; 02:05 Bush talks about his experience working at the Center for Defense Information. He mentions that he thinks it is just as important for national security to have strong economic and social conditions as it is to have a strong defense system; 02:00 Bush talks about his experience learning about missiles on nuclear submarines and how he assumed command of submarines; 04:40 Bush mentions that although he was fully prepared to command a nuclear submarine he was not trained and prepared for the responsibility of killing thousands of people if he were to actually deploy the nuclear missiles; 05:11 Bush makes three upcoming points. He first mentions he is going to talk about our current lack of logic regarding nuclear arms; 06:08 Bush looks at history after World War II in order to understand how we can reverse the arms race situation; 09:40 Bush talks about the concept â€œflexible responseâ€ presented to NATO allies; 17:05 Bush talks about the philosophy of mutual assured destruction and the three reasons why it failed; 24:20 Bush talks about the nuclear winter study; 27:50 Bush also looks at the role of arms control as a method of stopping or reversing the arms race; 29:35 Bush talks about a bill that was passed by the House of Representatives regarding three arms control measures; 37:29 Bush talks about the three categories of first strike weapons that the United States is building; 38:42 Bush talks about the defensive system the U.S. is building. He also talks about Navy tactic to destroy Soviet submarines; 40:24 Bush reviews his main points and explains that the nuclear arms race has taken place outside the democratic process and the only way to bring it back in is to negotiate arms control agreements or make legislation; 41:30 Audience member asks if Bush thinks President Reagan understands arms issues. The audience member also asks what the role is of the military in the industrial complex arms buildup; 47:00 Panel discussion ends.

description#1: Moderated by Rigomar A. Thurmer; 00:00 Thurmer starts the session by introducing the subject of the panel and panelists; 02:39 Samuel Cohen begins his discussion. [catalogerâ€™s note: audio very quiet]; 03:25 Cohen begins his discussion again. He talks about the technical uncertainties regarding nuclear winter; 04:45 Cohen talks about the uncertainties with the military if a nuclear winter were to happen; 05:20 Cohen offers his vision of how a nuclear winter would happen if it were to actually happen. description#1: The oil industry is not only valued by the Middle East, but also by the United States, Asia, and European nations as they all depend on the production of oil. The large revenues derived from oil production in the Middle East, allow many people to become wealthy and the goals of the oil companies are to improve national economy, and develop increased industry and agriculture. The speakers state that money which goes to the banker of the oil company will in turn be able to improve poverty, which is the current trouble of Middle East. The hopeful aim of these oil companies and nations is to better security and justice, living standards, and increased availability of education.

description#1: Moderated by Virgil F. Grillo. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how form is the way a director imposes their style. Ebert states two things that make movies an art: director's control over space and control over time. Lindsay Dean talks about how moving images are able to recreate the posture and emotional intensity of sculpture. Peter M. Mayer talks about how American movies are the most important movies made because of the influence of American economy, images, and lifestyle. Polly Toynbee talks about things film can't do and expresses her thoughts on films and novels.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The Vista Program is a model for volunteer service in America, uniting all forms of government. This program allows volunteers to go into a new community, and be given a project with a sponsor who holds a job in heavily poverty stricken areas, many of these being rural. The speaker urges that to integrate America, people must reach out through this creative partnership and enable people to feel their own worth.

description#1: Moderated by John L. Dotson; 00:25 Dotson introduces the panelist, Ted Turner; 04:53 Turner begins his discussion. He talks about the topic of the panel â€œone worldâ€ and believes we live in one world where we really need to start coming together all over the world; 07:05 Turner talks about his studies in history to uncover the threats of the world and understand the future. He starts the history lesson by talking about religion and Judeo-Christian beliefs; 11:43 Turner talks about the rapid increase in world population; 12:44 Turner talks about the arms race. He ties the topic of religion in with the military; 16:29 Turner talks about the industrial revolution and technology. He states we used the new technology and changed the environment; 19:44 Turner talks about the way Western man has treated the rest of the world. He talks about opium in China and slavery. He also talks about World War I and World War II; 22:55 Turner talks about the cycle in history being broken and a renaissance occurring at the current time. He continues to talk about nuclear weapons and the arms race; 25:41 Turner compares the current situation happening around the world today to the voyage of the Titanic. He mentions, like the Titanic, we have so many warnings about the environment and politics but we are not listening; 28:04 Turned states the United States is still making good progress because it is one nation. He uses other nations as examples of success and ties it back to the one world topic; 30:00 Turner talks about volunteering and making contributions to other countries that are struggling because we are all the same human beings; 31:59 Turner mentions that we need to stop the arms race and cut back on expenditures and the military budget. He also states we need to start planting more trees use cleaner forms of energy. He also thinks everyone should get healthcare and birth control should be provided to underdeveloped countries; 35:00 Turner talks about implementing a rule of law across the world and working with the United Nations and Soviet Union; 36:37 Audience member asks how Turner would phase out nuclear power plants in the United States and the nuclear weapons industry. He uses Three Mile Island as an example; 38:15 Audience member asks Turner how we can make news and the media less violent yet still exciting; 39:27 Audience member asks Turner how we can make the world a better place if people continue to profit off of these situations; 41:14 Audience member asks how we can achieve agreement with everyone around the world since there continues to always be fighting; 43:00 Audience member asks Turner if he will make the problem with drug trading a pertinent topic in the news; 44:54 Audience member asks Turner if he agrees that it takes money to implement the changes he talked about; 46:41 Audience member asks Turner if he is interested in seeking office; 47:30 Audience member asks Turner if he supports abortion; 49:33 Audience member asks Turner how he is going to change the hearts of men and uses Germany as an example. Turner talks about using education; 50:56 Audience member asks Turner â€œhow do we build the United Nations?â€; 52:11 Turner ends the discussion.

description#1: Moderated by James N. Corbridge; 00:00 Corbridge introduces the panel; 00:27 Ted Turner begins his discussion. He introduces topics such as the arms race, nuclear winter, and the money generated from the Cold War between the Soviet Union and the United States. He explains how destructive the conflict has been between the Soviet Union and the United States; 03:30 Turned talks about the concern regarding â€œwho started the war?â€; 06:30 Turner talks about the INF Treaty, or the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, and hopes that the two world powers can turn their attention to making the world a better place; 07:46 Jed Duvall starts his discussion. 08:13 Duvall mentions previous talks about the meaning of peace; 10:42 Duvall talks about the summit in the Soviet Union and how it might be the beginning of the end of the Cold War; 12:00 Michael Stoff begins his discussion; 12:28 Stoff talks about the excitement of a vision of â€œone world.â€ Although he mentions that he continues to take the viewpoint of a historian and admits the American â€œone worldâ€ attitude is bold and optimistic but not new. He continues to talk about the Treaty of Versailles and a vision of a new world made from a league of nations; 16:36 Stoff fast forwards twenty years later and talks about World War II and internationalism; 18:00 Stoff talks about how nuclear arms and energy could then be turned towards peace and a commonality of humanity; 18:50 Stoff talks about the dystopian book â€œ1984â€; 19:45 Stoff talks about the encouraging signs of the end of the Cold War like other wars, but provides a cautionary tale using Albert Einsteinâ€™s letter to Franklin D. Roosevelt urging Roosevelt to develop an atomic bomb; 22:44 Stoff talks about the importance of language, technology and a realistic sensibility; 24:01 Corbridge tells the audience the panel would like to talk to the audience about their comments and questions; 24:32 First audience member asks Mr. Duvall how the issue regarding the size of the military budget will play out in the election this fall; 26:19 Audience member states he is working on a constitutional amendment which entitles every Coloradan to a clean and healthful environment and he asks Turner what he can do to counter the negative media about the amendment; 28:20 New audience member tells the panel that their viewpoints are naÃ¯ve and the panel argues back and forth with the audience member; 33:21 Next audience member asks Turner why he does not use his supervisory power to tell his reporters exactly what they should report on; 37:34 Audience member asks Turner if he had heard about greater resistance regarding some extreme elements of our culture; 41:40 Audience member asks Turner if he is airing the â€œContragateâ€ hearings. He also asks if Turner has any plans to influence more peace in America; 43:32 Another audience member addresses a comment towards Turner about the ignorance of humanity; 44:58 Audience member admits she gets an uneasy feeling about the notion of â€œone worldâ€ and asks the panel how much power they are willing to give up to achieve â€œone worldâ€; 51:20 New audience member asks what steps it would take to develop sensitivity and a new point of view to enact peace around the world; 01:00:46 Audio cuts out; 01:00:59 Audio comes back in the middle of an audience memberâ€™s comment. He asks the panel to take a look at the Charter of the United Nations where it states the nations will not be using the threat of force against other nations and continues to ask the panel how they think the United States can become a meaningful member of a family of nations bound my international law; 01:06:26 Audience member comments that our government is very reactionary and asks the panel if they have any comments about the environment and the scarcity mentality of people; 01:09:25 Audience member asks the panel if they think nations have too many differences to ever come together; 01:11:35 Audience member asks what the differences are between communism and capitalism; 01:15:08 Audience member asks Stoff what he thinks the historical presence is of the EEC. He also asks Duvall and Turner if the European community can fit into the future of â€œone worldâ€ for all countries, not just Europe; 01:19:47 Audience member aims to address the issue of greed and the role of multinational corporations in the world. He continues to ask how we obtain peace with the exploitation that stems from greed; 01:22:00 Audience member asks Turner how we could ever achieve world peace if other people seem to think very differently than ourselves; 01:26:05 Audience member asks about the process of disarmament and the economy that is involved with disarmament; 01:32:15 Audience member asks Turner if he thinks there is a role for American military intervention into a culture after a war to help rebuild society; 01:36:06 Audience member asks Turner and Duvall why they donâ€™t use their influence and their network to let the rest of the world see the death from the Iran-Iraq War; 01:40:09 Recording cuts out.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Open and Closed: Bullies, Hackers, Saints - The Internet Changes It All
description#1: Moderated by Joe Wingerd. Oliver McBryan begins by predicting that internet access will be at the same level as television access. McBryan also predicts that internet access is going to become universal rapidly. McBryan then discusses how video companies and cable companies control a lot of bandwidth. Philip Zimmermann explains how new technology could affect freedom of speech. Zimmermann then talks about the debate of whether cryptography should be available to people. Floyd Cottonberg briefly talks about computer hackers. Roger Ebert discusses a few problems regarding the internet, such as pornographic materials and chain mails.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Speakers Peter Lupsha and Sam Papich discuss organized crime in America. Discussed are myths about organized crime, such as its actual activities, ethnic makeup, and geographical distribution. A theory of the current model and paradigm of contemporary organized crime are proposed. A historical overview of organized crime dating back to colonial America is given to explain the contemporary structure and process of organized crime, particularly in its relationship to the political system and corruption.

description#1: Moderated by Paul V. Thompson; 00:08 Thompson introduces the panel; Gerald Mason Feigen begins his discussion. He starts with a number of questions such as â€œdo we need spies?â€; 03:45 Feigen talks about the James Bond movies; 05:30 Feigen talks about the CIA and their lack of identity and professionalism; 07:15 Feigen talks about secret agents used to fight communism. He states communism is a failure of a system. He also talks about the Cold War; 10:30 Feigen states his opinion about the United Nations. He thinks China should be admitted to the United Nations; 12:04 Feigen states the United States has a poor image according to other countries and that hurts our spy system; 13:27 John Midgley begins his discussion. He talks about spy stories; 15:00 Midgley states the United Nations does not engage with spies; 16:00 Midgley asks â€œis spying necessary?â€ and talks about the abolishment of spying; 21:29 Midgley talks about voting rights amongst different nations and the United Nations; 23:40 Russell Baker begins his discussion. He talks about spies in literature and movies; 25:30 Baker talks about the British secret service; 27:26 Baker states that Russians have it easy when it comes to spying; 28:22 Baker talks about American electronic intelligence and the CIA. He continues to talk about congressional oversight; 33:05 Brian Urquhart begins his discussion. He mentions that the CIA is not the only secret agency in the United States; 35:15 Urquhart talks to the younger people in the room who may end up in this profession. He mentions there is a lot of dreary work associated with the job; 36:00 Urquhart talks about another thing an intelligence service does which is to collect information about its own government; 36:46 He also states the secret service exerts influence in other foreign governments; 40:53 Urquhart talks about the gathering of two kinds of secret military information; 49:08 Thompson allows the audience to ask questions. First audience member asks about intranational spying; 52:37 Audience member asks Feigen if wiretapping should be held as evidence in court; 53:20 Audience member follows up with Feigen and asks if the democratic right includes freedom of speech; 58:10 Audience member asks Feigen to expand on his statement about the Cold War diminishing; 59:30 Audience member asks if the panel would agree with depriving the CIA of propaganda functions; 01:02:35 Audience member asks about international spying having an impact on domestic policy; 01:04:00 Audience member asks if there are any United Nations hired staff to work with other nations; 01:07:08 Audience member asks about China in the United Nations and the panel clarifies that China already has a seat at the United Nations; 01:08:50 Unidentified person asks Urquhart how interested the Chinese is with entering the United Nations; 01:12:50 Last audience member asks if the next step for the spy situation is a scenario where citizens are spying to gain intel on what the government is doing; 01:14:47 Thompson ends the session.

titleSeries#1: Series XIV: Arms and the Man
description#1: Moderated by Rodger Padget. Peter Mayors begins by stating that people no longer have a positive faith in defensive armament or in pacifism as a positive force. Molse discusses why getting rid of all armed forces doesn't provide a utopian world. Molse talks about how there won't be state of peace unless everybody wants it. Rivers discusses how a whole system of relationship within society depends on exploited relationships. River also talks about his stay in Angola and states that the people in Angola are united because of the presence of an external oppressor. River ends the panel by questioning if the people would still be united if there was no external oppressor.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by John Dunn. Nancy Abrams notes the lack of women in science and uses premature birth research to illustrate the different views men and women can have. Sonya Hamlin states that men dominate many workplaces, because men are taught, from a young age, how to be successful in the job market while women do not receive the same informal training. Roger Ebert mentions that, for the past ten years, the winners of the Academy Award were male actors portraying regular men, while the female winners portrayed either political figures or prostitutes. Chad Gordon discusses sociological research on divorce, marriage, and gender roles.

description#1: Moderated by Walter Orr Roberts; 00:00 [Recording starts in the middle of a conversation]; 01:20 [Roberts] talks about alternative fuels and a necessity to develop a world system that makes careful use of the soils of the planet. He then introduces the rest of the panel; 05:55 First unidentified panelist begins his discussion by saying that the globe uses about 30% of planetary resources; 07:52 First panelist wonders who has a right to use the planetâ€™s resources and at the rate they are being consumed. He continues to talk about the privilege of developed nations and how to distribute resources to nations that are not as developed. He continues to question what the obligation is to make us do what is right when distributing global resources; 13:00 First panelist talks about the curves shown on graphs depicting an expanding world population and consumption of resources; 20:20 Second unidentified panelist begins his discussion. He mentions that people are a main planetary resource; 22:45 Second panelist talks about Benjamin Franklinâ€™s viewpoint on population; 25:00 Second panelist talks about the â€œfairness problemâ€ when distributing resources; 36:00 Second panelist talks about rationality with resources in the future and what will be left; 37:36 Third unidentified panelist begins his discussion. He continues the discussion about future of resources and immediate solutions that have been proposed; 39:00 Third panelist continues to say that the population and the press believe that small solutions today will fix resource problems for the future but the problem is much larger than that. He uses an example of solar energy and natural gas in Arizona; 44:00 Third panelist talks about a trend towards the rejection of technology; 53:30 Roberts opens the discussion to questions from the audience; 55:00 Howard E. Grubber starts the conversation about the temperature in the room and the sweaters the panelists are all wearing; 57:44 Unidentified panelist reacts to Grubberâ€™s statements regarding energy crises; 01:00:00 Another unidentified panelist also responds to Howardâ€™s sweater comment; 01:03:16 Audience member comments on Hodgeâ€™s remark about collecting resources from outer space and wonders if it would or would not cost the same amount to transport resources back and fourth on earth, rather than harvesting the resources from space; 01:05:22 Audience member talks about people taking care of their own problems without the help of other countries [catalogerâ€™s note: audience memberâ€™s conversation difficult to decipher]; 01:12:50 Audience member comments that American citizens are concerned about the prospect of our oil and natural resources running out. He continues to ask the panel how resources can be allocated and what the United States will do about it; 01:29:11 Audience member comments that it seems the world has the knowledge and resources to transform energy if you have the leadership to do so and then asks the panel if they we can get leadership to rationally push towards new technology or alternative forms of energy and if that would change our outcome by the year 2000; 01:34:00 Audience member asks a question [catalogerâ€™s note: audience memberâ€™s question difficult to decipher]; 01:42:06 Recording ends.

description#1: @00:05 Host introduces speakers @3:24 Kizer begins @20:16 Kizer ends @ 20:40 Hartley begins @26:02 White begins and discussion with Kizer and Hartley @35:09 Rosenberg begins @40:19 open for audience @1:28:16 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Margaret Robb. Beginning with readings of modern poetry, the speakers express a sense of loss in the American experience expressing society in tension with idealism. Modern society seems to expect humans to be analytical and temperate in emotions, but the cry of the natural man seeks expression. Differences in older vs. modern poetry include the diversity of poets, who create language with new meanings and interpretations. For example, the speakers discuss several African poets as adherents of the school of "negritude" in modern poetry. Poetry is often comparative, beginning with an observation, then comparison, and then the verse.

subject#2: Indians of North America--Politics and government--United States
description#1: @00:07 host introduces panel and topic @20:15 discussion open to questions from floor @46:30 Flies High begins @56:15 Flies high ends / open panel begins @1:44:01 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Floyd Westerman. The panel discusses the history and consequences of political activity by Indians. They agree that Indians must be fairly represented by a government that provides education, improves the economy, and supports political activity. Speakers suggest that education of Indians will free them of federal controls and allow them to preserve their culture. Issues discussed include fishing rights in western Washington, governance of reservation services, and empowering Indian students during their education.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series VIII: No Art This Year
description#1: Moderated by David L. Paulson. Peter M. Mayer mentions various art forms, how they fail to cause political action, and the possibility of video tapes to change this. Mayer and Roger Ebert discuss the future of books. Ebert lists the various types of political films, with emphasis on Jean-Luc Godard's films. Leonard C. Ball argues that films "mean nothing" and that "the arts have always been politicized." The panelists discuss creating "revolutionary films," how films are geared towards middle-class America, the future of the video tape, and the growing diversity of actors. The panelists have another discussion about Black protagonists in movies and Jean-Luc Godard.

description#1: @00:03 host introduces panel and speaker @3:53 Barthene begins @36:24 Barthene ends / discussion open for audience @50:47 tape ends
description#2: [Reportedly] moderated by James Corbridge [introduced by un-named Latina student]. The speaker [David Barthene, substituting for Hortensia B. Viuda de Allende] describes Chile's struggle for a peaceful transition to a just society. Salvador Allende, the president of Chile, used various tactics to pursue agrarian reforms, eradication of unemployment, and economic improvement by curbing the flow of Chilean wealth to developed nations. Allende presented socialism as a nonviolent alternative to colonialism and imperialism. However, the military opposition still controlled most events in Chile. In response, the speaker claims that the Chilean people fought for liberation around the world and for justice in their homeland.

description#1: Moderated by Blaine E. Mercer. Grace Husted begins by talking about how the interpretation of age and sex is changing so rapidly that it's important to encompass it from a different point of view. Husted talks about sex in terms of gender. Robert Ebert argues how Grace Husted's speech has anything to do with the topic of the panel. Ebert states that regarding politics of sex, a woman has a greater handicap in being elected president than a black man because women aren't trusted by either men or women. Henry Fairlie states his difficulty regarding women's liberation and states that women's liberation doesn't define common humanity.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series X: Sex in the Afternoon
description#1: Moderated by Christopher R. Brauchli. Roger Ebert summarizes the findings of the President's Commission on Obscenity and Pornography. Leonard Gross discusses the Swedish film, I Am Curious (Yellow), and how it exemplifies the idea of releasing frustration through art. Nicholas Von Hoffman argues that pornography has a right to exist and that the purported societal effects that it causes have been blown out of proportion. Liz Carpenter tells various anecdotes and believes that pornography is a form of "pollution."
