description#1: Moderated by Barbara Jones. Samuel Rosenburg begins by talking about how there was a time where pornography had great emotional charge. Rosenburg states how pornography was once a private domain of masculine society and how pornography has now become devaluated because it's no longer private. Roger Ebert talks about how the 20th century drowned down pornography. Ebert explains how porn is a dying field and art. Grace Husted suggests that there is a cultural difference in ascetic and aesthetic directions. Grace talks about how different cultures have different value systems regarding pornography which one shouldn't damage.

titleSeries#1: Series II: The United States: The Largest Third World Country
description#1: Moderated by Leslie Durgin; 05:05 Durgin introduces the panel topic and panelists; 08:00 Nicholas Lemann begins his discussion. He talks about the history of the term â€œunderclass.â€ He states that underclass refers to permanent poverty or those unlikely to ever get out of poverty; 11:30 Lemann talks about the idea of the underclass coming to fruition from the early 1960s. He talks about the inner-city Black ghettos and those trapped in poverty; 13:36 Lemann mentions that the topic is discussed again today because there was a dramatic change in the population of poor people, mostly consisting of elderly women and female headed families; 15:20 Lemann talks about extrinsic and intrinsic forces that contribute to poverty and the underclass; 20:17 Fredrica Gray begins her discussion. She talks about the issues of poverty related to Black women. She compared the income of Black and white families and noticed that Black women were less likely to be married and; therefore, had less income; 25:46 Gray mentions that Black men have had a difficult time in the labor force lately which is why more Black women are also single; 30:52 Jaime Snyder begins his discussion; 32:20 Snyder talks about Lemannâ€™s points about the extrinsic and intrinsic forces; 33:43 Snyder talks about his background and grandpa, Buckminster Fuller. He addresses what has been done and what we can do to help those in poverty; 38:35 Snyder talks about enacting a new type of Homestead Act in Los Angeles because housing prices continue to increase; 40:50 June Golden begins her discussion. She states she does not believe there is poverty or underclass in America and people should be able to get jobs; 42:50 Golden talks about womenâ€™s magazines and raising children; 44:00 Golden talks about her experience living in New York. She sees children on drugs on the street and worries about her own kids interacting with these children; 51:27 Audience member comments that the problem with poverty in America is an institutional problem but the comments from the panel made it sound individualistic; 01:08:07 Audience member asks a question [catalogerâ€™s note: question difficult to decipher]. Panelist talks about mobilizing people; 01:29:39 Audience member asks about a conspiracy theory to destroy black males from white males and talks about the book â€œCountering the Conspiracy to Destroy Black Boysâ€; 01:41:35 Panel discussion ends.

description#1: Moderated by Richard Schwarz. Each of the panelists introduces what they will talk about before returning to the stage. Weeden returns to gives a "personal history" that is meant to resemble an introduction at an AA meeting. Goodheart returns to go into more detail about her ex-husband's alcoholism, her experiences as a therapist, and the effects of having alcoholic parents. Ebert returns to describe what an AA meeting is like, how he became an alcoholic, how being an alcoholic affected his professional life, what it was like growing up in an alcoholic family, and how he became sober.

title#1: Premature Requiem for the Great Society
description#1: Moderated by Charles (Chuck) R. Middleton; 00:00 Middleton introduces the panel; 01:10 S. Douglass Cater begins his discussion; 01:29 Cater states that today is the 40th anniversary of Franklin Delano Rooseveltâ€™s death and makes a connection to the book â€œNineteen Eighty-Fourâ€ by George Orwell; 04:40 Cater talks about the 20th anniversary of the Great Society and The New Deal; 07:25 Cater talks about Murphyâ€™s thesis and the Great Society. He continues to talk about the welfare mentality. Murphy provides a three-point plan; 12:20 Cater talks about his experience working on health and education programs for the Lyndon B. Johnson administration. He talks about how he witnessed a large amount of functional illiteracy and the invisible poor; 14:50 Cater talks about the influence on Washington from the book â€œNight Comes to the Cumberlandâ€ by Harry M. Caudill. He continues to talk about urban poverty from one generation to another; 17:00 Cater talks about his experience writing for a magazine after the Lyndon B. Johnson administration started. He talks about the war on poverty; 25:54 Cater looks at the pros and cons of the Great Society; 29:21 Cater talks about Medicare and Medicaid; 30:46 Cater asks, did income maintenance bring the poor out of poverty or did it contribute to a growing lower class in America? He believes it is still unclear, but the programs did contribute a mindset of the poor and welfare mentality. He also talks about an influx of women entering the workforce and stagflation; 34:12 Cater talks about looking for villains in the political processes and how we should take a closer look at the condition in the 1970s regarding the growth of interest groups. He talks about a divided government and political irresponsibility in the 1970s; 39:27 Cater talks about technology and where our defense dollars will be going; 45:42 Cater finishes his discussion; 46:07 Audience member asks if Cater has any knowledge about Johnson not running in 1968 because of his health, rather than for reasons related to the Vietnam War; 47:07 Panel ends.

title#1: Private Genius and the Public Weal
description#1: Moderated by Eugene H. Wilson. Arthur Barber asks the question: Where do we want to go as a society in the future? He addresses problems oriented to Washington D.C but generalizes his points to apply to all society. He believes creative solutions to domestic problems are the best but does not see them being applied. He urges the US government to create a stronger sense of community through inventive techniques, focusing on the US school system as an example. Via a discussion with the audience he determines how the government should re-allocate funds to support the school system better.

titleSeries#1: Series II: What the Declaration of Independence does not Mention: A Right to Property
description#1: Moderated by Patricia B. Trainer. Roger Ebert begins by talking about why he doesn't agree with the public having the right to know everything. David C. Butterfield points out a few factors regarding the private life of a public person. Butterfield explains why in most cases people are victims of self censorship. Butterfield then questions where the line is drawn in what is legitimately private in the life of a public person. Patricia O'Brien talks about how people are most interested in knowing the sex lives of public people.

description#1: Moderated by John P. Lymberopoulos; 00:00 Recording starts in the middle of a conversation about health care for older adults; 01:45 Shepherd Brooks talks about prenatal care and uninsured people with children who need health care; 04:15 Brooks ends his discussion; 04:30 Christine Davies begins her discussion about the different levels of health care. She continues to say that anyone in a civilized society has a right to basic health care and talks about the limited resources available for life saving measures; 07:58 Christine Davies talks about measures that increase the quality of life and defines what would be considered a right or a privilege depending on the type of procedure needed; 09:36 Christine Davies talks about the basic minimum of health care and what type of ailments people encounter today. She continues to say that people are suffering and many of the illnesses today have been brought on the individual themself therefore questions the right to basic healthcare; 11:25 Joan Higman Davies starts her discussion by stating healthcare is a necessity [catalogerâ€™s note: speaker muffled and difficult to decipher]. Higman Davies continues to talk about the quality of water people deserve to have; 18:50 Higman Davies uses a womanâ€™s situation to compare healthcare costs from private health insurance; 19:53 Lymberopoulos asks the audience if they have any questions. Shepherd Brooks asks if he can respond to Christine Davies comment about the problem of someone with an illness that they brought upon themself and whether the state should have to pay. He continues to quote President George H. W. Bush about health care; 25:12 Christine Davies responds to Shepherd Brooksâ€™ comments by stating there needs to be more preventative medicine in the form of publicity to encourage people from drinking and driving, for example; 26:11 Higman Davies also responds about people smoking and the health care they should receive; 27:49 Shepherd Brooks responds again with a story about a seat belt law and helmet laws; 29:31 Lymberopoulos asks the audience for questions; 29:47 First audience member states they know the struggle of getting a new health care system in place in the United States and offers two suggestions for the panelists to respond to; 37:36 Second audience member asks the panel to explain the difference between the right of society and the right of an individual for health care; 42:38 Lymberopoulos tells the audience to take a break and return at 3:00 PM; 48:55 Lymberopoulos asks the audience if they have any questions for the panel. Third audience member asks about the British health care system and the comparison of cost in Britain and the United States; 52:49 Fourth audience members asks how the health care system considers unemployed people; 01;00:25 Fifth audience member asks how one chooses a primary care physician in Britain and if it is easy to switch; 01:07:37 Sixth audience member comments that people in America should also look at the negative aspects of the Canadian and British health care system so that the United States can make an educated decision when improving their system. She continues to say that all three health care systems have strengths and weaknesses; 01:13:46 Seventh audience member states that there is a problem in the United States for physicians and hospitals to locate in large populated cities so people in rural areas experience more expensive health care. He asks the panel if a government run health care system would impact that; 01:16:10 Christine Davies responds to the audience memberâ€™s question by stating that rural health care is also a problem in Britain. Higman Davies also responds; 01:22:03 Eighth audience member asks Shepherd Brooks about his statement of people in poverty status and states that people in poverty do not have equal healthcare; 01:23:28 Lymberopoulos closes the panel and thanks the audience for being there.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#6: United States. National Aeronautics and Space Administration
description#1: Moderated by E. A. M. Gendreau. Jiri Nehevajsa introduces the topic, then all panelists debate with each other about the extent to which the U.S. government should emphasize scientific or military programs in space. All speakers, some social scientists some military officials, give their opinions on space warfare and what it might mean to "control space". The cold war and role of Russia in space exploration is particularly discussed. The panelists also consider pros and cons of developing military versus scientific space programs. Questions from the audience follow.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by John Major. Victor Isakov discusses a potential future nuclear co-op and the draft treaties on nonproliferation of nuclear weapons. He speaks from the perspective of Russia and compares their policies to those of the United States. Richard Scott speaks on the drafting of a treaty to prevent the continued spread of nuclear weapons and which countries have been active in its development. He discusses cooperation between the governments as a key point in the development of a nonproliferated world. Jerry Page details the recent history of nuclear weapons and the rapid changes that the world has undergone. He questions what the world will look like if proliferation continues. Jacquard Rothschild discusses a United Nations strictly for weapon control to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and promote disarmament. He details what we need to do in order to avoid war.

subject#3: Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (1968 June 12)

description#1: Moderated by Rita Smith. Perdita Huston begins by stating that women as silent victims are no longer an issue. Hustion then talks about how violence is rooted in a long term cultural attitude. Vesna Kesic discusses violence against in women in wars. Kesic talks about how in modern history there is not a single document that sanctions rape as a war crime. Roberta Fahn Schoffman discusses problems women face in Israel. Roger Ebert questions if men are hard wired to be violent. Ebert then states that many men are violent because that is the way they were built.

description#1: Moderated by Robert C. Hanson. Roger Ebert argues that it is the purpose of art to stimulate people, including in prurient ways, and that pornography can be used as a catharsis for society. William Braden states that we should allow pornography in the arts. Zenon Rossides offers his opinion of the definition of art and believes that we should create art that "elevates man."

titleSeries#1: Series III: What is Wrong With the USA
description#1: Moderated by Stephen Foehr. Roger Ebert begins by talking about ethnic jokes and stereotypes. Ebert talks about how in American movies, it is ok to be prejudice against the Arabs, Japanese, and Germans for humor. Robert E. McClendon talks about three incidences that have happened regarding racism. McClendon then talks about the definition of racism. McClendon discusses personal problems he had faced for being black. McClendon ends the panel by explaining the color hierarchy in Thailand and how fear is associated with darkness.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Bruce Henderson. The panel discusses the 2000 American presidential election, and related issues like campaign finance reform and journalism. Mark Hertsgaard begins by arguing that the public discourse in American politics has degenerated over several decades. He links this degeneration to the culture in journalism that has devalued and effectively censored important stories. Molly Ivins continues the discussion by relating her experience covering the 2000 presidential election, including her thoughts on political reform. Dan Odescalchi shares Ivins' optimism that reform is probable, but expresses skepticism about campaign finance reform specifically. Richard Aregood laments the decline of responsible news reporting, especially in the realm of politics.

title#1: Reduction of the Risks of War
description#1: Moderated by Charles Nilon. Alexander Zinchuk discusses different strategies regarding how the U.S. and the Soviet Union can avoid war. Jiri Nehnevajsa explores the issues in trying to reduce the risks of nuclear war and the reasons that would cause it. Stanislaw M. Ulam describes the "layman's view" of the risk of nuclear war. Robert E. Matteson lists possible causes of nuclear war and the agreements (or lack thereof) between the U.S. and Soviet Union regarding nuclear war.

title#1: Religion and Politics: Does it Sell?
description#1: Moderated by Michael Newman. Molly Ivins begins by talking about the conjunction of fundamental religion and politics. Ivins explains why fundamentalism is attractive in the American society at this time. Roger Ebert talks about how a person with the greatest faith has the greatest doubt. Ebert then states three things Â– spontaneity, content, and interaction Â– religious television has that ordinary television usually lacks. Margot Adler talks about how spirituality reality is like the natural world. Christopher Bigsby explains why he doesn't fundamentally understand the United States.

description#1: Moderated by James A. Lavita. The panel discusses how media outlets gather and present news. Adam Hochschild relates personal anecdotes from his time as a reporter and argues that news is often manipulated. Simon Hoggart agrees, and identifies the problem as an overemphasis on facts and a lack of journalistic judgment. Molly Ivins makes the point that most errors are ones of omission, not commission. Audience questions cover unconscious bias, the relationship between the press and the presidency, and journalistic ethics.

description#1: Moderated by Forrest W. Williams. Daniel Ellsberg begins by describing his beginnings with the Rocky Flats Truth Force and the legal battles regarding their petition. He uses the overthrow of the Shah in Iran to illustrate how non-violent protest can be successfully used against powerful enemies. He also discusses the dangers of low-level radiation and the reason why the Rocky Flats Plant poses a health hazard. Then, Ellsberg tells some personal stories from his experiences with the Rocky Flats Truth Force. He also states that nuclear weapons were being produced at Rocky Flats and discusses nuclear war.

description#2: Moderated by Charles Nilon. Joseph Fink states that "the bomb" -- rather than a nuclear weapon -- could be a number of social problems including lack of education, incompetence, or overpopulation. For the first time humanity has changed course from survival to self-destruction. John Migdley discusses a permanent non-proliferation treaty that would prevent all countries from developing nuclear weapons and forbid the five countries that do have nuclear weapons from creating any more. He believes this agreement could only work if the current "nuclear powers" scale down their forces. Charles Nilon refutes some of Migdley's points.

description#1: Moderated by Edward P. Nolan. John Newhouse begins by talking about how SALT is a way in generating some restraint in the strategic arms competition. Newhouse states that SALT would not be possible if both sides were not in some degree of parody. Makins briefly mentions the importance of understanding what SALT really is. Engelbert Washietl emphasizes another aspect Â– European Security Conference Â– of the whole problem. Dolf Doge ends the panel by stating how the psychology of the United States has built up on the image of seeing progress toward the possibility of ending arms race.

description#1: Moderated by Peggy Tague. Patrick M. Morgan begins by talking about the major reasons why SALT is under attack, and the current American political debate and issues in SALT talks. Alexander S. Yereskovsky emphasizes the significance of the treaties and the business going on between the United States and the Soviet Union. Robert Pickus shares his opinion that governments cannot lead to the direction of arms control and disarmament because their first responsibility is to secure society. Felix Moos states that the problem in strategic arms limitation for the Soviet Union and United States is a national perception.

description#1: Moderated by Courtland H. Peterson. Thomas A. Halsted defends SALT II, which would limit further development of strategic nuclear weapons. Halsted begins by presenting a history of SALT, continues into the reasons why people have been opposed to SALT, summarizes what SALT will and will not achieve, and finishes with various viewpoints of SALT.

description#1: Moderated by Patrick M. Woods. Thomas A. Halsted begins by stating that SALT II deals with offensive weapons. Daniel O. Graham states that SALT should be looked at in the context of the number that results on what would really happen if a nuclear war occurs. J. David Singer talks about several criticisms of SALT agreements and mentions that he is in favor of SALT II agreements. Betty Goetz Lall makes six points that has to deal with the SALT agreement. Raymond S. Sleeper points out that there is no arms race and briefly talks about minimum deterrence. Jeremy Stone talks about the effects SALT has caused towards people. Paul Walker provides three possible future SALT legislations. Nancy K. Ramsey ends the panel by questioning what and who national security is.

description#1: Moderated by Theo Volsky, Jr. John Newhouse begins by talking about the dÃ©tente occurring between the United States and the Soviet Union. Newhouse states that the United States and Soviet forces are hard to compare because they are so different. Then, Newhouse advises that in order to achieve the stability that the two nations need, the number of strategic weapons has to be limited and the process of increasing the destructive potential of weapons has to be restrained. Newhouse ends by saying that SALT should be seen as steps of progress which will lead to greater stability.

description#1: Moderated by Chris Burns. William H. Blanchard begins talking about two kinds of pressures Â– honesty and seriousness Â– offered by negotiators in the American culture. Then, Blanchard asks the audience what they think of him. Peter I. Markov begins speaking by stating his opinion towards serious negotiations. Markov states that negotiations not taken seriously fail and he ends his speech by saying both countries will benefit if both sides are sincere and serious. Michael S. March presents numerical data on the United States government budget since the 1950s. Lastly, an unidentified speaker briefly suggests that United States negotiators should take a more realistic view point.

description#1: @00:14 Host introduces speaker @ 00:49 Wilson begins @39:24 Wilson ends @50:47 Tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Stuart M. Takeuchi. Crime around schools has increased due to the presence of gangs and readily-available drugs. Also, changes in family demographics and the accessibility of firearms have resulted in less discipline and moral guidance. Social changes among the poor result in a loss of community, which further inhibits economic and educational opportunity for young adults. Flaws in the justice system also inhibit the rehabilitation of juveniles. Therefore, we should empower social institutions to instill positive values and reduce delinquent behavior. The speaker asks: Are juveniles to blame for increases in violence, or does the failure lie within society itself? Society should strengthen and support families as they try to provide guidance and discipline.

description#1: Moderated by Rita Weiss. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how science fiction has created a sensibility of satire, reverence, rejection of authority, irony, and cynicism. Whitley Streiber states that he is not a science fiction author and explains why he is angry at science fiction. Streiber then talks about why the failure of science fiction is the failure of science. John Gliedman begins by stating that Streiber is totally wrong. Gliedman then briefly talks about science fiction in the 1950s. Charles-Gene McDaniel talks about why he can't stand science fiction novels. McDaniel states that science fiction can be an important instrument for criticism.

description#1: A panel of speakers discuss the role of diplomacy and intervention in foreign policy and decision making. Speakers discuss how transparent the use of secret diplomacy and covert intelligence in policy decisions should be. The panel also discusses when it is appropriate to use military intelligence, and how policy decisions should take intelligence into account. The effectiveness of current policy and the role of the media in dealing with intelligence matters are also discussed.

description#1: Thomas Findley discusses his relationship with Huey Newton as a reporter. He describes how both the Black Panther Party uses the media to create awareness for the movement, and in turn, they are misrepresented in the media. Discusses media's role in creating a "rock star" image for Newton. Expresses a frustration on behalf of reporters' inability to challenge conservative national media, specifically its editors and publishers. Henry Fairlie points out that the role of a journalist is to question those who seek power. Patricia Karvall discusses how the media supports the message. Discusses self-criticism among the press. Last speaker discusses people as transmitters of "symbolic codes." Chairman Thomas D. Bird presiding.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by [Merriam Basa]; 01:08 Timothy Findley starts speaking; 01:50 Findley introduces Huey P. Newton and how he is going to "rap about imperialism"; 02:34 Newton starts speaking; 3:00 Newton takes questions from the audience. The first question is about the Congressional Black Caucus and chairman of the Black Panther Party. Newton states the efforts were successful as far as he knew; 03:43 Findley asks about the electoral politics in the Black Panther Party. He says the party wants people to vote using a registration drive; 06:42 Findley talks about meeting Newton and how the mass media portrays the Black Panthers; 09:48 An audience members asks about factions and how the media portrays them. Newton responds that there are no factions but the more radical Black Panther members are known as "media freaks" because the media focuses on them more; 11:42 Findley asks Newton about how the media views the group as elitist and Newton responds that the group attempts to organize as many victims as possible and their work is in the community because that is where the people are; 14:19 Audience member asks Newton about the registration process for voting. Newton talks about the voting for a "survival ticket" and the campaign is not related to a traditional governement party in American politics; 15:25 Audience member asks about the party supporting Shirley Chisholm; 16:25 Audience member asks a question about the sensationalism with reactionary forces and the media. Newton talks about a report regarding Kathleen Cleaver; 23:12 Audience member follows up with a question about the People's Republic of China. Newton says the party wanted to try to upstage Nixon but the party has always been under the conlusion that the People's Republic is the most advanced society in the world, politcally and culturally speaking; 28:29 Audience member asks Newton about the prisoners in Attica. Newton explains the mission of sending messages about the party, but does not say what the messages were; 31:16 Audience member asks a question about the party's influence and idealogy. Newton talks about the structure of the party and what they supported; 42:58: Newton talks about George Murry and the organization; 44:25 Audience member wants to hear Newton's opinion about the struggle between the inferior group of people and the superior group of people and how the superior group puts on a facade by accepting Black and third world peoples to colleges and universities. Newton talks about how the gun is often used to gain power and how society gains power. Newton also mentions how the mass media and universities are used to frame a culture; 52:40 Previous audience member follows up by stating he was trying to understand the qualitative and quantitative differences in culture. Newton responds with an explanation about the "social strains" that lead to other cultural change and contradictions in society; 01:02:28 Findley interrupts to mention that another session changed locations; 01:02:44 Audience member asks a question about how the liberation movement has an impact on the liberation movement. Newton talks about the women's liberation movement as an example; 01:06:01 Audience member asks Newton about the political awareness of Black people and if the party has intellectual sessions. Newton responds that the party does have political education classes that revolve around the survival programs they take part in such as the free food or free clothing programs; 01:11:00 Newton talks about the bourgeoisie; 01:14:59 Newton goes back to talking about cultures around the world and how African cultures are looking and dressing more Western; 01:21:09 Audience member asks a question about the scientific socialists and technology. Newton talks about Chinese advancements and history. Newton also mentions the transformation theory regarding the Chinese people; 01:33:12 Audience applaudes and finishes with one more question. The question is about the Black Panter Party's position on the school busing program and political education classes. Newton responds by stating the party tutors people on a variety of topics; 01:42:11 Newton responds to the question about the busing program by stating the program only helps with the symptoms of an underlying problem in society; 01:44:48 Findley closes out the session and the audience applaudes.

description#1: Moderated by Cathy Comstock. The panel approaches the question posed by the title of the panel. Sean Kelly is uncomfortable with the title, and suggests that American voting systems may be more stupid than people. Dan Odescalchi argues that people in America have a stake in their government and tend to vote rationally. Simon Hoggart facetiously proposes an elitist scenario resulting in corporations voting in American elections. Joan Higman Davies makes an argument for proportional representation, and Molly Ivins makes a populist argument. During the audience question period, the panelists discuss voting patterns, the electoral college, education, and election strategy.

description#1: Moderated by Kevin M. McMahon; 00:10 Richard Farson is talking about relationships: singles, marriage, divorce, and remarriage; 07:32 Farson says that people just want to be known and be vulnerable with the person; 09:32 Farson stops speaking; 09:45 Michael Stoff begins speaking and takes a poll of who is single, married, or married and wants to be single; 11:08 Stoff talks about the history of being single in America; 16:45 Stoff talks about a film and advertisement about singles; 0:20:49 Stoff discusses that by being single one can discover themselves, so when people get into a relationship it is healthier; 22:17 Stoff stops speaking; 22:31 Roger Ebert begins speaking how their is no time in his life for a meaningful relationship with another person; 24:28 Discusses that his life and other people's lives do not have the time to be in relationship; 24:50 Suggests that people get married in late teens to early twenties to grow with each other. Then discusses people with addiction to drugs or drinking who get into relationships with people with addiction to make a bad relationship. 40:28 Ebert stops speaking; 40:34 Sonya Hamlin begins speaking about her personal life; 45:43 Hamlin says that people should reach out when they are lonely; 50:29 Discusses that it really hurts to involuntarily lose a piece of yourself; 51:13 Hamlin stops speaking; 52:14 Unidentified audience member asks what happened to Ebertâ€™s life that made him stop drinking. Ebert says that he reached out to AA. He then talks about drinkers; 55:33 Unidentified audience member asks how to say no. Hamlin says she felt that she was at a loss after her husband's death. Accepting everything helped her move on and then learned how to say no after. Hamlin learned how to say no because of her female friends. 57:41 Unidentified panelist talks to Hamlin about her time in Paris and says that travelling and eating alone is ok; 01:00:00 Unidentified audience member asks how she finds the balance between love and career. Hamlin says that she had a certain lifestyle so it was perfect for her; 01:06:05 Unidentified panelist says that pregnancies were a fear back then. There is also an age crisis that scares people; 01:08:57 Unidentified panelist says that intimacy takes time; 01:10:28 Unidentified panelist talks about what they look for when they are single. The panelists then talk about what they look for; 01:22:28 Unidentified audience member asks about serial monogamy. Unidentified panelist says that pregnancy and diseases have been a thing for a while and it has not changed; 01:27:13 Unidentified audience member asks whether people change their mind to get married when they swear they would never. Unidentified panelist says that people can change; 01:31:32 Hamlin says that there are many men, but there are only a few men who are perfect for them; 01:36:00 Hamlin says that the beauty standards are annoying, but people change when they find the right person; 01:37:04 Unidentified panelist says that advertisers have been taught to see what they think men like to see. The panelists then discuss the stereotype for women; 01:43:04 Unidentified audience member says that women have imposed things on men to live up to. Unidentified panelist says that men have done the same thing too. People have been doing this for a long time. People have found other things than physical features to be attracted to; 01:46:03 Audience members applaud and discussion ends.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Social Basis of the Radical Right
description#1: The radical sides are not the majority, yet they attempt to move Republicans more to the right because it controls most of the money and votes, which has resulted in success of republicans in general elections. The right fights for religion, patriotism, and freedom; as well as social groups based largely in middle class and rural communities. Even in the early Roosevelt days, the radical right opposed organizational support of society. The speakers argue that the radical right has done all the wrong things to obtain power and expand their voter base.

Then a discussion between the panelists and audience regarding Peter Principle arise. Further questions from the audience follow.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: There is an attempt to construct a communist society with peaceful coexistence, which means recognizing social systems with the right to form a government they desire. Thus, improving relations between socialism and capitalism as well as removing dangerous sources of war. Beginning in 1953, the United States and the USSR have managed a peaceful coexistence with steps toward deduction of military expenditures, ending arms race, and have achieved disarmament as a result of the test ban treaty. Contacts and exchanges between nations have broadened, and the speaker claims that the two countries have every reason to live and work together in peace, with no war and a profound community of interests based on mutual goals.

description#1: Moderated by Thomas Rauch; 00:52 Rauch introduces the panel; 03:00 Samuel Cohen begins his discussion. He states he supports President Reaganâ€™s Strategic Defense Initiative, or Star Wars Program; Cohen believes that Reaganâ€™s claim that the defensive system is â€œleakproofâ€ is absurd. He continues to talk about the testing and how the military planners did not take the real world into account; 06:20 Cohen states the only way we will know how effective the Strategic Defense Initiative system is will be when we have a nuclear war; 06:43 Cohen comments on another claim from Reagan that the defense system is supposed to protect American cities. Cohen also believes that claim to be absurd and unrealistic. He states the claims were a political ploy to win over scientists against the nuclear system; 11:30 Cohen talks about the sole focus from the president was on the Sovietâ€™s threat from their intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs); 15:58 Cohen talks about the best actions we can take right now which is taking on a mainly defensive posture by establishing air and civil defenses; 18:03 John Gliedmean begins his discussion. He states he wants to address the question as to why in the 1980s has a contradictory, nonsensical missile defense system been pushed so hard by the current administration and accepted by the scientific community; 19:24 Gliedmean presents the contradictions of the Star Wars Program. He states the program is a political response about policy making of armaments. He also talks about the basic economy of the United States; 41:37 John Tirman begins his discussion. He states that the moral intent of the Star Wars Program was to implement a defense system rather than retaliate after we have been attacked, but he believes Star Wars will not deliver on its promises to defend American citizens; 42:50 Tirman talks about the technological problems of the program first; 44:16 Tirman talks about the claims made by the Reagan administration that putting up a defense system does not hurt anyone; however, Tirman states that is untrue because the Soviet Union does not perceive the defense program in a passive way. Also, the Soviet Union perceives Star Wars as a first strike capability in national defense; 56:07 First audience member asks Cohen if Star Wars hardware can be made invulnerable to electromagnetic pulses; 57:40 Next audience member asks if the next administration will pick up the Strategic Defense Initiative after the Reagan administration; 01:01:06 Audience member comments that he is dismayed about Cohenâ€™s negative opinions of nuclear war; 01:03:00 Audience member asks about the Russians [catalogerâ€™s note: question difficult to decipher]; 01:14:55 Audience member asks if the panel can comment on Star Wars II as an alternative; 01:18:19 Audience member asks a questions about Russian actions; 01:25:44 Audience member asks about the capability to do missile defense and the technology involved with the system; 01:28:11 Same audience member asks a second question about radiation and a potential nuclear winter; 01:36:10 Audience member asks what loss our nation is willing to sustain from nuclear war; 01:36:53 Audience member asks what a public strategy could be and its limitations; 01:45:12 Audience member asks if the existence of chemical warfare would make Strategic Defense Initiative irrelevant; 01:46:10 Audience member asks Cohen about counteracting attacks from the Soviet Union; 01:48:38 Recording cuts out.

title#1: Star Wars: Its Implications for the United States-Soviet Relations and Alliances
description#1: Moderated by Theo C. Volsky; 00:10 Volsky introduces the panel; 02:00 Jonathan Dean begins his discussion. He talks about the administrationâ€™s program for ballistic missile defense, also known as the Star Wars Program; 03:00 Dean talks about the doubts of ballistic missile defense. He talks about Western defenses from Soviet attack; 04:15 There are three major doubts amongst experts about the Strategic Defense Initiative for ballistic missile defense. First, the feasibility of rapid defense is doubted. Second, skeptics doubt Soviet counter measures. Third, skeptics are concerned over the heightened possibility that in a situation of competition the Soviet Union might considered a preemptive attack; 07:41 Dean talks about the immediate consequences of the missile defense program. He first talks about the United Statesâ€™ NATO allies; 11:24 Dean talks about the European viewpoint if the missile defense program were successful; 13:14 Dean talks about another area of concern being American missile defense would not prove effective and there would be a dangerous increase in Soviet-U.S. tensions; 13:55 Another concern of European governments was the impact of public opinion of a major new controversy over defense; 17:10 Dean states the positive element of the American program includes European participation and research; 22:29 Dean mentions the major problem for the American ballistic missile defense program will be a political one; 25:10 Dean talks about the deploying of American pershing missiles; 29:29 Dean talks about the Soviet Unionâ€™s participation in Geneva talks and the actions they have done with their missiles. He states the missile defense program has decreased any potential willingness for Russians to reduce their missiles; 38:47 Dean asks, â€œwhat can be done here to break this deadlock?â€ between the Russians and U.S. He continues to say that the U.S. should not place too much reliance too early on an untried missile defense technology; therefore, risking the protection the U.S. currently has; 41:40 Dean concludes that the U.S. should aim for an agreement that prohibits the testing or deployment of weapons in space and the testing of defense against tactical nuclear missiles. He continues to list other stipulations about the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty (ABM); 47:40 First audience member asks Dean why take such a negative view towards the Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI or also known as the Star Wars Program); 50:02 Volsky thanks Dean and panel ends.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Stuart Takeuchi. The panel discusses state governance in the United States. Molly Ivins argues that returning power to state governments risks corruption and unfunded mandates. Eric Sterling stresses the importance of an independent judiciary and an organized populace in regulating state government and correcting its mistakes. Tom Potter makes the case for citizen involvement in government at the local and state level. Panel discussion covers the intersection between states' rights and civil rights. Audience questions cover property rights movements, mass transit, campaign finance reform, labor unions, and the death penalty.

subject#2: Interim Agreement Between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on Certain Measures With Respect to the Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms (1972 May 26)
description#1: Moderated by Joseph Lazar. Robert B. Bathurst begins by stating that the United States and the Soviet Union are to a degree neutralized. Bathurst explains what the Soviet Union is doing with their conventional forces. Bathurst ends by questioning whether the United States is going to help countries to be independent within their nuclear umbrella and to provide psychological strength. Questions from the audience follow.

He then briefly talks about the British and French style. Ebert mentions the Studebaker and explains why they are the most beautiful cars. He also explains why no one in America would buy an American car. Ebert ends the panel by talking about laser vision discs.

titleSeries#1: Series X: The Job of Sex
description#1: Moderated by J. Russel McGoodwin. Pepper Schwartz discusses what being a prostitute is like and how this affects typical male-female relationships. Roger Ebert notes that all of the past nominees for Best Actress and Best Supporting Actress had women portraying royalty or whores. Schwartz returns to state that women must find an identity that is in-between the Madonna-whore complex. Sonya Hamlin discusses how her sexual fantasies were ignored by her partner and how creating fantasies is beneficial. The panelists discuss vibrators, long-term relationships, sexual incompatibility, sex counseling, and communication between partners, the purpose of prostitutes, pornography, sadomasochism, and homosexuality.

title#1: Technology and Art: Is It Art?
description#1: David Chamberlain begins by questioning if technology makes better art or less art. David Finkle talks about how theater has become marginalized, and how technology has taken over live theater. Finkle then explains what the microphone has done to live theater. Rob Glaser talks about three issues regarding technology and art. Paul Kolsby states that technology will never melt into art. Kolsby then talks about the differences in technique and technology. Roger Ebert states that all of art and technology are inseparable. Ebert then discusses how technology influences the art that it creates.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by John Carnes. Noel Parrish states that banning nuclear weapons testing would not lead to peace since it would upset the "symmetry" of force which exists between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. Alexander Zinchuk's greatest concern with test bans is the possibility of one nation getting ahead in the arms race and how inspections would be conducted. Donald Michael posits the creation of an anti-missile missile system and argues that China could be stopped from obtaining nuclear weapons. J.P. Morray states that the Soviet Union has tried to establish a test ban with the U.S., but the U.S. has refused to discuss the issue. Parrish returns to discuss the distinction of offensive and defensive weapons, test bans, and China. Zinchuk refutes Parrish.

subject#5: Spraying and dusting residues in agriculture
description#1: Moderated by Edwin Crow. Molly Ivins discusses the current political situation in Texas and shares stories of outlandish political behavior. Michael Stoff explores the transition between old politicians and new politicians, arguing that Texas will be a political barometer for the rest of the country as it transitions to a new form of politics. Tani Adams recounts her work as a chemical activist and the institutionalization of the battle against agrarian pesticides. Whitley Strieber describes the polarization between Texans and Mexican-Americans. He shares stories of his own familyâ€™s role in Texan history and his encounters with politicians.

title#1: The angry, unskilled, unemployed, uncommitted young men
description#1: (tape 1: cwa_65-54) @00.02 Bob Turner introduces Charles Butcher, @2:35 Charles Butcher talks @20:57 Butcher ends @21:22 Bob Turner introduces Leslie Fiedler @22:39 Leslie Fiedler talks @36:55 Fiedler ends @37:33 Bob Turner introduces E. James Lieberman talks @11:45 Lieberman ends @11:56 Bob Turner introduces Jean Kern @13:15 Jean Kern talks @20:20 Kern ends @20:50 Audience Questions
description#2: Charles Butcher, speaking as a conscientious objector, describes three groups of people that represent the population of the United States (while removing articles of clothing) -- 1. college students, dropouts, beatniks, and streakers; 2. "trash" i.e. poor people; 3. "smug-uglies" i.e. the rest of us. He describes the sources of anger of the first two groups, and what each group should do about it. Leslie Fiedler asks if the youth of the United States should be considered an oppressed minority. He speaks of psychological exploitation by groups in power, and the replacement of traditional masculine roles by feminine ones. E. James Lieberman describes adolescence and gives statistics of youth in the United States. He talks about programs that provide useful employment and experience for disadvantaged youth. Jean Kern talks about the frustration of the poor caused by rejection and lack of job opportunity. Chairman Bob Turner presiding.

description#1: Moderated by J. Edward Murray. Daniel O. Graham begins by defining the problem of arms race. David Singer then states the problem of arms race from a different aspect. The panel provides three possible solutions of arms race: first solution from Philip Morrison, second from Betty Goetz Lall, and third from Raymond S. Sleeper. Katherine L. Camp also talks about another solution regarding arms race. Dorthy Gillam Baker discusses the global perspective on nuclear arms race. Thomas A. Halsted talks about problems President Carter faces. Paul Walker talks about what congress should do with respect to the 135 billion dollar budget President Carter has presented. Robert W. Degrasse provides an input on his view towards SALT. Daniel Ellsberg talks about what the average United States citizen should do about arms race.

title#1: The Arms Race: Their View and Ours
description#1: Moderated by Patrick Jobes. Robert Vincent Daniels begins by giving background on attempts to control arms and arms limitation efforts. Daniels briefly talks about the struggles of nuclear and conventional agreement between America and Russia. Club Bateau states that the best solution for disarmament would be to destroy/block not only the bombs, but also the means of delivery. Walter H. Pincus discusses his views towards arms race by saying that the United States approach to disarmament is more of a domestic consideration than an international consideration. Pincus states that any agreement is going to involve chance, and a lack in arms control agreement will only cause a continuation of the arms race.

description#1: Moderated by J. Edward Murray. There are two common methods to avoid nuclear war: avoiding conventional wars and deterrence. Samuel T. Cohen believes the former is impossible since the U.S. would need to be ready to fight "Vietnam-type wars" at all times. He also states that deterrence may not work since the U.S. has no guarantee that their retaliatory forces would sufficiently cripple the Soviet Union. Cohen also mentions that containment is "a dangerous myth" and urges the U.S. to focus on defending itself instead. Cohen concludes with a personal anecdote about meeting various Catholic figures.

titleSeries#1: Series VI: Survival of the Human Race
description#1: Moderated by Antonette Stepanak. Gerald Mason Feigen begins by talking about the atom bomb and discusses some situations involving nuclear weapons that could eventually lead to war. Gerard Gray Grant explains how all forms of nuclear weaponry involve fallout. Grant briefly mentions two moral elements, use of means and use of force. John W. Spanier talks about how disarmament is not feasible. Spanier states that there is no solution to nuclear weapons, and that people just learn to live with problems as best as they can. William von Eggers Doering suggests that the audience should not let the issue of nuclear weapon, power, or waste recede into the background of their active conscious.

title#1: The Brits Look at the Yanks
subject#1: United States--Foreign public opinion, Austrian, [British, etc.]
description#1: Moderated by Kent Zimmerman . Molly Ivins interviews British panelists, soliciting opinions on political and social questions. Early topics include Ireland, speech patterns, and imperialism. Special attention is given to the historical relationship between the United States and the United Kingdom. The panelists strike a lighter note when they compare British and American wine, food, and humor. Coming from several different regions, the panelists compare and discuss accents. A final discussion compares violence in America and England. Audience questions cover the death of Princess Diana, anti-Americanism, and American Anglophilia.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speakers discuss how politics mixes with the notion of thespian with a criterion of our candidate must act depending on the prospective audience. A well qualified candidate must represent the nation, but given the equality of power in the government with massive staff workforce, the work is hardly authentic. Meaning, the media sets up an image and forces others to follow, but the speakers argue that people do know more than they are able to articulate. It's posited that candidates must be thespians in order to convey their ideas, and must take advantage of technology for mass communication.

title#1: The Chessman Case and Capital Punishment
description#1: The speaker gives a brief history of Chessman's life. With a disabled mother and living in poverty, he resorted to burglary and car theft. Marrying in 1940, he divorced a year later and was convicted in 1941 of robbery and assault. In jail he spent his time teaching subjects and debating, only to be caught in 1947 as the red-light bandit, so he was then trialed for 18 charges. This case became a legal-limbo for Chessman who had 8 executions spared out of 9. Thus in this panel capital punishment and abolishment are discussed, including statistics on the pros and cons of the death penalty. Speakers discuss the importance of the deterrent effect, rather than executions.

description#1: Moderated by Laurie McNown. The panel discusses increasing polarization in the American legislature. Michael Franc outlines the legislative strategies employed by the Republican Party in the House of Representatives, which rely on alignment between partisanship and ideology. Molly Ivins decries pork-barrel politics and campaign financing. Tim Wirth attempts to understand Congress in 2003 by tracing the institution's history from the 1960s to the 2000s, concluding that legislative power is becoming centralized. Panel discussion focuses on the conservative Republican approach, while the question and answer session covers health care, money in politics, and potential solutions.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Constitution--The Living Versus the Literal
description#1: The speaker's argument is that increasingly, decisions are being carried out by the Supreme Court and that the executive is becoming only the packager of legislative programs. Also, recently there has been a decline in the role of parties in bringing together factions and compromising in issues such as national security, policies, and the economy. Thus, there has been a rise in individual groups pressuring political agendas through manipulating propaganda, resulting in the decline of power for political parties. This brings with it the concern of editorial power and news filtration. Looking at this issue, suggestions for improvement range from creating a sub-government to having a quota system.

title#1: The Cost and Worth of the Military Industrial Complex
description#1: Moderated by Mary Wolff. Robert McClendon describes the process of producing military equipment and machinery. John Gliedman discusses some of the problems plaguing the world and the U.S., particularly economic scientific issues in the U.S. Gordon Sumner Jr. argues that the military-industrial complex requires "an overhaul" financially and politically, but also points out that the research labs within the military-industrial complex most engage in research that is useful for the general public.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Creative Process: Stimulus and Response
description#1: Creativity is composed of two parts: the creative act and society's response. The creative process has to be distilled from a point of interest, through which society uses languages, art, etc., allowing for communication. This process requires a high degree of specialization to derive truth from different point of views and to retain the importance of the individual in society. The speakers conclude with the causes and results of creativity, improvements for society and individuals, and creativity's ability to change thought patterns and lives.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Christopher J. Busick. The panel takes a multifaceted, humorous approach to discuss the concepts of crises and media coverage. Molly Ivins details several of these crises, including the threats of terrorism, drugs, and illiteracy. She examines the way the media covers these problems and the consequences of that coverage. Jonathan Kwitny tells humorous anecdotes about his experience writing and publishing a book. William Eagleton analyzes different types of crises, focusing on those caused by the government. Michael Elliott discusses the historical role of women in the military. Audience questions cover Margaret Thatcher, the Chadian crisis, and future trends.

title#1: The Crisis in Central America and the Role of Costa Rica
description#1: Moderated by James N. Cambridge; 00:00 Recording starts in the middle of the introduction by the panelist, Carlos Jose Gutierrez. He explains he is going to talk about the situation in Central America and actions from the Reagan administration; 02:12 Gutierrez talks about the three levels of confrontation in Central America. First is the East versus West conflict between the Soviet Union and Cuba against the United States. Second there is a confrontation between Nicaragua and El Salvador and Honduras. Third there are internal struggles in Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala such as gorilla movements; 03:44 Gutierrez talks about the relationship of Costa Rica to the three problems previously mentioned; 04:34 Efforts to settle the South American crisis have been dominated by the Contadora group formed by Panama, Mexico, Venezuela, and Colombia. He talks about the halt of the Contadora in July, 1985 and how Costa Rica attempted to create a peaceful solution and peace plan presented with twelve regulations; 11:30 Gutierrez talks about democracy in Cost Rica and how it is the most developed country of the area; 14:20 Gutierrez believes democracy is getting stronger in Latin America; 15:27 Gutierrez talks about the implementation of the peace plan by the Contadora group and President Oscar Ariasâ€™ peace proposal; 18:06 Gutierrez talks about the resistance from the most conservative groups for the peace plan and allowing communists to participate in elections; 18:52 Gutierrez talks about a kidnapping and failed talks between governments in September, 1985; 20:00 Gutierrez talks about showing independence by not accepting any policies from the United States; 22:58 Gutierrez talks about the 1960s and the relationship between Fidel Castro and the United States; 24:22 Gutierrez talks about important programs that have been implemented in South America to increase a democratic system such as making elections more efficient and human rights issues; 26:50 Gutierrez reflects on what we know now in 1987 versus when Mr. Henry Kissinger wrote a report about the situation in Central America; 29:25 Gutierrez thanks the university for the opportunity to speak and the session ends; 29:50 Cambridge tells the audience that questions can be taken near the dressing room.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Fuller presents the hypothesis that humanity has something that no other creature has: mind. This allows us to discover relationships between ideas rather than having to depend on those ideas by themselves. Because of this, we must be here for some reason: to be problem-solvers for the universe. This has been Fuller's drive for the past several decades. Fuller believes that humanity is in a time of extraordinary crisis. He provides a brief history illustrating the links between power and shipping, from ancient times through Magellan to the founding of the East India Company. He then describes the links from this to Malthus and Darwin, then to Karl Marx, and the roots of the two great theories of capitalism and socialism that now have the capacity to destroy all life on this planet within minutes. Next Fuller describes the variety of forces that affect our lives, most of which we are completely unable to sense directly. From there, Fuller lists the development of materials that humanity has invented to deal with those forces and put them to use for us. He continues by describing the differences between tension and compression. Fuller brings out his tensegrity sphere to illustrate these differences, and spends some time describing how the tensegrity sphere works, and how it relates to his geodesic dome designs. Fuller then relates that in 1970, he realized that the Earth has enough resources to provide an excellent standard of living for all human beings, what that means for politics, wars, etc., and the great challenge of trying to communicate this to everyone. Next, Fuller points out a wide range of logical fallacies that are made by the general public, with a bit of nerdy humor thrown in as well as a detailed exploration of geometry. He then makes some lengthy remarks relating to humanity's place in the universe, given recent advances in standards of living as well as the development of technologies capable of destroying all life on Earth. Chairman Arnold Weber presiding.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Anthony Ripley. Speakers discuss how the media uses personalities to shape our beliefs and devise new sources of information. As the audience, we encounter a cult of personalities, based on a fantasy presented to us -- not based on what they do. Celebrities gain name recognition and fame when the press selects individuals to present to the public. The speakers conclude that the press, through negative publicity, becomes a saleable commodity and no longer functions as a public service. Television becomes a business to sell the most time for money.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Death of Political Parties in America
description#1: Moderated by Doug Costain. The panel discusses the state of political parties in America. Nancy Ramsey covers the evolution of political parties and the emergence of new political parties. Jurek Martin compares the Anglo-Saxon and European political models, and concludes that the American political party system is still strong. Molly Ivins summarizes current Texas political events to demonstrate public dissatisfaction with the political establishment. The panel analyzes open primaries and women voters. Audience questions cover third parties, campaign finance reform, and the religious right.

title#1: The Death of the Planet: Who Cares?
description#1: Moderated by Sandra Hale; 00:00 Recording starts in the middle of a conversation; 00:25 First unidentified panelist talks about ethno-consciousness where we protect culture and the homocentric connection with nature; 03:44 B. F. Backlund begins his discussion; 04:39 Backlund talks about how much Denver and Boulder had changed since the 1940s. He continues to talk about the pollution and highways in the area; 05:48 Backlund states he is appalled by the lack of concern amongst his peers about the environment; 08:23 Backlund talks about [Thomas Schumacher] and his statement about accountability; 09:33 Whitley Strieber talks about the fictional book he wrote called â€œNatureâ€™s Endâ€; 10:47 He talks about learning about the trouble of the ozone layer and how the scientific community knew about it but most other people didnâ€™t know about it at the time. He also mentions that the book sales were good until the Chernobyl disaster happened and then book sales stopped. He concludes that real life was becoming so similar to his fictional book people thought it was terrifying and not entertaining anymore therefore, completely turned away from the subject about the environment; 13:00 Strieber talks about extinction through catastrophic events, the food chain, and planktonic events; 15:48 Strieber talks about a design problem when it comes to humansâ€™ sexual seasonality and activity. He continues to talk about how humans do not have hair on their bodies and big brains; 17:10 Strieber mentions that there is a sense of fault in the media which is why people turn away from the topic of the environment. He also wonders how we manage our presence on the plant to confirm our own survival; 18:48 Strieber talks about the research he has done and what the world is doing about the environment; 27:47 Strieber answers the question â€œwho cares?â€ and believes not everyone cares about the health of the planet; 28:42 Strieber asks an audience member why they were laughing at him during his discussion. The audience member states that many of the things Strieber talked about touched him. Strieber thinks the topic is difficult to face and will be a challenge for future generations to tackle; 30:10 Next unidentified panelist begins her discussion. She talks about the image of a man in Denver; 31:20 Panelist talks about the design flaw we have as humans, being a short memory and the fact that we are unable to perceive the changes that happen around us on a long-term scale. She continues to talk about the population increase that we donâ€™t recognize; 32:50 Panelist mentions she sees the environmental problems as a religious and political problem; 37:57 Panelist talks about how diversity is good for the planet such as lots of species. She continues to talk about Paganism; 41:44 Panelist says we need tools to help us where our memory fails us so that we donâ€™t run into the death of the planet; 42:35 Hale asks the audience for questions; 42:48 First audience member states that everyone in the room is probably at least a little interested in what can be done to help the environment and asks what humans can do on a smaller scale that will make an impact. He continues to ask about the system of justice and injustice on the planet and who profits from it; 54:20 Unidentified person talks about New York City and homelessness; 55:16 Unidentified person changes the topic to science programs in the world; 59:28 Audience member mentions a film about the water in Colorado; 01:00:30 Unidentified person talks about how we as individuals have a lot to learn about ourselves and awareness of where we are regarding environmental problems; 01:03:48 Unidentified panelist talks about the death wish of humanity; 01:06:26 Unidentified person talks about major events that were important ten years ago versus what needs to be implemented today in regards to the environment; 01:12:03 Audience member talks about investigating the problem of the environment; 01:15:05 Unidentified person talks about a point Strieber mentioned and continues to say that people need to â€œlight a fireâ€ under the scientific community and politicians so that more is done; 01:26:30 Hale stops the discussion and the audience applauds.

title#1: The Department of Defense on the Defensive
description#1: Moderated by Eugene H. Wilson. Edward P. Morgan argues that there isn't a military-industrial complex, but a "military-industrial-political complex" that has come under fire. Some of the criticisms of this proposed complex include political biases that influence government funding, the misappropriation of government funding for military expenditures, and gross underestimates of the military budget.

description#1: Moderated by Berkley M. Sterling. Sam Rosenberg states that current movies "offend him," citing that current movies feature too much nudity and there are fewer pictures worth seeing. Hayden V. White lists some rules regarding types of movies to avoid. Roger Ebert argues that new movies are simply "a new way of doing an old thing" and explains some film conventions and how they are changing. The panelists discuss how the pace of movies is increasing, the difference between watching a movie on television and in the cinema, their interpretation of the title of the panel, and the five worst movies of 1969.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Dani Newsum. Lael Segall begins by questioning where civil society came from. Segall then makes an assumption that the features of civil society may have been prescribed by a particular culture in a particular time in history. David Finkle explains how there is some form of integration in society when there is disintegration. Finkle then states how civilization has found a way to put a break on the disintegration of humanity. Finkle briefly talks about how fear makes the world go round. Roger Ebert explains how tribalism is the biggest social disease in the world today. Ebert then discusses how most of the people who are against abortion are women.

description#1: Moderated by Jean Delaney; 00:03 Jean Delaney starts speaking. Introduces Myrdene Anderson, Sidney Kramer, Claudio Spies, and Karl Pribram; 03:01 Delaney stops speaking; 03:02 Myrdene Anderson explains why creativity is important; 04:35 Talks about the three Câ€™s: craziness, creativity, and criminality. 16:08 Anderson says that creativity can surpass constraints; 17:00 Anderson stops speaking; 17:13 Sidney Kramer begins speaking about two rabbis; 18:47 Kramer says that there is a relationship between creativity and depression; 0:23:56 Discusses the Warren Commission or Warren Report and what creativity is; 24:30 Kramer stops speaking; 34:35 Claudio Spies begins speaking that the word creativity is abusive and talks about imagination. Talks about how people are more creative in other areas; 32:16 Spies discusses game playing; 37:32 Spies stops speaking; 37:42 Karl Pribram begins speaking about the brain and the systems that deal with creativity; 45:47 Pribram discusses that difference between familiarization and innovation. Unidentified panelist agrees; 01:16:19 Unidentified panelist says that creating a composition cannot be done with a foggy head because it is extremely intellectual; 01:20:16 Unidentified panelist discusses that when they create something they just know it's done when it feels right; 01:24:05 Unidentified panelist discusses that space time and a spectrum of frequencies are related to each other; 01:32:44 Unidentified audience member asks if the body has anything to do with creativity. titleSeries#1: Series XII: How many days for NATO
description#1: Moderated by Vincent W. Beach. John Midgley covers Dulles's ideas about war with the Soviet Union and the historical role of NATO. Gordon P. Savill states that the U.S. will probably choose to not escalate the conflict if the Soviet Union attacked Western Europe, which concerns Charles de Gaulle. Berndt von Staden argues that, in the past, the Soviet Union was willing to take greater risks, but that is not the case now. This change in Soviet policy should be used to further attempts at disarmament. Kenneth B. A. Scott outlines strategies for Western Europe in the event of war with the Soviet Union.

description#1: Moderated by James R. Carrigan; 00:14 Recording starts in the middle of a conversation by panelist, David Little about the ethics of nuclear weapons and testing. Little continues to talk about the just war theory and combatant and noncombatant war; 4:30 Little talks about counterforce; 06:09 Little talks about the book â€œCommon Securityâ€ and mentions he agrees with the authors of the book when they say nuclear weapons are not war-fighting weapons; 08:40 Little asks â€œis there an operable moral distinction between the use of nuclear weapons and their deterrence value?â€; 11:56 Little talks about creating a system of common security and arms reduction but believes we are faced with a moral dilemma such as using the â€œnecessity excuseâ€; 17:00 Little states that deterrence strategy and just war theory is morally wrong; 19:11 Little talks about the book â€œDeadly Gambitsâ€ written by Strobe Talbott; 22:25 Little expands on the broader implicated of necessity to use or keep nuclear bombs. He continues to talk about three restrictions related to necessity such as supreme emergency or threat; 28:37 Little talks about morality and foreign policy in respect to nuclear arms; 31:24 Little finishes his discussion and Carrigan asks the audience for questions; 31:54 First audience member points out the danger of applying necessity, especially in other countries with less of a democracy where anyone can make any excuse to use bombs. The same audience member also asks about deterrence in the form of nuclear weapons when countries could use purely defensive nonnuclear weapons instead; 36:50 Same audience member replies to Littleâ€™s response; 39:00 Second audience member makes a statement regarding the Japanese in internment camps and human rights through the use of war. He continues to state that we should eliminate war â€“ not just the bombs in war; 41:06 Third audience member talks about political systems of the world and mentions Dharma; 43:20 Little responds to the second audience memberâ€™s statement about the imprisonment of the Japanese and eliminating war. 47:28 Fourth audience member asks if itâ€™s more exciting to read about war getting out of hand in history books; 48:36 Fifth audience member asks how an individual such as Little decides what particular technology or event is so immoral he is willing to risk his career over his strong opinions; 51:50 Sixth audience member asks about imposing necessity; 54:34 Seventh audience member asks what circumstances Little would be in to be willing to kill; 55:48 Eighth audience member asks if any important people have suggested a total world-wide nuclear disarmament with weapon destruction teams; 58:15 Third audience member chimes in [catalogerâ€™s note: audience member difficult to decipher.]; 58:37 Carrigan and Little thank the audience for their questions and the discussion ends.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The External Relations of the People's Republic of China
description#1: @00:05 host introduces speaker @3:03 Mehta begins @47:20 Mehta ends / open to discussion and questions @55:43 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Stanislaw Ulam. The speaker claims that past judgments of China have erroneously focused on a drift between the Soviet Union and China. He states that faulty views of China emphasize a Maoist variant of Marxism, interested only in its own security. He suggests that China seeks links between her traditions and her new revolutionary ideologies; thus other nations should clarify their policies toward China. Her policies seem to be based on solidarity with the developing world, growth of external trade, securing governmental controls, the drive to industrialize, and the rubrics of Marxism and Leninism. China's relations appear pragmatic, and its interests in the world should not be dismissed.

description#1: Moderated by Arnold R. Weber; 00:28 Weber introduces the panel and speaker; 04:15 Eugene J. Carroll, Jr. begins his discussion. He talks about the rift between President Ronald Reagan and the British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher; 05:35 Carroll talks about the failure of nuclear deterrence from the viewpoint of a military man. He also provides some optimistic views for the future later in the panel; 08:45 Carroll reads from a passage written by Richard Pearl, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Global Strategic Affairs. Carroll continues to talk about fear in the nuclear arms race; 10:38 Carroll reads a passage from General John Vessey. Vessey stated that both the U.S. and Soviet Union were over armed; 12:40 Carroll talks about a study that was done to determine how many weapons would be needed to deter a nuclear war. He states 400 weapons would be needed to destroy the Soviet Union and the U.S.; 14:00 Carroll talks about Reaganâ€™s policy on peace through power and strength. He continues to talk about all of the weapons we are developing; 18:30 Carroll states that he thinks we will have a nuclear war during the 20th century if things continue the way they are; 19:20 Carroll talks about a concept of mutual security and arms control measures; 25:30 Carroll talks about the nation state system based on absolute sovereignty. He offers a solution to the problem of sovereignty; 27:43 Carroll talks about President Eisenhowerâ€™s practical steps for moving towards international order and mutual security; 33:10 Carroll ends his discussion and takes questions from the audience; 33:48 Audience member asks about the fact that the Soviet Union is not willing to change power; 36:18 Audience member asks about the consumption of natural energy resources to gain world order; 37:00 Audience member asks how small of an accident it would take to set off a nuclear war; 40:17 Audience member asks whether the Soviet Unionâ€™s technology is a step behind the U.S. and asks about verification procedures; 42:37 Audience member asks about fear and the reduction of nuclear weapons. Carroll talks about arrangements the U.S. could do to achieve this; 46:21 Audience member thanks Carroll for his work with the Center for Defense Information (CDI) and asks Carroll about the broken agreements from the Russians; 49:50 Audience member asks how we can sacrifice our national sovereignty to an international authority for the preservation of peace; 51:21 Audience member asks about ultimatums presented to the Russians from the U.S.; 53:00 Audience member asks about Carroll â€˜s opinion on the nuclear [bill down?] policy; 53:36 Audience member asks how the U.S. will get the Russians to share their power when we have so many problems sharing our own power with minorities in the U.S.; 54:50 Audience member asks what people can do to convince its leaders that we want an agreement made; 56:32 Audience member asks what is behind the mutual buildup; 58:59 Carroll ends his discussion; 59:10 Weber thanks Carroll.
