title#1: The Fight for Freedom in South Africa
description#1: Moderated by James R. Scarritt; 00:00 Panelist, Tsietsi Mashinini starts by saying hi to the audience and states he is talking about communism; 01:55 Recording cuts out and starts in the middle of another conversation. Mashinini is talking about the call from communists for the fall of Johannesburg; Mashinini tells a story about a Black man living in a tent in South Africa in 1652. He continues to say that a white, European man came to South Africa and kept asking for more and more from the Black man until he took over the rights and land of Black people in South Africa; 06:17 Mashinini states that white people have been tricking marginalized groups for centuries and continues to say that in order for white people to maintain a system of power in South Africa they will need a number of things. He begins by talking about cheap labor. He talks about the passbook, also called the â€œbook of life,â€ invented by white people in Johannesburg which was another form of identity. The book contained polaroid photographs and native identity numbers. The book stipulated where certain people were permitted to work and go to school throughout Johannesburg; 13:01 Mashinini talks about the four types of education in South Africa. He also talks about how unqualified the teachers are in South Africa; 15:30 Mashinini then talks about the architecture, streets, and railroads in Johannesburg. He explains he does not understand the technology and lifestyle of white men. He continues to talk about the gold that is extracted by the white man in South Africa and either exported to America or dug back into a hole in a bank; 18:40 Mashinini talks about the Black man who had to work in mines to earn a wage below the official poverty line of which he sent back to his wife in rural areas. He continues to talk about a culture of people destroyed by the exploitation of labor; 20:00 Mashinini talks about the population of Johannesburg. He also goes into more detail about the subjects students must learn in school. He mentions some of the courses were taught in Afrikaans and others were taught in English; 23:00 Mashinini talks about the Soweto Uprising that occurred on June 16th 1976. He states him and 20,000 black students demonstrated in the streets. The people that started the rioting were the police; 26:38 Mashinini comments that South Africa is a beautiful place and wonders why people talk against South Africa. He continues to talk about the victims from the Soweto Uprising; 28:32 Mashinini tells a story about a little boy that stole a car and was sent to jail and died. He states that since the uprising until the day of the panel, in 1977, more than 8,000 people had died in the hands of the police; 30:30 Mashinini talks about the policies put into place by white people to maintain black resistance in South Africa. He talks about the Suppression of Communism Act; 32:00 Mashinini talks about detention at John Vorster Square; 38:44 Mashinini reads a poem by a South African student exiled in Botswana; 39:30 Mashinini changes the conversation to talk about students in America as well as American government and the foreign policy of the United States government. He talks about Henry Kissinger; 41:56 Mashinini talks about Vietnam and the Western press which sways the minds of Americans. He also talks about the need for Americans to better understand and fight against communism; 46:37 Mashinini admits that America is a sick country and asks the audience if they agree. He continues to talk about the links between the racist regime in South Africa and the American corporations and government; 49:19 Mashinini states the United States government only benefits from profit and mentions that Jimmy Carter called for more corporations in South Africa to put economic pressure on the racist regime there, but Mashinini admits that Black people have not died there because they wanted an 80% increase in economic gain but because they wanted total liberation of the Black man; 51:39 Mashinini asks the students to bring back the sickness that was sent to South Africa, meaning the corporations. He tells them to go back to their communities and teach people about the genocide happening in South Africa and start a movement; 54:36 Mashinini reads the audience a poem that he wrote called [Bluesing In]; 57:39 Scarritt tells the audience that there will be an opportunity to ask questions; 58:33 Audience member asks about the relationship between the United States, Israel and South Africa; 59:33 Next audience member tells Mashinini that he disagrees about his statement that profits being made in South Africa stem from communism, and rather stem from American imperialism; 01:00:11 Audience member asks why Mashinini does not get his organization armed; 01:01:17 Audience member asks if there has been any liberation done by the whites in South Africa; 01:02:52 Audience member states that strikes can achieve a just system over armed groups; 01:05:42 Audience member asks Mashinini to provide more information about what the â€puppets in government have done.â€ She asks for positive examples before imperialism occurred; 01:07:01 Audience member asks if the paper that students have to sign when they are detained, which labels them as communist, is a paper from the South African government; 01:10:34 Audience member states he is from Mexico and expresses solidarity for the liberation of the people in South Africa. He continues to say the people of Latin America have been oppressed by the same people in South Africa and the root of that oppression is imperialism; 01:11:59 Audience member asks if Mashinini can elaborate on a specific situation and how the Western press misinterprets the situation; 01:14:15 Audience member asks Mashinini how he envisions the new state that will come with the revolution; 01:16:10 Audience member asks how much gorilla warfare is going on in South Africa; 01:17:35 Audience member states he is an Iranian student and agrees with the South African revolution; 01:19:23 Audience member asks what the position of the white South African will be after an arms struggle and revolution; 01:24:12 Last audience member asks about the efficiency of the special branch of the South African government and how it will organize internally or externally; 01:24:55 Tsietsi Mashinini thanks the audience for their questions.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The First Amendment: Right to Speak or the Press of America's Right to Know
description#1: Moderated by Michael Tracy. The panel explores the relationship between the First Amendment and the Press. Richard Aregood discusses the historical roots of freedom of speech and describes attempts to limit speech throughout the history of the United States. Jonathan Kwitny argues that the concentrated ownership of the media has resulted in a restricted flow of information; he provides several personal anecdotes of media corruption. Simon Hoggart discusses how newspapers cater to their audience, claiming there is a lack of reporting on atrocities in the world because Americans do not want to read sad news. Gene McDaniel emphasizes the fact that freedom of speech belongs to citizens and not just the press. He maintains that we have to fight for our right for freedom of speech as well as our right to know what is going on in the world.

title#1: The Fortieth Anniversary of the Atomic Bombing of Hiroshima
description#1: Moderated by Joseph Geiger. Michael B. Stoff begins by briefly explaining the city of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. He then talks about the effects of the bomb, "little boy" and "fat man", in detail. He presents numerical data on the deaths that occurred due to the bomb. Stoff then presents a historical melodrama in four acts Â– Act 1: The Decision to Build the Bomb, Act 2: The Decision to Use the Bomb, Act 3: The Decision to Keep the Atomic Secret, Act 4: Hiroshima and the Holocaust Â– to see how the bomb set the past and shaped the future.

description#1: Moderated by De Von Carlson; 00:30 Carlson begins with an introduction of the panel; 03:00 Buckminster Fuller begins his discussion; 04:30 He talks about his experience in 1932 when he realized he needed to do the opposite of what society taught him to do and believe; 10:40 Fuller talks about the principles of being human. He continues to talk about the stars and planets in the night sky and how humans used light to record time and the seasons; 15:20 Fuller talks about calculating capability. He uses an example of Johannes Kepler calculating planetary motion. He also talks about Galileo Galilei and Isaac Newton; 27:00 Fuller talks about scientific generalizations and uses examples from former scientistsâ€™ experiments; 31:00 Fuller talks about the term â€œsynergyâ€ and talks about the behavior of the whole systems; 37:00 Fuller talks about Darwinâ€™s principles and early human beings. He uses an example of horses to explain his concept. He continues to say that divide and conquer is a power structure that has always been around; 43:20 Fuller tells a story about the American Association of the Advancement of Science in Philadelphia; 46:00 Fuller talks about the development of human beings and extinction; 51:12 Fuller tells a story about his birth in 1895 and early technology. He also talks about the massive amount of illiterate people versus literate people when he was younger; 56:45 Fuller talks about his first job as a skilled man before World War I. He states that the people he worked with had small vocabularies. He also talks about the first broadcast of a human voice over the radio; 59:37 Audio briefly cuts out and comes back. Fuller is talking about the television and light; 01:01:00 Fuller tells a story about meeting with a graduating class at the University California Berkley in 1966 and how the students looked back at their own lives. They mention when televisions came into their lives and suddenly you could get information from all over the world; 02:02:38 Recording cuts out.

description#1: @1:37 Ebert begins @14:00 Fairlie begins @20:00 Rosenberg begins @35:54 panel discussion @1:03:19 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Kerry Pataki. The panel discusses the various forms of X-rated films, including "stag films", "adult" films, and "skin flicks", which are rated X by the MPAA. The Immoral Mr. Teas (1959) was the first skin-flick in the American repertoire. The discussion attempts to describe the function of these films, their purpose, and the dangers they might present to American society. Speakers believe that these films tend to lack good filmmaking. These experiences matter especially to young adults, whose profound curiosity for the naked body renders the films irresistible. However, the speakers all agree that the X-rated film will eventually self-destruct because after viewing it, two human beings still have to communicate with each other, with or without sex.

titleSeries#1: Series XIII: Europe: Rapacki or Dulles
description#1: Moderated by John B. Schoolland; 00:00 Schoolland introduces the panel and panelists; 02:00 Horst Osterheld begins his discussion; 02:37 Osterheld first talks about the reunification of Germany. He talks about friends and relatives that live in the eastern part of Germany; 04:06 Osterheld talks about the number of refugees from East Germany to West Germany. He continues to talk about the standard of living and land that is given up by West Germans every time an East German crosses the border; 06:32 Osterheld also talks about how Germany must become a loyal alliance member of the Western world and NATO. He continues to talk about stipulations of a proposed peace treaty; 11:40 Osterheld talks about characteristics of the peace treaty; 14:30 Osterheld mentions that Berlin is the best city for refugees because of its manufacturing capabilities and location of the city; 22:26 Osterheld talks about another proposal that involved relocating the United Nations headquarters to Berlin; 31:35 Schoolland thanks Osterheld and asks Sidney Giffen to begin his discussion; 32:40 Giffen brings up two points regarding the crisis in Germany. First, he talks about a problem of force and fortitude regarding Berlin in East Germany; 36:46 Giffen talks about his second point regarding Russian control. He says the Russians stated they would make Berlin a free city; 38:20 Giffen talks about the combination of political and military factors in the situation; 45:29 David Ketel begins his discussion. He talks about his experience when talking about the German crisis with another colleague in Washington. He continues to say that the Russians need to be watched over in East Germany; 48:24 Ketel talks about the differences between the educational experience of students in America versus communist countries. He mentions that the ability to have free thought and question things in America is great, but that freedom comes at a cost; 49:56 Leslie Glass begins his discussion. He mentions that he agrees with the other panelistsâ€™ viewpoints regarding NATO. He continues to add a British point of view to the conversation; 51:32 Glass states that Britain absolutely wants to protect Berlin and West Germany and Britain is not making any concessions to the Russians; 55:00 Glass mentions that the true leader of the West is America. He continues to talk about [Mr. Macmillan?] and his diplomatic trip in Russia; 01:01:00 Glass talks about some of the negotiations with the Russians. He hopes to be able to reduce tensions without concessions; 01:02:55 Pierre Landy begins his discussion about the Berlin crisis; 01:04:37 Landy mentions that he had lunch with the Russians where Nikita Khrushchev stated Russia canâ€™t stand Berlin and that there is a class struggle in Berlin; 01:06:00 Landy talks about why France is so supportive of the situation in Germany after the Germans treated France so terribly during World War II; 01:13:16 Schoolland thanks the speakers and the panelists clarify some of their statements; 01:14:53 Audience member asks two questions about the Russians blocking Berlin and why have the Russians proposed an altitude limitation; 01:19:19 Audience member asks if there is a possibility that Khrushchev built the Berlin Wall to distract us from the Middle East; 01:19:41 Audience member asks if war is still a possibility in Germany; 01:20:20 Audience member asks if there is a possibility that Russians will pull out of East Berlin; 01:23:30 Audience member asks about the negotiations between the Russians and the allies. He also asks if anything the Russians conceded to would be a gain to them; 01:24:57 Audience members asks Landy for a prediction regarding the arms race; 01:28:15 Schoolland ends the discussion.

Morgan agrees with Hartley, adding that ABM is simply "part of the problem." Robert Goulard mentions the secrecy of the government regarding armament.

titleSeries#1: Series XIV: Arms and the Man
description#1: Moderated by Norman A. Hilmar. Robert B. Bathurst begins by talking about what is wrong with military war machine as a representation of itself and society, and how it could be fixed. Bathurst compares the similarity of the military system between the United States and the Soviet Union. Franklin talks about how the United States government does have a global strategy. Then, Franklin mentions the Vietnam War, and the reasoning behind why the United States lost. Gennady I. Fedosov talks about Bathurst's comparison between the United States and Soviet Union more in depth. Fedosov also describes the complexity of the problem the two nations face regarding disarmament.

title#1: The Historic Roots and Current Aspects of the Civil War in El Salvador
description#1: Moderated by Thomas Mayer; 00:00 Recording starts in the middle of the introduction by Mayer; 01:40 Victor Rubio starts his discussion. He talks about the threshold of the liberation movement in El Salvador and the obstacles still in place by the United States state department and military; 3:30 Rubio talks about his experience growing up in El Salvador and the poverty there; 05:17 Rubio explains that it is important to understand the economic and political processes put in place in El Salvador to understand why people are fighting the system; 05:40 Rubio talks about an event that happened in 1881 that initiated the current oligarchs. The rise of coffee harvesting caused the beginning of the marginalization of the major population that lived in rural areas in El Salvador. Rubio also mentions the investment of Britain and United States markets; 09:00 Rubio talks about the overthrow of President Arturo Araujo Fajardo by Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez in 1931. Rubio continues to say this event was the beginning of the 50 years of struggle and dictatorships in El Salvador; 12:00 Rubio talks about increased manufacturing investments from U.S. firms in the 1950s-1970s as well as increased oppression and economic injustices; 13:02 Rubio talks about the â€œelectionsâ€ the military would hold but were fraudulent; 14:00 Rubio talks about the groups, unions, and organizations that have appeared throughout the country as a result of the oppression; 15:20 Rubio talks about the formation of the Democratic Revolutionary Front (Frente DemocrÃ¡tico Revolucionario, FDR); 16:56 Rubio talks about the current Revolutionary Government Junta regime that started in 1979; 21:00 Rubio states that Ronald Reagan believes the current Junta is a centrist government. Rubio reads through the crimes the Junta has committed and disputes Reaganâ€™s claims; 28:20 Rubio talks about the reforms the Junta is trying to undertake. He starts with land reform (Decree 153) in 1980; 33:45 Rubio talks about phase two of the reform; 36:32 Rubio talks about Reaganâ€™s claims that Cuba and the Soviet Union instigate the insurrections in El Salvador; 43:15 Rubio mentions that the people of El Salvador want the world to know that they are fighting because they want to gain their own national independence and that it is not the place other world governments to impose their positions. 44:00 Rubio goes over the tasks and revolutions of the Democratic Revolutionary Front (FDR); 51:49 Rubio ends his discussion and the audience applauds.

description#1: Moderated by John Williams. Michael Stoff presents a history of the "atomic age," and begins with a letter Albert Einstein sent to President Roosevelt about the possibility of the Nazis creating an atomic bomb. Stoff discusses actions during WWII that lead to the Cold War, including the actions of General Leslie Groves, the distrust between Russia and the U.S., the viewpoints of various scientists on using the bomb, and Truman's handling of the bomb. Warren Broderick explores how the atomic bomb influenced scientific communities and governments worldwide by comparing the atomic age and the space age.

title#1: The Legacy of Star Wars: The Force is With Us
description#1: Moderated by Daniel Sher. Andy Ihnatko begins by talking about the Star Wars opening crawl. Ihnatko then talks about Star Wars in detail. Paula Pesman discusses why Star Wars is a familiar film drama people could relate to. Pesman then talks about the legacy Star Wars has left, such as the visual effects. Pesman explains how Star Wars found a way to introduce religion and faith to children. Jeff talks about whether "the force is still with us," then discusses what the "force" is. Roger Ebert talks about the making of Star Wars. Ebert also questions what the "force" is and states that the force is extremely shallow and meaningless. Rodion Nahapetov talks about the impact Star Wars had in Russia.

description#1: Moderated by Rose-Marie G. Oster; 00:00 Oster introduces the panelist; 01:00 Peter Davison begins his discussion. He states the theme of the reading is called â€œThe Life of Thingsâ€; 01:20 First, Davison reads a short poem called [â€œThe Pletersâ€?] related to Philip Morrisonâ€™s plenary address regarding disarmament titled â€œThe Price of Defense: A New Strategy for Military Spendingâ€; 04:00 Davison talks about the poems he has written in the last few years; 04:45 Davison also reads a poem called â€œElsewhere in Coloradoâ€ about the World Affairs Conference in Boulder; 06:48 Davison reads a poem titled â€œDoorsâ€ that he wrote regarding his childhood home in Colorado; 09:42 Davison reads one more Colorado related poem called â€œMagpieâ€; 11:08 Davison talks about the notion of the life of things and reads a poem; 13:13 Davison talks about the collection of things and tells a story about a guy that collects beer cans. He continues to read a poem related to the collector; 15:16 Davison reads a poem called â€œThe Diamond Pipeâ€ and talks about a vein of diamonds in the ground and mining; 17:39 The next poem read is called â€œStumpsâ€; 19:20 Next poem read is called â€œGroundâ€; 20:50 Davison reads a poem called â€œInto the Futureâ€ about a dark, political time; 21:55 Next poem read is titled â€œDance of the Hours for Itâ€™s a Livingâ€ about working; 23:33 Next poem read is called â€œHeadstoneâ€ regarding the Great Ridge; 25:53 Davison mentions that all the poems read so far were old poems already published in books. He continues to say he is now going to read new poems. He reads the next poem called â€œBarn Feverâ€; 34:40 Davison reads another poem called â€œJanuary 1977â€ about the farm; 36:12 Davison reads the next two poems. The first poem is called â€œThe Ram Beneath the Barnâ€ and the second poem is called â€œMy Lady the Lakeâ€; 39:03 Davison reads the next poem called â€œUntuned Stringâ€ about his family piano. He was hoping a pianist named Lucas would hear his poem; 41:47 Davisonâ€™s next poem was inspired by John Cheeverâ€™s novel titled â€œFalconerâ€ and the Falconer State Prison. The title of Davisonâ€™s poem is â€œIl Se Sauveâ€ which is a French phrase for â€œhe escapesâ€; 44:20 Davison reads a poem called â€œParadise as a Gardenâ€; 46:40 Davison reads his final poem titled â€œThe Sound of Wings.â€ He mentions the poem is written in four tenses; 49:57 Davison finishes his poetry reading and the audience applauds.

description#1: The speaker explains the processes of presidency and public rule. Including questioning by public poll, the period of primaries, and lastly, the convention. Validity of arguments by critics results in measurements of a presidency whether or not a candidate has the capacity to be able to organize support, manage publicity, and keep ambition and goals for higher achievement. Cater concludes his session by expounding on the presidential use of power, and characteristics of leadership.

title#1: The Military Establishment: Its Impact on American Society
description#1: Moderated by William E. Briggs. Adam Yarmolinsky begins by talking about the relevance/irrelevance of the military establishment in the United States. He states that the size and pervasiveness of the American military establishment have tended to obscure the questions of its relevance. Yarmolinsky questions how something so big like the military can be relevant, and to what purpose. He also states his opinion that nonnuclear forces are relevant in some way to national security but are irrelevant to internal problems of other nations. Yarmolinsky ends his speech by exhorting the audience to broaden their views about what is really relevant to our national needs.

title#1: The Military Industrial Simplex: No Feedback
description#1: Moderated by Lawrence G. Weiss. Joseph Kraft begins by stating the aspects of military industrial complex that makes it look like a pure force for advocacy. Kraft mentions that the military industrial complex isn't all that big in the United States and states that it's a political reason for why it looks potent. Scott Payne starts by agreeing with Kraft and extends some of the remarks he made about the military industrial complex Â– absence of countervailing forces, appeal to patriotism for more money, and large share of federal budget. Reginald Duwarem states the differences in military in France compared to the United States and mentions that military in France are a nationalized industry.

description#1: @00:19 Bob Jacobs introduces Robert Moog @1:58 Moog begins @41:00 Moog ends @42:02 open for question among discussants (Kizer, White and Rosenberg) @1:01:52 opens for audience @1:22:42 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Robert B. Jacobs. To Bob Moog, electronic music is a medium of musical expression. Electronic music results from the "generating of sound material", as well as the control of sound, its storage and recording. He explains the creation of composition through parameters of pitch, amplitude and timbre. Using a synthesizer, Moog demonstrates variations in sound as pure pitch vs. pure noise (e.g., white noise), as transient variations, and through filtering to modify tone color. In composition, he emphasizes the importance of the distribution of sounds as an expression for electronic expression. The variations of sounds are enhanced by modern materials and technology, demonstrating the relation between computers and electronic music.

description#1: Dr. Bruner states that western culture is faced with a crisis of values and he argues that foreign policies reflect our values. He explains the crisis in the nature of myths, ideals of society, the nature of the universe, and man; also, explaining the relation of myths to human condition and the intellectual community, in search for identity. Economic well being and adjusted happiness must be equal among strong and weak nations, which in turn increases communication for the myth of self. Bruner states that we must be ready to look at revolutionary challenge in creating conceptions of man and nature through all aspects of economic and political power.

description#1: Moderated by Michael C. Ehlers. The panel discusses how and why American media neglect some current events. Charles-Gene McDaniel examines journalistic business practices to help explain why some stories are not covered. Lee Allen argues that the media are manipulated by public relations firms, and cites several examples of poor journalism. Molly Ivins discusses the media's errors of omission. Arturo Arias uses the example of Guatemalan history to analyze the American media's approach to international stories. Judy Jackson shows a film about human rights violations in Brazil. Panelist discussion and audience questions examine television journalism, veterans' affairs, consumer behavior, and paranoia.

description#1: Moderated by Philip L. Krauth. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how only a part of the new age is a con game. Ebert briefly compares magicians and spiritualists. Chip Howells talks about two appealing aspects of what is leaked into the new age: traditional spiritual notions and the powerful new scientific discoveries. Myra Pearson discusses why she doesn't have anything positive to say about the new age. Mark Kramer explains why he thinks the new age is paradoxical. Kramer then talks about how new age language is a use of some special ecological opportunity that language presents.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speaker explains the goals of the new constitution (1954) of Pakistan after the failure of the old (1947). It is estimated that the failure of old constitution was due to lack of proper elections, leadership, and undue interference by head of state. Whereas, the new constitution focuses on social reform and economic development, in which the system separates power between the executive and legislative branches of government. There will be a division of power amongst the executive, legislative, judiciary in attempt to foster national unity as well as solve future conflicts over issues such as: elections, budget proposals, change in amendments, and citizen equality.

description#1: Moderated by Jack H. Crouch, Buckminster Fuller defines the terms "synergy" (where the whole is greater than the sum of the parts) and "energy" (the actions of the individual parts). Fuller explains how synergy is an important concept, drawing on examples from chemistry, the human body, the educational system in the US, geometry, and pattern recognition. Finally, he states how synergy can be applied in engineering and architecture.

title#1: The Peace Corps, Food and Skills--Tools for Development
description#1: Rather than debating power and policies, the differences between the two systems, communism and democracy, are discussed. The capabilities of free systems includes providing sympathetic understanding, moral support, and material aide to developing nations. Herein it is posited that citizens should be able to enjoy a minimum standard of living by improving primitive economies. With freedom results peace; thus, leading nations must share resources and skills for others to solve own issues. Understanding the difference of communist and democratic philosophies will allow for a stable democracy, starting at a local level.

description#1: Moderated by John Dunn. Marcus Cohn begins by talking about how the problem of pornography is related to the past. Cohn points out a few concerns in newspapers/magazines regarding pornography. Roger Ebert talks about how pornography is not cinematic but violence is. Ebert explains that pornography of violence and pornography of sex are related in the sense that they provide jolts, chills, or thrills to the audience watching it. Cosmo Campoli talks about taking sex to a high spiritual state where women are more like a temple rather than something that is disgraced.

description#1: Chaired by Beverly Sears. This panel explores religious fundamentalism around the world and seeks to discover motivations, causes, and long term effects of this zealous religious movement. Jonathan Broder discusses fundamentalist religion in the Middle East and recounts a brief history of the area to explain the emergence of fundamentalist terrorists. Molly Ivins describes American fundamentalism, and provides reasons and motivations behind this religious movement. Sally Fay explores the power of fundamentalism and the place of social issues in religious fervor.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speakers discuss the tasks of members in the press, and what they report in the news, such as the Washington Post. There are various techniques with which the government and those in executive positions use to communicate with the people, primarily: press conferences and releases of information communicated to the public. There are informal sessions in which such are debated; however, the speakers argue that all people have the right to know what is going on but not the right to participate in the deliberations. This is where the press' job comes in, because they depict what occurs in the deliberations

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Jennifer Heath. This panel discusses flaws and problems in the field of journalism, particularly issues in producing marketable content that is also factually correct. Molly Ivins reflects on the history of journalism and claims that omission in journalism results from attempts to reduce complex stories to two sided conflicts. Peter Pringle acknowledges corruption and the inward focus of journalists and discusses problems in British journalism. Lee Allen maintains that a free press and flow of information is what contributes to the success of the world; he explores the difficulties of crafting marketable news for a wide audience. Francois Xavier Lovat shares his anger with the mechanisms of journalism and recounts stories of his struggle for justice in journalism.

description#1: Moderated by Storm Bull. Thomas Brimelow outlines the history of the Red Army in the Soviet Union, particularly Stalin's attempt to establish political control over the Red Army. G. Deane Davis discusses the military-industrial complex in the U.S. Brimelow returns to speculate what the military-industrial complex is like in the Soviet Union. Alex Campbell compares the military-industrial complex in the U.S. and the Soviet Union, but also states that they share some similar components which he calls the "research-and-development complex." Brimelow responds to Campbell's thoughts about the Soviet military-industrial complex. Davis goes into the history of the U.S. Air Force and industry. [Tape cuts off before Davis finishes.]

description#1: Moderated by Robert M. Hunter. Robert J. Low begins by explaining what he thinks the panel is about. Low states that there are two elements regarding the panel: the right to know and the right of privacy. Low suggests that the issue lies on the right of the press to know what's going on in the counsel's government. Peter M. Mayer mentions that the issues back then were not the same as now; the issue didn't have to do with the press but rather deals with the right to know as a citizen. Mayer then briefly talks about the Army McCarthy Hearings.

title#1: The Rise and Fall of Intellectual Movie-Going
description#1: Moderated by Maria C. Westkott. David Finkle begins by talking about how intellectual movie-going can be two things: intellectuals going to movies and/or people going to intellectual movies. Finkle discusses how there is no fall in intellectual movies since there are intellectual people still making movies. Roger Ebert explains what intellectual film and intellectual film going experience is. Ebert talks about three things that make movies more realistic. Annie Brody discusses the Hollywood standard of film making. Brody states why film going experiences need to be more meaningful and valuable as a cultural product. Judy Jackson briefly talks about documentary film making.

title#1: The Role of Smart Weapons in Non-Nuclear Forces
description#1: Moderated by Lloyd Weber. Philip Morrison begins by talking about how technology plays an important role in security issues. Morrison explains how large expenses in vehicles which remain extensive become more extensive. Raymond S. Sleeper talks about how warfare affects social conditions. Sleeper explains how social conditions developing around the world are within the people's influence. Sleeper then talks about model situations between the two conflicting systems. David Singer talks about how both the United States and Soviet Union are complex industrial societies with different kinds of interest groups.

title#1: The Role of Sound Radio and Serious Writing
description#1: Moderated by Paul Danish. Laurie Taylor begins by talking about the decline in American radio drama and documentary. Taylor questions what has happened to the American radio. Maureen Buunyan talks about four areas where she has a connection with the radio. Buunyan also talks about her experience on television news and states that people who watch television are only watching and not listening. Lee Allen talks about a few observations on radio from a different aspect. Allen discusses the importance in radio outside the United States. Roger Ebert talks about how the radio could leave so much imagination and how sound create pictures in peoples mind.

title#1: The Role of the Artist in the Future
description#1: Moderated by Alden Megrew; 00:08 Megrew begins by stating that Louise Nevelson could not make the panel discussion and Bella Schaeffer will talk in her place. He continues to introduce the panel and topic; 02:15 Bella Schaeffer begins her discussion by stating she wants to consider all creative artists since there is an interrelationship between all mediums of art. She also talks about technology and the advancement of industry. She hopes the economic conditions of the artist will not have problems in the future; 03:36 Schaeffer continues to talk about the artist in the industry; 04:12 [Paul Thomas] begins his discussion. He starts by talking about architecture and the architect in the future. He also mentions the future of industry and the architect; 06:30 Thomas talks about the technology used today for architecture. He mentions that buildings are constructed by computer; 07:48 Thomas also talks about more teamwork in architecture. He worries that group ideas will be a problem in the future; 08:22 Thomas also talks about the bigger architects versus the smaller architects. He mentions that the big architects become businessmen to keep clients while the smaller architects are the more skilled architects; 09:40 Thomas talks about the arts in general. He is sad to see so much talent used in industry and advertising. He thinks there is an alienation between art from life. He talks about the trends he sees in his graduate school with students wanting to make a cultural center that can accommodate many arts; 14:30 Malcom Bradbury begins his discussion. He talks about the people who live closely to artistic values; 15:55 Bradbury mentions he is interested in the literary artist. He also talks about the literary intellectual; 17:40 Bradbury talks about the difference in literary history between England and the United States. He also talks about the alienation of the American writer; 22:44 Bradbury talks about an active creative instinct for the future and artists will have to adapt to technology in the future. He proposes the creation of a new kind of artist for the future; 24:18 Richard Schlatter begins his discussion. He admits he does not know that much about the topic but agrees with what Mr. Bradbury said; 25:32 Schlatter mentions that Americans do not quite know where the artist fits in in American society. He talks about the entertainment provided by the artist in American culture; 27:18 Schlatter asks the other panelists about the role of the artist in the university and academic art; 30:00 Bradbury responds to Schlatterâ€™s question first about the student as an artist; 03:28 Thomas also mentions that there is a problem with the artist on the campus. He relates it to the architecture student and staff; 36:29 Schaeffer changes the topic back to the role of the artist in the future. She talks about conformity in a materialistic world; 39:26 First audience member asks Schaeffer what type of situation would be needed to produce the angry young man; 47:00 Audience member asks Bradbury if there is a correlation between experimentation and indignation; 50:26 Audience member asks about the artist retiring to the university; 56:22 Audience member asks about the potential for communication using technology; 01:00:28 Audience member asks about the writer, J. D. Salinger; 01:01:45 Audience member asks about the future of music; 01:05:18 Audience member makes a follow up comment about music; 01:06:20 Audience member asks about a need for artists to record immediate human experience; 01:08:06 Audience member asks a question about music and experimentation; 01:09:03 Audience member asks how much art is in architecture today versus engineering; 01:12:40 Audience member states that most modern art contains crap and talks about the use of computers in art; 01:14:15 Audience member asks about young geniuses and the need to learn the tools; 01:15:58 Audience member asks about culture to produce good art and whether American artists are at a disadvantage because the United States has less limitations in society than other countries; 01:23:50 Audience member asks about the creative writing class; 01:24:40 Megrew ends the session.

description#1: Moderated by Forrest Williams. Marya Mannes begins by talking about how young audiences were laughing during a rape scene in the movie Clockwork Orange. Marya expresses her distaste in such a happy response to violence. Marya then states how frequent use of violence in films is a conscious rape against the sensibility of what's left in the audience. Robert Ebert agrees with Mannes regarding Clockwork Orange and briefly talks about violence in films and critics. Then a discussion between Mannes and Ebert starts with Mannes talking about how criticism isn't just confined to films. Mannes asks Ebert if French films use violence in the extent Americans do.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: United Nations as a Changing System
description#1: The discussion explains the function of the United Nations secretary general, needed when extreme fluctuations and changes occur due to tension of the world. The secretariat is comprised of the secretary general, who is the chief administrative officer of organization and is appointed by the UN general assembly. The General's role is to harmonize and strengthen international relations and actions. For the future, the secretariat might look at defining the rule of power in nations, and presenting in specifics what they are in favor for.

description#1: Moderated by Thomas D. Bird. H. Bruce Franklin begins by talking about the two most violent events in human history caused by the United States. Franklin suggests that in order to deal with violence historically, one has to look at the root causes of violence that took place within a society. Russell Baker talks about how acts of terror are instantly communicated with all worlds through the media. H. Bruce Franklin talks about terrorism as a phenomenon in the 20th century. Franklin states that the most sensationalized acts of terrorism are from the acts committed by the state.

subject#3: Treaty Banning Nuclear Weapon Tests in the Atmosphere, in Outer Space and Under Water (1963 August 5)
description#1: Moderated by Jack H. Gore. Robert C. Brictson lists some of the key features necessary for a successful arms control. Vadim Loginov outlines the Soviet Union's position on arms control. Leslie C. Green argues that arms control is impractical because, historically, arms control could only be established with weapons that were outdated at the current time. Dr. Bran states his "layman's view" on arms control. [(Some portions of this recording are partially indecipherable. These portions are indicated by asterisks in the SegmentSequence section.)

description#2: Moderated by Dusty Blades (James N. Corbridge, presiding). All panelists begin the session with a satirical performance of British newscast. Martin then criticizes the current state of the British monarchy as becoming too much like celebrities and unnecessary for the British people. The rest of the panelists agree with Martin in criticizing the functions and publicity of the British royal family. All panelists speak in a humorous tone. Questions from the audience both criticize and support the panelists' positions.

description#1: Professor Taylor spoke about the crisis on college campuses and student unrest. The students are agents of change who represent the character and needs of the society in which they find themselves. He compared student movements in America and Europe and spoke to what the universities can do to provide a university experience which will enable the students to recognize their potential. Chairman Courtland Peterson presiding.

description#1: Moderated by Georgiana Colville. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how the trend towards teenage movies is over. Ebert then discusses two types of teenage movies: dead teenager movies and horny teenager movies. Molly Ivins states that there are other kinds of films aimed towards young people other than the ones Ebert has mentioned. Johnn Mendel briefly states how people are getting a better shot at film. Habibullah Tegey talks about how the video cassette machine is not only affecting the present market of the movie, but also the social changes and social relations in American society.

description#1: Moderated by Norman J. Michaels. William Simon states that the relationship between the mainstream and the underground has become less distinct over time since the mainstream is able to incorporate the underground faster and the underground has become more homogenous. Stanley Forster Reed argues that free press does not exist in America because it derives too much funding from various corporations. The panelists discuss the impossibility of objectivity in reporting and technology in the counterculture.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Upper Crust Doesn't Know what is Going on Below
description#1: Moderated by David M. Armstrong. Molly Ivins argues that, during the Reagan administration, economic classes in America are becoming more stratified and segregated as a result of public policy decisions. Ivins uses statistics and demographic information to make the point that the middle class is shrinking while the lower class grows. She also explores why poor people seem to be ignored by the media and the American public. Both Barry Newman and Sally Fay respond that the Reagan administration has not caused the problem, and that upward mobility still exists in America. Audience questions cover political solutions, international comparison, and further discussion of Ronald Reagan.

description#2: Adam Yarmolinsky speaks about the analogy between the Vietnam War and the War on Poverty as a long struggle against tyranny. Both seem to be a long way away. He describes the War on Poverty as largely an opportunity to prepare for, get, and hold a decent job. We, as a nation, have the wealth to eliminate poverty. He cites examples of successful programs in the War on Poverty in the United States. He talks about monetary and debt management policies, and mobility and communication techniques. Chairman E. Robert Turner presiding.

title#1: The Whore with the Heart of Gold
titleSeries#1: Series V: The Mythology of the American Experience
description#1: Moderated by Curt R. Zimansky. Jennifer James begins by defining prostitution in terms of the American society. James explains four main aspects of prostitution: cash, promiscuity, relationship, and subtlety. James also talks about the appropriate use of criminal law. Timothy L. Findley talks about the differences between prostitution and whoring, professionalism and non-professionalism. Nat Lehrman talks about how there should be no arrests for crimes without victims. Lehrman also comments on James's definition of promiscuity with another definition. Roger Ebert talks about legalization of prostitution and questions James if she opposes prostitution all together.

title#1: Time for a New Cruasde Against All Fanatics
description#1: Moderated by Dalene Beaver. Roger Ebert begins by recalling his first exposure to the concept of equality in Catholic school, exploring the increasing tribalism in the U.S., the various minority groups in the U.S. who feel they have been wronged in some way, and the decrease of open-mindedness of the U.S. educational system. George S. Harris discusses various types of fanaticism in the U.S. and across the globe and urges for moderation. Robert E. McClendon discusses the history of Armenia and how its people insist on perpetuating a religious war without thought to their own wellbeing.

description#2: Ambassador Chow Shu-Kai speaks about China's difficulties in changing from an ancient society to a modern state. He focuses on the current difficulties in China under Mao Zedong and the Communist Party and the abuses of the Cultural Revolution. He closes by describing his hopes for the future of China without Communism and the assistance that the United States can give in achieving that end. Chairman Warner Imig presiding.

title#1: Toward the Brink: The Middle East
description#1: Moderated by William E. Briggs; 00:00 Briggs introduces William R. Polk and the panel; 00:36 Polk begins his discussion. 01:50 He starts by talking about the background of the current situation in the Middle East. Polk also points out recurrent problems; 03:09 Polk goes over three contemporary issues including nationalism, conception of justice, and security in the Middle East; 06:00 Polk talks about the Arabs and a movement of national identification. He then goes over the three contemporary issues again; 08:54 Polk talks about the interference of the British in the Middle East. He then mentions the United Nations; 10:53 Polk talks about actions taken by the United States. He mentions that the U.S. disregarded the three issues previously discussed; 11:39 Polk says the first thing the United States did in the Middle East was engineer a cease fire, then attempted to gain electricity in the area using the Jordan River, which failed, and then attempted to create a Works Progress Administration so Palestinians could get jobs; 13:25 Polk talks about the Cold War and its impact on the Middle East; 18:00 Polk talks about further war in 1973; 20:40 Polk talks about Secretary Henry Kissingerâ€™s shuttle diplomacy and his step-by-step approach; 23:50 Polk talks about three options America had when trying to instill peace with Anwar Sadat and the Middle East; 28:35 Polk talks about issues with the Palestinians; 30:35 Polk talks about his predictions for the future of the Middle East. He believes there will be permanent war if peace is not found; 34:00 Polk mentions people must constantly reevaluate the issue of nationalism, conception of justice, and security; 35:15 Audience member asks what lessons of history could be applied to the current situation in the Middle East; 37:23 Audience member asks about the relationship between the Jordanians and Palestinians; 40:15 Audience member asks Polk to expand on the difference between the Christian community and political structures in Lebanon; 43:34 Audience member asks whether Saudi Arabia will take a more active role in the near future; 44:05 Audience member asks about a third option Sadata had; 45:10 Audience member asks Polk whether he believes if Sadatâ€™s economic position in Egypt had been better would he not have gone to Israel at the time; 45:51 Audience member asks if there would still be a war in the Middle East if Americans and Russians did not get involved; 46:07 Audience member asks about the role of the United Nations in the Middle East; 47:08 Panel ends.

description#1: Moderated by Michael Newman. This panel explores the cultural impact of the game Trivial Pursuit and itâ€™s representation of the current â€˜yuppieâ€™ generation. Mark Kramer argues that Trivial Pursuit advocates a homogenization of knowledge and equates â€˜trivialâ€™ pop culture facts to more important pieces of information. Bill Weeden ponders the definition of trivial; claiming that what is trivial and what is important is a matter of perspective. Molly Ivins explores the social status, cultural bias, and culture gap in our society that is showcased by Trivial Pursuit. James Jackson maintains that we are always taught to not do trivial things, but many upper class activities (such as sailing) are trivial.

title#1: TV: The Man With The Power Saw
description#1: Moderated by Albert Smith. Roger Ebert argues that seeing a movie on a screen is superior to watching it on the television. Norman I. Gelman believes that the radio and movies provide better entertainment and news than the television and lists some of the benefits of television. James Stokely proposes that society should attempt to improve the quality of programming on television. The panelists discuss the inferiority of television.

titleSeries#1: Series X: Is Art Saying Anything to Anyone
description#1: Moderated by Harold D. Kelling. William McPherson begins by making some distinctions regarding the tyranny of the critics by talking about current works, not works of the past. McPherson also makes another distinction about critics and reviewers, and states that he is a reviewer. Leslie Kopit talks about a problem regarding critics and a problem regarding criticism. Kopit then states that critics are not necessarily experts. William Braden explains why there is adverse criticism by book reviewers and also explains how a book gets reviewed. Steven A. Linn shows the audience some slides of his own sculpture.

description#1: Moderated by Eugene Wilson; 00:10 Wilson introduces Brian Urquhart and the panel topic; 01:32 Urquhart begins his discussion. He talks about the last time he landed in a helicopter in the Congo; 02:30 Urquhart talks about the phrase U.N.C.L.E. and how disturbed he was with the title of the panel. He reflects on a situation in North Africa in 1941. He also mentions that he asked NBC what the term U.N.C.L.E meant and they stated it meant United Network Command for Law Enforcement and that it was a fake organization, or had been discontinued; 05:12 Urquhart talks about the vision for nonviolence in relation to U.N.C.L.E.; 06:32 Urquhart states he will talk about the desire for security and the United Nations for the duration of the session; 07:00 Urquhart states that the United Nations will survive as long as it keeps peace. He continues to talk about the â€œeconomic and social delusionâ€ often talked about in England; 09:17 Urquhart talks about where the world is now when keeping the peace. He states the world is in the same position as it was even before there was a strong agency to enforce the law. He continues to say there is a lack of system that continues to make life insecure for people; 11:29 Where are we on peacemaking? Urquhart states that the United Nations manages to keep peacekeeping functions. There are more than 100 disputes in the world that are diplomatically negotiated or organized peacefully through the United Nations; 12:30 Urquhart talks about the unresolved problems of the world such as Germany, Vietnam and Korea being divided into two countries and mentions these situations are where the United Nations is ineffective; 13:32 Urquhart talks about the nuclear balance and situations that are bigger than the United Nations. He talks about the lack of a system regarding disarmament and how that causes a lot of insecurity for people around the world; 17:20 Urquhart asks how the world could get to some sort of stability, law and order regarding nuclear arms. He starts with Article 19 of the Charter of the United Nations about financial contributions and budgets to the United Nations; 20:37 Urquhart talks about sovereignty and the lack of sovereignty in the United Nations. The United Nations works on consensus and negotiation; 23:25 Urquhart mentions that we have a weak basis for how much gets done and how much international cooperation there is; 25:28 Urquhart mentions that there are countries with a desire to avoid conflict or to stay neutral during conflict; 28:28 Urquhart talks about the obstacle of slow growth in the world even though the world wants change towards world order. He talks about the things we need to change or get rid of in order to move forward; 32:26 Urquhart asks if it will take another world war to enact change because people typically do not like institutional change until there is a disaster; 36:19 Urquhart states the world does have the communication and means towards world order, but wonders if it is actually possible for man to make a positive effort to secure the future before it is too late; 37:00 Urquhart finishes his discussion; 37:37 Wilson thanks Urquhart for his contribution to the Conference of World Affairs and ends the session.

description#1: Moderated by Alan Shapley. J. David Singer begins by stating that both the United States and the Soviet Union doesn't have a global strategy. Philip Morrison states that strategic doctrine is largely a rationalization of complex political process with many non-analyzable inputs. Raymond S. Sleeper talks about how America thinks strategy comprises only warfare. William Epstein explains how global strategy is not solely military strategy, but military strategy is the most important element of any global strategy. Anne H. Cahn ends the panel by informing the audience to write to the congress/senate to have SALT III ratified.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: U.S.Ã‚â€“Vietnam Relations After the Lifting of the Embargo
description#1: Moderated by Philip Distefano. Speaker, and first secretary to the UN delegation from Vietnam Vu Khac Nhu discusses the normalization of the relationship between Vietnam and the United States. He gives this talk as a forerunner to the opening of the Vietnamese embassy in Washington D.C. Vu Khac Nhu reviews the historical and practical reasons that normalization of relations has been delayed, such as the Vietnam war, MIA's, and frozen assets on both sides. He makes the case for a stronger relationship between the United States and Vietnam, such as business, trade, and travel rights for Vietnamese Americans.

description#1: [Original moderator, George W. Zinke did not make it to this panel. New moderatorâ€™s name is unidentified.]; 00:00 Moderator introduces the panel; 01:14 Mulford Sibley begins his discussion. He talks about unilateral disarmament and how it would require a radical change in attitude; 02:26 Sibley mentions that we need non-violent talks although it is not enough. We would also need a radical reorientation of the economic system to bridge the gap between over developed and under developed countries; 05:20 Sibley states that a program of disarmament would need to appeal to people as well as governments, meaning military matters must be made available to people. He continues to say that this program could lead to a race of disarmament, rather than armament; 10:20 Noel Parrish begins his discussion; 11:45 Parrish talks about the perception of wars before World War II and that all wars were aggressive and everyone involved were at fault. He states the wars could have been avoided using diplomatic maneuvers; 13:40 Parrish talks about the belief of developing undeveloped countries. He states that he does not believe this is the road to peace; 16:00 Parrish states that if we were to renounce violence we would have to give up everything we earned by using violence; 20:02 Jerry Page begins his discussion. He states he agrees with Sibley with one exception. He states the exception is that there is no such thing as a military solution to worldâ€™s problems; 20:43 Page also states he believes the United States has already renounced violence. He continues to talk about the word â€œdeterrenceâ€; 25:13 Cord Meyer Jr. begins his discussion. 25:45 Meyer states that to avoid nuclear war we must step out of it; 27:00 Meyer states he could not live under Soviet rule and talks about Hungary as an example. He continues to talk about the effective advocacy of unliteral disarmament; 29:10 S. Grover Rich begins his discussion. He talks about the nature of man himself and how much man would need to change to get to disarmament; 30:00 Rich discusses how men have been able to live peacefully; 33:18 Rich states that in order to get rid of this problem we need to institutionalize the use of violence through government; 34:19 Cecil Hinshaw begins his discussion; 35:19 Hinshaw talks about important key points that need to be made about evil existing in the world; 36:36 Hinshaw also talks about the revolution in Hungary during November, 1956. He continues to talk about using nonviolent resistance in relation to the Hungarian Revolution; 41:28 Recording cuts out and ends.

title#1: United States Military Forces: Requirements for NATO
description#1: Moderated by Reuben Zubrow. Christopher J. Makins discusses the history of U.S. public opinion on U.S. military involvement in world affairs and gives his opinion on the current situation. Hans von Klutz explains the European view on NATO. Mr. Walker provides some statistics on U.S. and European forces. Ian Soutar discusses Soviet involvement in world affairs and the actions NATO has taken. Katherine L. Camp comments on the growth of the U.S. military budget and the cost of NATO to member countries. Raymond S. Sleeper compares the U.S. military force with that of the Soviet Union.

title#1: United States Policy in World War III
description#1: Moderated by Leslie Fishman. Caryl Conner is the interviewer for a mock Presidential Debate. Charles Butcher is playing the Peace Party Presidential Candidate. Arlo Tatum is the Democratic-Republican Coalition Presidential Candidate. Questions include topics such as the Vietnam War, rising Communist governments, the national debt, admitting China to the UN, overpopulation, biological and nuclear warfare, foreign aid, building an anti-missile system, and cooperating with the U.S.S.R. in space exploration. In the end, Tatum is "elected."

description#1: Moderated by Leslie Eaon. The panel explores the correlation between high priced food and upper class consumers. John Brown discusses the gastronomical tour of the world now available in American restaurants and explores the prestige of cuisine. Molly Ivins recounts food horror stories of the Midwest and argues that food as a marker of prestige will not last long because it is not conspicuous enough. William Eagleton shares his food related stories as a Middle Eastern diplomat and the varying cultural norms and customs surrounding food. Andrew Neil discusses foodies in Britain and shares excerpts from a book entitled Are You a Foodie?

description#1: Moderated by Robert Lewis. The panelists begin by addressing Robert Lewis's concerns about how yuppies are portrayed in the media. Peter Tauber explains how the 60s generation became yuppies as well as the contradictory values of being a yuppie. Molly Ivins describes being along the "periphery" of the yuppie generation. Annette Goodheart notes that ridiculing yuppies shows society's distress about materialism and nuclear annihilation. Roger Ebert believes that there is nothing wrong with consumerism and focusing on the self. The panelists discuss whether the yuppies are still missing something, bodybuilders, the 60s, sexuality, movies, drugs, and the productivity of yuppies.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Molly Ivins. The panel examines the concepts of verification and intelligence related to nuclear arms limitation treaties, specifically the strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979. Coming from several different perspectives, the panelists discuss the difficulties in determining the size and capabilities of the Soviet nuclear arsenal. Katherine Camp provides political context, followed by Daniel Graham's in-depth analysis of the diplomatic and strategic landscape. Thomas Halsted makes the distinction between verification for treaty purposes and intelligence for national security purposes. Marvin Leibstone shares the other panelistsâ€™ concerns about the difficulties of verification, while questioning the end result of strategic arms limitation treaties.

description#1: Moderated by Laura Marshall. Roger Ebert begins by talking about why there are not a lot of Hollywood movies about families. Ebert then states that families are not taken seriously in American films. Kathryn Olney talks about her search for the perfect crossover movie. Charles-Gene McDaniel explains why he blames the decline of good manners on television. McDaniel then discusses how Hollywood has not caught up with the rest of the world in depicting different races and sexual orientations in films.

description#1: Moderated by Alice Reich. Hayden White begins by talking about how violence is regarded as a necessary condition for the transformation of society. White explains why violence in the media is socially less revolutionary than pornography. Lonny Myers explains what violence does to people and morality in terms of the media. Roger Ebert talks about the esthetics of violence and the ethical nature of violent content in the media. Ebert then answers a question on why violence is more cinematic than sex. Melvin Howards talks about how there can be two types of violence, the verbal and the nonverbal type.

description#1: Moderated by Larry Baccus. Roger Ebert notes that movies have become increasingly violent over the years, and although he states that is a fan of certain violent movies, he does not approve of "movies that excite through the exploitation of bloodshed." Alisdair Clayre believes that violence in the media has led to a more violent society since the media emphasizes "violence without the rule of law" and that this generation needs to "rediscover" lawful violence. Lamar T. Empey offers some demographic information about crime and victimization in urban areas.

title#1: Violence is Sex; Sex is Violence
description#1: Moderated by Philippe Almeras. Edwin Casebeer begins by talking about the similarities of violence and sex. Casebeer then talks about why death and love doesn't have a lot to do with sex and violence. Larry Horton talks about the issues of civil liberty in the media. Horton states his opinion on why problems of violence are much more troubling than problems of sex in film. Jane Howard explains why people confuse violence with strength. Roger Ebert talks about violence and sex in movies, and explains why violence is more cinematic than sex.

description#1: Professor Taylor begins by describing America as two countries; one black and one white. He then moves on to the failures of the Vietnam War. His last target is the shortcomings of U.S. colleges. Throughout this talk Taylor points out the similarities between the young and restless all over the world. The talk ends with a call to the young to begin a revolution. Chairman Stanislaw Ulam presiding.

description#2: Moderated by James N. Corbridge. The speaker discusses the differences between the U.S. and Europe from the 18th to 20th centuries, using examples of clothing, language, beliefs, and various roles between Europe and this 'free country'. America exerts its influence in the supermarket (as a symbol of consumer society), as well as in clothing, mass production, and automobiles. These concepts are accompanied by ideas for which the young are responsible, such as influencing speech throughout the world and triggering liberation movements worldwide. Americans tend to reduce society to pieces to see how it works, in the belief that we can rebuild and reshape society.

titleSeries#1: Series VI: The Nixonization of the Nation
description#1: @00:14 host introduces panel @4:16 Midgley begins @22:49 Herzstein begins @39:15 Fairlie begins @46:10 Fairlie ends / questions from the floor @1:38:14 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Ray Cuzzort. [Two years before 5 men try to break into offices of the Democratic National Committee at the Watergate hotel], the speakers describe the Nixon administration either as 'Watergate' or 'waterlog'. Their usage varies, but one speaker claims that the hotel symbolizes problems of political and social life in the U.S. The actions of Nixon and his cabinet are discussed and compared to those of previous presidents. One speaker argues that Nixon's administration was effective, in that it senses the aspirations of the American people and appeals to their energies to translate them into effective programs.

description#1: Moderated by William G. MacDonald. Stanley Reed analyzes the economics behind the acquisition of nuclear weapons. Donald Michael mentions the benefits of establishing a weapon systems evaluation and who is involved in the process. Richard Fryklund argues that elected civilian officials should be in charge of what weapons system is used. Harvey Averch states that both informed government officials and civilians have a role to play in weapon systems evaluation (which he calls "systems analysis"). MacDonald defends the military by pointing out it is difficult to provide the public with accurate cost estimates for weapons systems when the majority of information is highly classified.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by E. James Archer. Rothschild outlines his points: the desirability and possibility of banning particular weapons of war, specifically the toxic (chemical and biological) and nuclear weapons; and methods of ensuring the obsolescence of war in the future. Rothschild gives a general history of weapons-use and then focuses specifically on toxic and nuclear weapons. Negative effects and the humane nature of toxic weapons are explained, as well as their effectiveness against enemies. Suggestions are given for the eventual elimination of weapon-use and the prevention of war altogether.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Welfare Reform: What Can be Done? What Should be Done?
description#1: Moderated by Susan Purdy . David Kopel and Molly Ivins debate the topic of welfare reform. Kopel argues that single parent homes are a major predictor of violent crime and other social problems. He connects illegitimate children to the American welfare system, and argues that welfare reform must address this problem. Ivins disputes the statistical basis of Kopel's argument, argues that Kopel has overstated the problem, and identifies several other factors causing the rise in single parent homes. Ivins also proposes welfare reform based on an increase in social services. Audience questions cover personal responsibility, the minimum wage, public schools, and health care.

title#1: What I Want to do When I Grow Up
description#1: Moderated by Anne R. Higman. Peter Tauber begins by asking the audience if they think it's important to grow up. Tauber then answers by staying it's very important to grow up. Malcomlm Bradbury talks about how he would be a writer like James Joyce if he could grow up again. Fourth speaker talks about the World Affair Conference. Fourth speaker states that he wanted to be president when he was younger. Fourth speaker then jokingly announces his candidacy as the President of the United States and starts his speech. Questions from the audience follow.

title#1: What I've Learned at the Conference on World Affairs
description#1: Robert McClendon recalls trying to get into the University of Wyoming as a person of color. Wendell Harris tells an anecdote about Howard Higman. Joan Higman Davies mentions the lack of international participants. Leslie Green believes that he gained a "sense of humility" from the conference. Sayre Sheldon discusses Buckminster Fuller. Mary Redick recalls her experiences with sexism in academia. Nancy Ramsey also discusses sexism in academia and notes the "importance of students." Julie Fisher recalls going to the conference. Jonathan Broder discusses his first time at the conference. Eric Sterling discusses his first experiences with the conference.

description#1: Moderated by Peter Spear. Paul Kolsby argues that classics are first romantic in their time, discusses "Offending the Audience," and lists classic moments from literature and movies. Sayre Sheldon gives her criteria for a classic and asks the audience if any novel on the New York Times Bestseller List could become a classic. Jingalu describes what a "classic" is from an Aboriginal perspective. Wendell Harris believes that there are no classics because there is no "common core of information." Roger Ebert concurs with Harris, discusses reading classics, lists some of his favorite classical authors, and explains the various levels of culture.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: What is Technology Doing to the Way We Communicate?
description#1: Moderated by Kathleen Campbell. Sidney Pike begins by discussing a few predictions regarding the future and population of the world based on his experiences with new technology Pike also predicts that English would be the only language spoken. Roger Ebert talks about how new emerging forms of communication such as emails have impacted him. Ebert explains why telephone is the greatest waste of time in modern civilization. Ervin Duggan talks about the greatest moral and human danger of new technology. Sonya Hamlin explains why people are product orientated people. Hamlin then states that technology should be used for research, and not for communication.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Horace Lewis Sawin. The panel discusses various problems with the American media. With the help of the audience, Robert McClendon identifies problems like sensationalism, bias, and negativity, which he then traces to consumer habits. Charles-Gene McDaniel argues that journalism is an overly self-critical profession, but acknowledges that the press serves the establishment. Molly Ivins examines shortcomings of the American media in the Vietnam War and El Salvador and analyzes the role of the media in politics. Panel discussion and audience questions address the relationship between government and media, journalistic bias, and alternative media.

description#1: Moderated by Leslie B. Eaton. The panel discusses the role of men in relationships. Molly Ivins argues that the question raised by the panel is inherently sexist, and that this type of thinking has negative consequences for men and women. Russell Schweickart notes the evolving definition of gender roles, and argues that men ultimately want meaning in life and a clear definition of masculinity. Mel Stewart makes a distinction between what men want and what men need and discusses the merits of polygamy. Audience questions cover the origins and future of gender roles, the concept of equality, the effects of feminism, and gender violence.

description#1: Moderated by Giora Bernstein. The panel attempts to define and discover the origins of â€œyuppiesâ€ in America. Molly Ivins identifies materialism as a defining characteristic, and wonders whether media coverage of yuppies will continue after the 1980s. Ivins and Stuart Schoffman agree that the term is a media creation, but Schoffman argues that it reflects a growing materialism in America. Peter Tauber disparages yuppie culture with jokes about Walkmen and designer water, concluding with an exhortation to ignore the trivial and improve the world.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Howie Movshovitz. The panel discusses the state of comedy. David Finkle argues that comedy is enjoying a resurgence because of television, new comedy clubs, and excellent writing. Peter Tauber shares his experience writing comedy and analyzes the success of comedians like Jay Leno and Robin Williams. Molly Ivins relates several experiences covering Texas politics, and outlines the difference between rural and urban humor. Eric Lax discusses Woody Allen and fields audience questions about Allen's career. Audience questions cover successful comedians, freedom of speech, and the nature of satire.

description#1: Moderated by Gary Blonston. Someone argues that the media does not have a liberal bias, but a conservative bias and that unbiased reporting can only come from independently owned newspapers. Someone describes the process of publishing a book. Someone states that various major reporting agencies are owned by the same people and this is due to the high costs of televised reporting and film making. Someone compares the media in the U.S. and Great Britain and notes that increased competition often does not equate to diversity in coverage.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Rolf Kjolseth. The panel discusses the administration of newspaper journalism. Richard Aregood criticizes the emphasis on profits, especially by local newspaper editors. Mariana Edmonds shares her experience developing the 60 Minutes television program, questioning the distinction between news and entertainment. Jonathan Kwitny identifies several problems resulting from newspaper monopolies. Panelist discussion and audience questions continue to examine how money affects reporting. Other topics include consumer behavior, controversial reporting, and potential solutions.

titleSeries#1: Series XI: The Changing Understanding of What is Human and What is Natural in Human Nature
description#1: Moderated by Payson D. Sheets. Jack Forem begins by suggesting the audience to look at two words that seems to be implied in the title: wholeness and holiness. Forem then talks about how any individual who lives in the wholeness of life would be a person capable of being called holy. Jane Howard talks about her experiences investing different approaches toward holiness and wholeness. Roger Ebert also talks about his experience regarding his first-hand contact with two representatives in the human potential movement. Jack Forem ends the panel by talking about movements and followers.

Urquhart also asks who the book would corrupt, if they would be corrupted in the first place; 12:34 Marya Mannes begins talking; Mannes states that, like Urquhart, she was also not corrupted after reading â€œLolita.â€ 13:40 Mannes continues to say that censorship makes no sense and did a poll of ten friends to get their opinions on â€œLolitaâ€; 15:10 Mannes states she disagrees with Urquhart about his opinion that older men would change their way of life around little girls after reading the book; 18:05 [Esmee Brooks?] disagrees with Mannes and thinks the book is not pornographic at all. identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Why Conservative Pundits Are So Mean
description#1: Moderated by Christopher Brauchli. The panel discusses the American conservative approach to politics. Jurek Martin argues that conservatives engage in a political approach based on hate and lies. Daniel Odescalchi disagrees with the premise of the panel, making the case that conservative pundits are usually wrongly accused of meanness when they use humor. Molly Ivins argues that she is less concerned with unkind rhetoric than with policies that hurt people. Michael Franc explores the media landscape in the 20th century, concluding that as organizations compete for ratings they often become mean-spirited. Panel discussion and audience questions attempt to define conservatism and the possibility for civility in political discourse.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Why Dubya Could Make a Great President
description#1: Moderated by Kathy Howe. Shortly after George W. Bush's inauguration, the speakers ironically make the case that Bush could make a great president. Topics include Bush's economic, education, and foreign policy. The question and answer period takes a slightly more serious tone, as the panel discusses Bush's Texas political career, family, Cabinet appointments, environmental record, and potential judicial nominees.

title#1: Why I am a Computer Zombie
description#1: Moderated by Dana Leibsohn. James Jackson discusses the use of computers when writing. The panelists are distracted by Roger Ebert's "lap portable." Jackson returns to tell his personal experience with using a computer and how it inspired the name for this panel. John Gliedman discusses the evolution of the computer and his personal experience with using a computer, downloading software, and using a lap portable. Roger Ebert makes many comments about computers including various personal anecdotes, how the lap portable has revolutionized writing, the difference between various word processing programs, and online communication. Jackson returns to further elaborate on online communication.
