title#1: Why is it Impossible to Walk Joyfully in American Cities?
titleSeries#1: Series XXXIII: Ã¢â‚¬Â¦ in a Meaner and Rougher World
description#1: Moderated by Karl Openshaw. Roger Ebert begins by stating that it's almost impossible to walk around an American city in the same way one walks around London or Paris. Ebert talks about two things that have happened to take away the joy in walking in American cities. Margot explains that the thing that prevents people from walking joyfully is because most of them are not doing what they want to do, and not living the life that they want. Phillip K. Bock discusses how walking joyfully has a lot to do with expectations. Bock then briefly talks about walking down a public street.

description#1: Moderated by Charles Nilon; 00:10 Nilon introduces the panel topic and panelists; 05:13 Margot Adler begins her discussion. She asks how many people were at the witchcraft panel last year; 06:00 Adler talks about ideas regarding Neo-pagan witchcraft religions; 08:06 Adler talks about the idea that monotheism is an idea of religious imperialism; 09:36 Adler talks about the idea that religion is not always dependent on creed but based on practice; 10:40 Adler mentions that popular culture conceives a deity to always be male. She continues to talk about the initiatory process in religion; 13:00 Adler lists what people are looking for in a Pagan religion today such as ritual and both male and female ideas if deity; 13:46 Adler talks about the Society for Creative Anachronism; 16:12 Adler talks about why she got involved in modern witchcraft. She talks about her encounter with Greek mythology; 18:11 Adler talks about the book titled â€œEncounters with the Archdruidâ€ by John McPhee; 19:50 Adler talks about the small religious groups she discovered. She noticed that these groups donâ€™t prophesize and they are central, autonomous organizations that believe in participation; 27:54 Betty Dodson begins her discussion. She talks about the sexual awareness trainings she conducts with women; 29:20 Dodson talks about her own awareness as a witch during last yearâ€™s panel discussion on witchcraft. She continues to talk about her physical and sexual consciousness groups; 37:10 Dodson talks about using sexual energy for unification as a ritual and healing process in her groups; 44:50 Louisa Messologhites begins her discussion. She jokes she is the â€œChristian witchâ€ and talks about the loss of knowledge from the roots of the religion over time; 45:48 Messologhites tells a story about her mom. She also talks about her readings about the witch; 48:30 Messologhites talks about the ancient functions the witch performed; 53:20 Messologhites talks about the role of the hypnotist; 55:20 Messologhites talks about a game she would play as a child; 59:27 First audience member asks Adler a question about religious symbols being either masculine or feminine; 01:05:04 Audience member asks Adler to describe some rituals she has been involved in; 01:11:48 Audience member states that the items the panel talked about is not witchcraft and says witchcraft is like Christianity; 01:16:28 Audience member asks for a definition of witchcraft; 01:27:37 Audience member asks about the credibility of modern druids; 01:29:00 Audience member asks Messologhites about the difference between the cult philosophy in witchcraft and cult history in the United States; 01:32:02 Audience member asks about the book of shadows; 01:34:12 Audience member follows up by asking what the basic tenants of the book of shadow are; 01:34:55 Audience member asks how South American shamanism culture fits into witchcraft; 01:37:50 Audience member follows up with a comment about the shaman; 01:39:05 Audience member asks about the matriarchal role; 01:43:37 Audience member asks how important is the belief in reincarnation to witchcraft and what are the political ramifications of this reawakened psychic power that is occurring; 01:52:34 Audience member asks the panel if they think the use of the ritual is tapping into an archetype; 01:53:50 Audience member asks about the rituals of birthing; 01:55:39 Audience member asks about a discipline with the small groups Adler came across; 01:56:55 Audience member asks where most witches are at with the religion knowing that Adler does not believe in the supernatural. Adler talks about theology; 02:01:50 Audience member asks Adler if it is difficult to connect with nature living in New York; 02:05:05 Audience member asks a question about tarot [catalogerâ€™s note: question difficult to decipher]; 02:05:45 Audience member asks if a large group is necessary to conduct a right.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Susan Barney Jones. The panel discusses American foreign policy after the Cold War. Richard Dennis Baum discusses the end of the adversarial relationship between communism and liberalism, but argues that other conflicts will take its place. Julie Anne Johnson further illustrates the American relationship to the Soviet Union, and anticipates a difficult post-Cold War transition for the intelligence community. Richard Farson argues that the United States will be able to transition more of its resources into domestic development. Molly Ivins examines potential domestic and international conflicts, large and small. Audience questions cover the military-industrial complex, the war on drugs, and international aid organizations.

description#1: Moderated by Sharon Menard; 00:22 Mary Lou De La Cerda begins her discussion. She talks about her childhood; 02:30 De La Cerda talks about her worry of polarization and a lack of communication between members of La Raza Unida; 05:33 Unidentified person asks how La Raza Unida accounts for the humiliation during movements of conquer; 13:50 Unidentified panelist talks about the poor communication in the United States between white people and minority people. The main question was â€œhow does a minority defend him or herself in the United States?â€; 26:00 Panelists talk about the movement in a school and a school teacher; 32:30 De La Cerda talks about an arm band; 45:00 The panel talks about a school teacher again; 54:00 Panelists talk about how they spread information. One panelist talks about calling editors for newspapers and asks the editor to write about a topic the panelist wants to share with people; 01:00:00 Unidentified panelist talks about â€œservice to yourselfâ€ and goes into her background; 01:05:00 Unidentified panelist talks about the power of women to be equal to men; 01:13:00 Panelists talk about how the movement has managed to remain as a peaceful revolution. An audience member asks a question about women making an equal salary to men in Chile; 01:18:00 Audience member and panelists talk about the roles of men and women in a relationship in Chile. Carmen Orrego-Salas mentions that the role of a couple acts as a team where there is equality; 01:31:00 Unidentified person asks if there is any psychological difference between a man and woman in Chile. Orrego-Salas does not know how to answer the question because they never felt like there was a difference; 01:33:00 The conversation changes to women in sports and what would be considered â€œunfeminineâ€; 01:38:00 Orrego-Salas talks about the relationship between parents and children in Chile. Orrego-Salas talks about the need to instill leadership in early childhood; 01:55:00 Orrego-Salas talks about keeping her maiden name after being married and how her children bear her maiden name; 02:00:00 The panelists talk about how women manage to take care of children while working. The panel continues to say that the liberation of a woman does not happen in a movement, but happens in the individual self; 02:05:17 Audience member asks a question about curse words in Spanish and Orrego-Salas reflects on a story from her childhood;02:09:50 Orrego-Salas talks about death; 02:18:09 Audio cuts out and recording ends.

description#1: Mitzi M. Wertheim states that in every war, in which the United States has fought prior to the 20th century, women have seen combat. She gives the history of women in the services during the 20th century, noting the major turning points in policy during World War II and the change in attitudes during the 1960s and 1970s. She describes the current issues of women in the military, including pregnancy, promotion, and combat service. Chairman Dwayne C. Nuzum presiding.

title#1: Women Journalists: The Girls on the Bus
subject#3: Women in the mass media industry
description#1: Moderated by Kathi George. Molly Ivins shares her experience as a women journalist in a nearly all male dominated institution, stating that it was only her excessive height that allowed her to really break into the kind of work she wanted. Margot Adler discusses sexual harassment she faced in the workplace, as well as the immense pressure on journalists and the high suicide rate that accompanies the profession. Myra Lea MacPherson discusses the discrimination she faced and the need she felt to act like one of the boys. The Q&A session explores gender roles and ethical issues in reporting.

description#1: Moderated by Max S. Peters. Norman Cousins begins by briefly talking about the death of General Douglas McArthur. Cousins then questions how the United States can provide security for Japan, Philippines, and etc. He also questions if arms are working. Cousins then provides an example of where arms didn't work too well. He states that just getting rid of arms isn't good enough, and states that it's necessary for something to take the place of the arms. Cousins ends the panel by stating that he believes America still has time to think/act to justify the great gift of life.

description#1: Moderated by Joseph R. Smiley; 00:00 Smiley introduces the panel; 04:15 Buckminster Fuller begins his discussion; 05:00 Fuller tells a personal story from 1927. He talks about the principles of industrialization and how man must earn a living; 11:00 Fuller mentions that America is not a nation but represents the highest world confluence of separate nations. He continues to say that hosting a world conference in America and Colorado is fitting; 12:03 Fuller talks about how fortunate he has been to be able to visit many universities to speak. He talks about his fifth trip around the world due to the many university invitations; 15:00 Fuller talks about the technological advancements and industrialization he has witnessed over time; 16:56 Fuller changes topic to talk about the idea of wealth. He also talks about trade and currency between countries; 21:00 Fuller continues to talk about wealth in relation to wars. He talks about the term â€œcapabilityâ€ often used by the military; 24:00 Fuller talks about capability and how it stems from two kinds of energies from man and the world. He mentions radiation as energy and matter as energy. He also talks about energy from the view of the physicist; 29:55 Fuller talks about the experience and intellectual capabilities man brings once the energy, wealth regeneration is recognized and used for the advantage of man; 31:02 Fuller continues to expand on the intellectual factors of man. He talks about how man continues to learn more; therefore, the wealth of the universe is always expanding; 33:18 Fuller changes the topic to observations he has made about the earth. He starts with a story about the traffic pattern in the streets of Tokyo, Japan in 1958. He talks about the transition from people travelling by bicycle to the automobile in Japan; 37:29 Fuller talks about his last trip where he was invited to Ghana in West Africa to speak at the National Academy of Sciences. He continues to talk about politics and politicians from the places he visited; 44:00 Fuller talks about a typical day for a college student in Ghana. He also talks about his experience speaking with students and staff at the university. He mentions that the students seemed noncommittal at first and interest was gained slowly once the students realized Fuller was telling the truth. He also talks about a large structure he built with the students; 50:00 Fuller talks about how much people can accomplish when resources are handled correctly. He continues to talk about a world revolution of design initiated by the universities; 58:08 Fuller offers his prognostication about what will happen around the earth in the future. He mentions that China will industrialize faster than any other industrialization period before. He also talks about automation which will generate more wealth and unemployment. He concludes by saying that universities and the students are the tools that will advance wealth in the world; 01:03:00 Fuller finishes his discussion.

identifierSource#2: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series X: Sex in the Afternoon
description#1: Moderated by David A. Breternitz. Roger Ebert describes the evolution of movies in terms of the average viewer, the types of movies, the film rating system, types of X-rated films, and violence in movies. Kay L. Corbett asks why American society is so obsessed with sex and if the panelists have ever seen a "really beautiful erotic film." Michael Wadleigh describes the type of people on rating commissions, the process of rating Woodstock, and censorship of Woodstock in other countries. Sam Rosenberg argues that a similar movement has already occurred in literature and that, in each time period, sex was used as a socio-political tool.

title#1: Zeus, Energy, and the Hairy Man Within
description#1: Moderated by Olivia Edwards. This panel explores the changing role of men and their relationship to women during the womenâ€™s movement. Stuart Schoffman introduces the work of Robert Bly and discusses the necessity of creating an image of maleness that is both sexual and sensitive. Michael Stoff shares his own experience in a time of changing gender roles and his own familiarity with the isolation of sensitive men. Molly Ivins counters Schoffmanâ€™s point, arguing that Robert Bly isnâ€™t relevant and men are just using Blyâ€™s work as an excuse to demonize the womenâ€™s movement. Laurie Taylor contemplates the very nature of talking about oneself and the rhetoric used to describe men and women.
